PETITION.TITLE: Industrial Relations
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that any reform to Australia's system of industrial relations should recognise the special needs of employees to be protected from disadvantage, exploitation and discrimination in the workplace.

We the petitioners oppose the Coalition policies which represent a fundamentally anti‐worker regime and we call upon the Senate to provide an effective check and balance to the Coalition's legislative program by rejecting such a program and ensuring that:
(1) The existing powers of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission (AIRC) be maintained to provide for an effective independent umpire overseeing awards and workplace bargaining processes.

(2) The proposed system of Australian Workplace Agreements (AWAs) should be subject to the same system of approval required for the approval of certified agreements (through enterprise bargaining). Specifically an AWA should not come into effect unless it is approved by the AIRC.

(3) The approval of agreements contained in the legislation should be public and open to scrutiny. There should be provision for the involvement of parties who have a material concern relating to the approval of an agreement, including unions seeking to maintain the no disadvantage guarantees.
(4) Paid rates awards be preserved and capable of adjustment, as is currently the case in the legislation.
(5) The AIRC's powers to arbitrate and make awards must be preserved in the existing form and not be restricted to a stripped back set of minimum or core conditions.
(6) The legislation should encourage the processes of collective bargaining and ensure that a certified agreement within its term of operation cannot be over‐ridden by a subsequent AWA.
(7) The secondary boycott provisions should be preserved in their existing form.

(8) The powers and responsibility of the AIRC to ensure the principle of equal pay for work of equal value should be preserved in its existing form. We oppose any attempt by the Coalition to restrict the AIRC from dealing with over‐award gender based pay equity issues.
(9) A `fair go all round' for unfair dismissal so that all workers currently able to access these remedies are able to do so in a fair manner, at no cost.
(10) Workers under State industrial regulations maintain their rights to access the federal awards system in its current form.
Your petitioners therefore urge the Senate to reject the above proposed reforms to the area of industrial relations.

PETITION.TITLE: Food Labelling
PETITION.PARA: We, the undersigned citizens and residents of Australia, call on all Senators to support implementation of the following:

PARA.TAB: a requirement to label with the production process, all foods from genetic engineering technologies or containing their products;
real public participation in decisions on whether to allow commercialisation of foods, additives and processing agents produced by gene technologies;
premarket human trials and strict safety rules on these foods, to assess production processes as well as the end products.

PETITION.PARA: Precedents which support our petition include several examples of foods already labelled with the processes of production: irradiated foods (here and internationally); certified organic foods; and many conventional foods (pasteurised; salt‐reduced; free‐range; vitamin‐enriched; to name only a few).
We ask you all to accord a high priority to supporting and implementing our petition.

PETITION.TITLE: Gun Control
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

The petition of the undersigned shows that the overwhelming majority of Australians support uniform, national gun laws and the associated compensation measures as agreed between the Prime Minister, State Premiers and the Chief Ministers of the ACT and NT.

Your petitioners as that the Senate continue to demonstrate its firm support for these measures; take all possible action to expedite their implementation; and resist all calls for the control measures to be watered down or abandoned.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

the Petition of the undersigned shows that the Australian Broadcasting Corporation will be forced to significantly reduce its services in Tasmania in order to meet the Budget cut of $65 million as announced by the Government.
Your Petitioners request the Senate to oppose the funding cuts proposed by the Government and to ensure that:
a) the ABC can maintain its valuable communication and education services to Tasmania;
b) ABC Launceston—the ABC's largest regional operation in Australia—can maintain its range of programming;
c) the Launceston television crew—one of only three in regional Australia—is maintained;
d) the future of the Tasmanian Symphony Orchestra is maintained; and
e) the Coalition's pre‐election promise of maintaining existing levels of Commonwealth funding to the ABC is upheld.

PETITION.TITLE: Australian Broadcasting Corporation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
Your Petitioners request that the Senate take note as follows:
a) We call upon the Australian Government to ensure that Triennial Funding is retained
b) That no cuts are made to the operation of the Australian Broadcasting Commission
c) Further, we call on the Australian Government to ensure that ABC services remain free of commercial sponsorship and advertising
d) That no cuts are made to radio and television services
e) That Radio National, Classic FM, Radio JJJ and Regional Radio Services are retained.

PETITION.TITLE: Nursing Homes
PETITION.PARA: To the honourable senators in the Senate assembled:

I beg the Senate to inquire into the number of nursing homes, particularly small nursing homes, disadvantaged to the point of devastation as a consequence of decisions made by officers of the Department of Health and Family Services where the decisions are
(a) contrary to law on the one hand and/or
(b) contrary to published circulars (non‐reviewable at law) on the other hand.

I beg the Senate to ensure that safeguards are set in place to ensure that, in the future, nursing home proprietors severely disadvantaged by Department of Health and Family Services decisions have a fair and independent opportunity for review of those decisions—Administrative Review Council report No 37 refers.

PETITION.TITLE: Aboriginal Sacred Sites
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable President and members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned recognises the significance and vital role of Aboriginal Sacred sites, as integral to the observance of Aboriginal law culture, and spirituality.
Your Petitioners ask the Senate to call on the Australian Government to:
1. halt any further desecration of the Sacred sites at Evans Head New South Wales on behalf of the Traditional owner and Custodian, Mr L. Wilson.

2. actively encourage Senator, the Hon. John Herron, Federal Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, to carry out his statutory duty and protect Aboriginal culture and heritage as charged under the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Heritage Protection Act 1984 (Cth).
3. protect all Sacred sites, areas and sites of significance for all Aboriginal Australians.

SPEECH.PARA: To: Hon John Howard, Prime Minister of Australia
Hon Senator Amanda Vanstone, Minister for Employment, Education, Training & Youth Affairs

The undersigned are extremely concerned about threats to university funding and express their support for Australian public universities and for government measures to ensure that the highest possible proportion of school leavers and adult students can have a university education. We demand no cuts in Commonwealth Government funding of universities fully funded wage increases for general and academic staff in universities full Commonwealth funding for the new Queensland campuses announced at Cairns, Gladstone, Hervey Bay, Sunshine Coast, Ipswich, Logan
A FAIR GO FOR Queensland STUDENTS!
A Petition to the Honourable the Speaker and Members of the House of Representatives assembled in the (Commonwealth Parliament of Australia.

This petition of certain residents in the State of Queensland draws to the attention of the House our concerns that extra tertiary places, previously announced for Queensland universities, may now be revoked.

The previous Federal Government allocated an extra 7600 funded student places for Queensland universities over a three year period. In addition $43.8 million in capital funding was set aside for campuses and facilities in regional areas, including Ipswich, Logan, the Gold Coast, the Sunshine Coast, Wide Bay, Gladstone, Rockhampton and Cairns. However these initiatives are now in doubt following recent comments and speculation by Federal Government Ministers. Any reversal of the above decisions will severely disadvantage potential Queensland tertiary students. Our State continues to experience rapid growth and education services remain a priority need.
We request the House to call on the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia to guarantee that the tertiary places and facilities, previously announced for Queensland universities, be delivered.
The Right Honourable Mr John Howard
Prime Minister and The Honourable Ms Amanda Vanstone Minister for Employment, Education, Training & Youth Affairs Parliament House Canberra ACT 2600

We the undersigned citizens respectfully submit that any further reform to the higher education sector should be undertaken in a planned, consultative manner in order to achieve clearly specified social and economic goals. We the petitioners oppose the random, ad hoc and irresponsible nature of the current threats to reduce Commonwealth funding to universities which are damaging to our international reputation as a provider of high quality tertiary education; disruptive to orderly planning and long term development for the sector, needlessly painful to staff and students attempting to work within the current environment; and devastating to our regional economy which is still recovering from drought.
We ask that:
1. the government state publicly its vision and direction for the future of Australian universities as a matter of urgency;

2. the government recognise its moral and economic duty to recompense university staff for their achievements in social and economic reform by maintaining, as a bare minimum, the wage supplement previously offered;
3. the government honour its pre-election commitment to maintaining both the number of student places and the quality of education offered by the Australian university system;
4. the government honour its commitment to rural Australians by adequately supporting regional universities and other public service institutions.
Your petitioners urge you to address these matters immediately and positively.

SPEECH.PARA: That an address be presented by the Senate to His Excellency the Governor‐General, as follows:
MAY IT PLEASE YOUR EXCELLENCY
We, the Senate of the Commonwealth of Australia in Parliament assembled, desire to present the following address:
The Senate:
(a) commends you for defining signposts to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander reconciliation in the inaugural Vincent Lingiari lecture; and
(b) expresses its support for those signposts, which are as follows:

PARA.TAB: (i) the express acknowledgment of the past injustice and oppression suffered by Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Australians,
(ii) mutual recognition of a need for some redress,

(iii) rejection of any policy of complete assimilation and integration, and acceptance of an approach which recognises both that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people have the right to effective choice about the degree to which, and the pace at which, they are assimilated with, or integrated in, ordinary Australian society, and that the role of government should be to assist the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples to achieve their goals by their own efforts,
(iv) recognition that there is Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander leadership which can and does speak with authority on behalf of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people,
(v) recognition that the heart of reconciliation is a consensus that indigenous and non‐indigenous Australians can move forward as friends and equals,
(vi) recognition that reconciliation between indigenous and non‐indigenous Australians can be achieved, notwithstanding that much remains undone,
(vii) consensus about steps already taken or about to be taken, and steps and policies to be taken or followed in the future to partly redress the wrongs of the past, and
(viii) transformation of consensus into a formal ceremony of reconciliation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: — by leave—If I heard Senator Bolkus correctly, he is seeking to have this matter hanging over a senator's head for another three months. We would obviously oppose that. He has been hounding Senator Ferris since before she came into this place, when she was a senator‐elect.

SPEECH.PARA: This is, of course, his second attempt to bring her down in this way. The first instance is history. In the second instance, he being dissatisfied with the determinations in the past, he has decided to have another go on another alleged set of facts. So he gives the notice of motion; presumably, he would not do that flippantly. He presumably believes he has got a case to support the claim that he makes. I would have thought that on any reasonable assessment of natural justice, if he has got that case, he ought to bring it and the Senate should have its opportunity to make its determination, rather than simply make the allegation, put it on the public record and then seek to leave it hanging over the senator for a period of three months.

I think that is totally unreasonable in any circumstances, let alone all the circumstances of the history of this matter. Therefore, what he is seeking to do should be opposed. If he wants to pursue his motion, he ought to do so and he will either win or lose. If he loses, hopefully, he might get on to something more constructive in the future. But certainly, what is being suggested now is totally unreasonable, totally unfair and the Senate should not be supportive of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—In some informal discussions yesterday, it was quite apparent that the government would need some time to consider this proposed resolution and to consider their position.
—We don't want time.

—No, I did have an opportunity to talk to Senator Hill very briefly yesterday and put to him that maybe they would like some time. The motivation behind deferring this is to give some time to the government to work out their position. If you do not want time now, that is one thing. If you do not want as much time, that is another thing.

BREAK.PARA: I say to you, Senator Hill, that you are accusing me of hounding Senator Ferris. But the hounding is really coming from your party and from within your party in South Australia. This issue would not have had any sort of legs at all had it not been for the degree of hounding that has been going on there. The intention on our side has been to give the government some time to consider its position here. That was the motivation behind this. If the government would like to defer this, for instance, to the next day of sitting, that is something we can do. If you want to go ahead today, we can go ahead today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Without anticipating an order of the day, I would like to say that I do not want to see any senator here feeling under great personal pressure because of the delay of a motion like this, having it hanging over her head for months and months. I have seen this happen at state parliamentary level in Tasmania. It is crucifying. I think we can do better than that. I think the Senate's energies ought to be going into rectifying the quite untoward circumstances of the constitution, a glitch in the constitution, which has led to this situation, rather than pursuing an individual who has been caught up by it.

SPEECH.PARA: That is my stand on this predicament in which Senator Ferris finds herself. I have made that clear to her and to the opposition. I think we would be much better to take her off the burner, so to speak, get out our microscope and magnifying glass, look at the constitution and act on it, so that we do not have future senators and members of another place being caught up by a section of the constitution which I do not think was ever intended to catch them up in that way.
Question resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of that vote, in view of the fact that it does remain available to any citizen of the state of South Australia to pursue this matter, and in view of the fact that I think some parties are not ready to proceed with this at this particular stage—and that is not us—
—Who gave the notice, Nick?
—I gave the notice, but I do say to you, Senator Hill—
—Through the chair, please, Senator.

—Through the chair, this is a matter that is of concern and, in fact, of immediate responsibility of the government—that is, whether a vote in this place is tainted in any way at all, given the notice the Senate is on in respect of the eligibility of a particular senator. But, given that notice and the government's responsibility here, which it is not meeting, and given the fact that this matter is available to any citizen in the state of South Australia to pursue at any particular time, I withdraw notice of motion No. 2 standing in my name.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask that general business notice of motion No. 196, standing in my name for today relating to an order for production of documents, be taken as a formal motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment)

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to say why we will vote against general business notice of motion No. 196. This process of return to order was something that was exercised on rare occasions.
—What?
—No, you go back and check the records.
—I was the target about 10 times personally.
—On rare occasions.
—Rare occasions, my foot.

—On rare occasions and in exceptional circumstances. What has changed over a period of time is that it has just become another tool of procedure rather than a circumstance that would merit the enormous amount of work and effort that is taken to produce a set of documents that covers everything imaginable. Senator Collins would understand because he was in default of an order of this Senate for some several weeks.
—Not me, that was a colleague.

—You were in default of an order of the Senate for some several weeks because you complained of the level of work that was necessary for the bureaucracy to produce what you regarded as an excessive requirement of documentation. The circumstance of my opposition to this motion is not dissimilar to that.

SPEECH.PARA: Since I made the Hinchinbrook decision, I have been putting together for the Senate and for the public a set of every document that I believe to be relevant starting with the applications, all the scientific advice that we sought, all the principle advice of agencies within my department—whether it be the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority or the Australian Heritage Commission—the advice of the department itself and even specific references to advice of branches and sections within the department. All were put together on my instruction to be made public in order that the public can make a judgment on my decisions in a transparent environment. The public has a right for that.

That is reasonable practice. All of the key documentation was tabled yesterday. Not being satisfied with that, Senator Woodley wants the department, in effect, because they have to do all the work, to produce for me and therefore for the Senate:
all documents, correspondence, reports,—
I think we have put in all reports—
advices and memos and scientific assessments received by the Minister, his office, the secretary of the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories . . .

He wants all this not only in the term of this government but also going back before the term of this government, going back to 1 January 1995. So matters that clearly cannot be relevant to any assessment I make, he nevertheless demands be produced for the Senate.

That department is grossly overworked as it is. Senator Woodley might not understand this, but I get 40,000 letters a year apart from anything else. I would suggest that it is being unreasonable. It is over the top. It is unnecessary either for this Senate or for the public. It is, therefore, an abuse of this—

TALK.START.PARA: —Did they talk to you about it?
—No.

—Talk about what? This is an abuse of this process. I think it is even further extending a precedent that has been grossly extended since this opposition lost government and therefore has built a new enthusiasm for these sort of procedures. I think the time has come when the Senate says, `This has gone too far; to be fair is to be fair, but this is just unreasonable and almost becoming unworkable.' I would therefore urge the Senate to vote against this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Returns to order are an important procedure of the Senate in terms of obtaining information, with which I am extremely familiar. As Senator Hill knows full well, I was the subject of quite a number of returns to order. Despite all the huffing and puffing, I actually do have some high regard for the institution of parliament. I also have a fundamental view—I have certainly exercised it in Senate estimates as well as with returns to order—that information which is fairly asked for is entitled to be provided.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Hill is correct when he says that on a number of occasions the sheer omnibus nature of the demand was absurd in the actual volume of work and material that was required to produce the papers required. I have participated in this exercise, and there is no question that there is an enormous amount of work required to turn up these documents.

Clearly, the government has been entirely at fault in this. On every occasion that I can recall the normal procedure was that when a return to order was made, if the government considered that the ambit of the order was too wide to be reasonable—this certainly happened when we were in government, and I can say this personally on a number of occasions—discussions were held with the opposition or whoever was moving the return to order about potentially amending it to produce a more reasonable or achievable result. Clearly, the government has just ignored this. They knew perfectly well that it was happening. Senator Hill has waited until now to jump up and say, `Oh, this is all too terrible.'

By way of interjection, I asked the mover of this return to order whether any attempt had been made to discuss with him a potential amendment of the order. He responded no, no-one from the government had been near him.

There is one particular piece of nonsense that I want to nail down completely. Senator Hill said it when he began his contribution. With great respect, Senator Hill, it is statements like this that give politicians a bad name. Senator Hill said that a return to order was a rare thing in this parliament and we have abused it. I think I have moved one.

TALK.START.PARA: —How many do you think have been carried in the 13 years that we have been in opposition?

—Let me tell you. After my staff had finished rolling around on the floor of my office, hearing Senator Hill say that it was a rare occasion, I asked the Clerk for some advice on this. I am advised that in the last parliament—
—No, the last 13 years.
—The last parliament will do.
—Select the period that suits the argument, hey? It is the oldest trick in the book.

—The oldest trick in the book? Can I point out in terms of that idiotic interjection that necessarily the number of times a return to order was moved in the last parliament was significantly smaller than over the last 13 years. If Senator Hill wants me to multiply this number by a significant degree, I will go back over the last 13 years, but can you accept the obvious, Senator Hill, that the number is going to be bigger and not smaller?
—The number over the last three years would have been more than any previous three yearly period. Do it for six years then.

—Let me settle the argument in terms of Senator Hill's definition of `rare'. In the past parliament alone—forget the last 13 years—there were 53 returns to order. I was the subject of quite a number of them; I certainly remembered mine. In terms of that blatant attempt to mislead and gull the Senate—which is not going to be gulled on this occasion—you have a strange definition of rare. There were 53 returns to order in the last parliament.

SPEECH.PARA: In conclusion, if debate is to mean anything in this chamber, on the basis of Senator Hill's contribution alone, the Senate should carry this return to order.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Woodley, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I should not reveal what happens in the Democrat party room, but I can say that the Democrat party room believes that I am so reasonable that, really, I should be much more unreasonable at times. I reject that accusation that I am unreasonable. My own colleagues do not think so.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Hill has made a number of arguments for refusing formality on this return to order. Let me point out that he did speak to me. He said that he was making available certain documents. Having examined those documents, I have discovered that they are documents from July 1996 to today's date. However, I did ask for documents from 1 January 1995, the reason being that the whole process has been corrupted right through and the documents are necessary. We do need them so that we can get this process straightened out—the process in terms of the original environmental report, the process in terms of the Queensland government and the process in terms of what has happened in this place. Right through the process has been corrupted and I believe it is time that we had all of these documents available.

In terms of whether or not the government, when it was in opposition, did not seek returns to order on an inordinate number of occasions, let me point out that this very issue of Hinchinbrook was the subject of a return to order by Senator Ian Macdonald in November 1994. When the coalition was in opposition on this exact issue—on the whole matter of Port Hinchinbrook itself—it sought a return to order for documents, and they were provided by the Labor Party, which was then in government.

I am only asking on the exact issue that the coalition itself sought a return to order on. What I need, perhaps, to reassure Senator Hill about is that I will be seeking to extend the date because the date was for today.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Woodley, you need now to move your motion. If you are seeking to amend it, perhaps you would do that first.
—I seek leave to move the motion standing in my name, No. 196, and to amend the date to Thursday, 19 September.
—I ask that general business notice of motion No. 207 standing in my name, relating to sandmining in D'Entrecasteaux National Park, be taken as a formal motion.
—Is there any objection to this motion being taken as formal?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a brief statement.
—Are you objecting to formality?
—The government will not be opposing the motion going formal.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I just want to say that the government would be voting against this motion and I will explain our reasons very briefly. In relation to Senator Margetts's motion there are three points to be made. Firstly, the Commonwealth government has absolutely no jurisdiction over this land management decision in Western Australia. In relation to the excision of this area in D'Entrecasteaux National Park, the Western Australian government will be going through a whole environmental impact assessment process involving the Environmental Protection Authority in the instance that mining is proposed. The Commonwealth has absolutely no jurisdiction there. It is possible that, under certain circumstances in the future, the Commonwealth may be required to act. There may be processes that do trigger Commonwealth action on behalf of the Minister for the Environment. That could occur if export licences were sought, for example, and if the Australian Heritage Commission Act came into play.

SPEECH.PARA: The second important point to note is that there is multiple use of national parks across Australia. This, of course, is not unusual or specifically a Western Australian phenomenon, as most members of the Senate would know.
The third and final point I would like to make is that Senator Margetts's motion says:
. . . calls on the Federal Government to put into practice the rhetoric that it has used in relation to the Natural Heritage Trust of Australia Bill 1996 . . .

I ask all honourable senators to understand that the government's intention is not to put into practice rhetoric. We are very keen not to put in place the rhetoric of the National Heritage Trust Bill and its funding by the sale of one‐third of Telstra. We are, in fact, very keen to urgently put in place the billion dollars plus worth of programs which will make an historic difference, not only to the amount of resources that are going into environmental rehabilitation and conservation, but also, very importantly, in relation to this motion, to increase the cooperation between the two larger levels of state and federal governments which the Natural Heritage Trust Bill will ensure. It will see the biggest increase in cooperation between state and federal governments on a whole range of issues, and vegetation protection within national parks is, of course, a crucial part of that. As I say, we have not opposed formality, but we will be voting against this motion for those reasons.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I do not intend to canvass the whole issue. Obviously that would have been canvassed if there had been a full debate on the issue. I would like to say, however, that Senator Campbell has used even more so, I think, part of the argument that has been used in the past in relation to mining. He said there is no power for the Commonwealth government to intervene. I remind Senator Campbell that there are the corporations powers. I also remind Senator Campbell that the government tried to throw away the export powers—tried to toss them away—and the rest of the Senate caught them and threw them back. Basically, the government maintained those export powers and it is possible for the government to intervene via export powers and, if you like, some elements of corporate power if they so desire.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a defining issue in the environment in Western Australia. The defining issue here is that the federal government is choosing not to take action, not that they have no power to take action. I look forward to the majority of the Senate supporting this when it comes to the vote.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—One of the problems I have is that when a matter comes before the chamber, and a request is made for it to be dealt with formally, one does not hear the arguments in depth. I had hoped in respect of this matter that we would have heard the arguments in depth. I have not heard them and I really cannot vote on the matter at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: I would suggest that the matter might be adjourned. I do not know whether I am able to move the adjournment of a motion when a request has been made for it to be taken as formal. I know you can move an adjournment of the debate, but this is a matter that is to be taken as formal, therefore without debate. I assume that one could, through a contingent motion, move the adjournment of the matter, but I would hope that perhaps we could get some understanding that either we withdraw the formality bit so that people can hear what the arguments are, or alternatively have the matter deferred or adjourned to the next day of sitting.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine, I have been advised that you cannot adjourn the motion, but Senator Margetts could, if she so wished, withdraw the motion and move to have it postponed to a later date. That would be the alternative. She would withdraw the request for formality and then move to postpone the motion. That would be the only way we could achieve what you wanted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—The problem with this situation is the urgency of the matter. The problem is also that we have quite clearly here, at face value at least, the principle of national parks. What is the attitude of this chamber to the sanctity of national parks? In the motion itself is the proposition that in Western Australia part of a national park of national and global significance is about to be excised and handed across to sandmining by the state authorities. This is a matter of national importance. It is a matter that needs acting upon urgently and ought not to be allowed to drift away into the future while that process is proceeding at state level in Western Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Margetts has said, it is a litmus issue for environmentalists, and that means a large section of the population in Western Australia. We should be treating it with a degree of urgency, while, if there is an avenue open for further debate, taking that avenue as well.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—In respect of the concern Senator Harradine has rightly raised, the opposition would have supported this motion as a formal motion. It is an extremely important issue. The matter at hand is the proposal by the Western Australian government to excise a portion of the D'Entrecasteaux National Park in south‐west Western Australia—an absolutely beautiful area, I might add; I have been there myself—for sandmining.

SPEECH.PARA: I might add, in respect of the concerns raised about any powers of the Commonwealth government, the Commonwealth government has a direct power of export controls over mineral sands.

TALK.START.PARA: —I said that.

—That is exactly right. So Senator Parer, in order for this to even go ahead, has to be prepared to issue an export licence for this product. Now it is urgent and I understand that. The reason I am rising briefly is this: if Senator Margetts wished to move a suspension of standing orders to have the matter debated we would support the suspension of standing orders. I am certainly ready to debate it.
—by leave—I am happy to move for the suspension of standing orders. I might need some guidance in the wording that I would use.

— Senator Margetts, I have been advised that you only need to do that if somebody is objecting to it being taken as formal, so I would need to put that the motion be formal and, if there is objection, then you have the alternate route to take. Is there any objection to the motion put by Senator Margetts being taken as formal?
—Yes.
— There being objection, the motion is not formal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Margetts moving a motion relating to the conduct of the business of the Senate, namely a motion to give precedence to general business notice of motion No. 207.

I never thought I would be so grateful that someone objected to my motion. Very briefly, in relation to the suspension, why is this motion urgent? The D'Entrecasteaux National Park on the south coast of Western Australia is an extremely important area from both an ecological and an Aboriginal cultural perspective. I will elaborate on both of those issues if the Senate agrees to suspend standing orders and allow proper debate on this motion.

Suffice it to say that the entire area of the national park is listed on the register of the National Estate. The matter is urgent because last week the Western Australian government passed the inappropriately named WA government reserves bill, which excises 368 hectares of fragile woodland and heath land adjacent to Lake Jasper in the D'Entrecasteaux National Park.

The reason for this outrageous decision is to allow Cable Sands WA Pty Ltd, which is a wholly owned subsidiary of Japanese company Nissho Iwai, to undertake mineral sands mining. It sounds like a great deal, does it not? We allow a foreign owned company to come and export both the mineral sands and the profit overseas and at the same time give them the green light to trash our precious natural heritage. I thought this only happened in developing countries under the guiding hand of the World Bank, but perhaps I am naive.

It is my understanding that, whilst this bill has passed both houses of the Western Australian parliament, the bill has not yet received royal assent. That is why it is an urgent matter to debate it. The bill is, however, due to go to the Western Australian Governor in the very near future. Consequently, I feel that this creates an opportunity for the federal government, with the support of the Senate, to intervene and urgently request the Western Australian government not to proceed with the formality of obtaining royal assent for this bill.

It is important to debate this motion today in order to send a strong signal to the Western Australian government that there is strong opposition in the Senate to the idea of allowing mining in D'Entrecasteaux National Park or, for that matter, in any national park. There are options for the federal government to intervene and they should be taken now. I therefore trust that the Senate will support this motion to suspend standing orders and debate this crucial issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition will be supporting this motion. I welcome the opportunity, which I was not expecting to get, to speak on this proposal of the government of Western Australia to excise a portion of this most beautiful national park in south‐west Western Australia for sandmining.
—Have you been there?

—Yes, I have. For the information of senators who may be unfamiliar with this area, d'Entrecasteaux National Park is in the far south‐west of Western Australia. It is an area which is famous for its outstanding natural beauty. It attracts a very large number of eco‐tourists. Much of this park is on the register of the—
—Madam Acting Deputy President, I take a point of order. The numbers are here for the suspension. We would concede the suspension. Can we get on with the debate?

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Margetts) agreed to:
That general business notice of motion No. 207 may be moved immediately and have precedence over all other business today till determined.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee
SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate—
(a) notes:

PARA.TAB: (i) with outrage, the passage of legislation through the Western Australian Parlia ment to excise a large part of the D'Entrecasteaux National Park in the south west of Western Australia to facilitate the mining of mineral sands by Cable Sands, and

(ii) that there are currently 22 national parks in Western Australia that have exploration licences or temporary reserves applying to them, with many more applications being made for exploration licences in national parks; and

SPEECH.PARA: (b) calls on the Federal Government to put into practice the rhetoric that it has used in relation to the National Heritage Trust of Australia Bill 1996 and urgently intervene to prevent mining in the very important D'Entrecasteaux National Park, which is on the Register of the National Estate, or any other national park.

We are dealing here with an issue of great interest to many people in Western Australia, and I am sure many people from other parts of Australia as well. The reason this is of interest is that the area is of such great significance as an area that is very dear to many people's hearts. The issue has a historical context. It has been debated for some years, including with the previous Labor government in Western Australia. In 1990 the Western Australian Labor government released a policy on mining in national parks, ironically called `Resolution of Conflict', which allowed exploration of D'Entrecasteaux National Park for three years from that date. There was an immediate community response with large rallies, petitions, letter writings and a sustained campaign of non-violent direct actions. These protests continued for several years and resulted in a number of arrests.

PARA.BREAK: This is not just removing some small part of a national park that is on the edge. There is social and spiritual significance for Aboriginal people in the area. The lake and its associated sites represent a visible link with the past. Lake Jasper, part of the park adjacent to the area which is being excised, contains a great deal of information about our pre-European past. The lake is tied to the land for which Aboriginal people feel a deep association through blood affiliations to the country and through custodial responsibility as a result of residents. The lake provides a dramatic and exciting illustration of Aborigi nal habitation of the area. It is important in its ability to provide a way to present Aboriginal culture to Australian and international visitors.

SPEECH.PARA: Because of the extent of the dispossession of the past, the tangible and dramatic evidence of Aboriginal occupation of the land that the lake provides lends it a spiritual significance as a symbol of continued and lengthy Aboriginal association with the country through the constant and dramatic changes that it undergoes. I would like to read a letter which was sent by the Manjimup Aboriginal Corporation to state Labor politicians in Western Australia. They say in summary:
. . . the Aboriginal traditional owners and custodians of the area:

Object to mining in the area as it has the potential to create a direct physical impact on the site itself. We feel that any physical impact to the lake would be an absolute disaster for our community, people and culture.
Object to mining in the vicinity of Lake Jasper because such an activity in such close proximity will take from its value and is an affront to the spirituality of the area.
Object to the excision of the national park as the piecemeal cutting up of this area further reduces the country that we can use for cultural and community activities.

Let there be no misunderstanding—there are huge implications here. The lake is unique; it was the first and only underwater prehistoric campsite to have been discovered in Australia. The sites and inundating landscape on the floor of Lake Jasper illustrate the dynamic and changeable nature of geomorphology over a relatively short time span. The lake has a substantial peat bed, which may provide the first comprehensive record of south-western vegetation history through the sampling and analysis of the peat. There are a number of other issues concerning Aboriginal significance, but that gives you the general flavour.

From the wetlands perspective, the area proposed for excision includes part of the catchment of Lake Jasper, the largest permanent freshwater lake in the south-west of Western Australia. For many people who have not seen a mineral sands mining site, this is hard to imagine because, unlike many other mining sites, it is extremely extensive. It is not in one little spot, it is not down in the ground, and it is not a hole in the ground. The physical nature of mineral sands mining means that the whole of the topsoil and everything with it is stripped—and is stripped over a large area. That means that anything growing on top obviously has to go. It means that any of those species which rely on that extensive area lose their habitat.

For some areas of mining you could say that there will be a rehabilitation process. But let me be quite clear: I know of no example in Western Australia where mineral sands mining sites have been able to be rehabilitated to a natural bush state. The technology and the research has still not enabled that to happen.

So what happens? You excise a large area of national park and you turn it into cow land. That is fine if you are a dairy farmer, but it does not in any way, shape or form rehabilitate that important area to its natural form, rehabilitate the plant life or provide a habitat for the animal life, and so on. So, if you lose that area to national park, you have lost it for all time. That means that you have lost that buffer zone. Certainly, it seems almost incomprehensible that you would do that so close to the outstanding wetlands and Lake Jasper.

It is interesting to hear a quote from the Leader of the Opposition in Western Australia, Mr McGinty, relating to the state government's proposal to mine in D'Entrecasteaux National Park. The government are doing it without knowing its environmental impact. They are rushing this through, and that is having a huge impact on the people who have been given glib assurances that mining will take place only with the highest levels of environmental assessment. Mr McGinty said:
If it were on the fringe of the park, without the possibility of an enormous environmental downside, we at the Labor Party would support it.
That goes along with the 1990 decision. However, he went on to say:

But you are talking about the environmental jewel in the crown of the park, concerns related to mine tailings contaminating Lake Jasper, the bottom of the lake being disturbed and the effect on native plants and animals.
Mr McGinty said that the government's approach to mining in D'Entrecasteaux was at odds with its urban planning policy, which included up-front environmental reviews of planning proposals.

It seems extraordinary in the light of this statement that this should be rushed through. We know that there are differing views within the Labor Party on mining and exploration in national parks. But I would like to think that even within the Labor Party there is a desire to make sure that those very important areas of Australia which have deep significance are protected.

Let us have a look at some of the issues relating to this area. As I mentioned, the excision includes part of the catchment of Lake Jasper. It is the largest permanent freshwater lake in the south-west of Western Australia. The quality of the lake will be threatened even by mining operations only 300 metres from its edge. Silt, pollution, chemical spills and changes to the water table are all potential hazards for both wildlife and vegetation.

The lake system is a biological reservoir for native freshwater fish, while the associated wetland habitat contains several rare plant and protected bird species. In return for mining in the existing national park, Cable Sands has offered to add to the park 1,000 hectares of degraded former farmland. The land would be classified only as C-class reserve, and Cable Sands would still retain the right of access to mining and related activities. So what will have been gained? This land swap would add nothing to the value of the national park. It is an insult to the Western Australia reserve system. In fact, all it is doing is providing a means to further degrade the amount of reserve for the future.

Lake Jasper is unique, being the only known underwater archaeological site in Australia. Sandmining activities which involve using large quantities of water will threaten the integrity of the site. The flora around Lake Jasper is at risk of infection by dieback. Mining and associated road building are known to spread dieback.

PARA.BREAK: D'Entrecasteaux ecological importance is recognised by the Australian Heritage Com mission, which has placed the park on the register of the National Estate for its high conservation values. This is the nub of the point: little value added processing is done in Australia and the royalties in general are only of the order of $12 million to $17 million. This is the raffle. This is what we are trading off—$12 million to $17 million in royalties. Allowing mining near Lake Jasper would set a precedent for mining D'Entrecasteaux and other national parks. Excising patches of this magnificent national park will degrade the very values for which it was set aside in the first place.

SPEECH.PARA: According to a senior scientist, rehabilitation of an area of such diversity with over 1,000 plant species identified in the national park so far will be an obvious impossibility. I happen to know that the mining company commissioned a biological survey. I happen to know that the timing for this biological survey was two weeks—two weeks. It is a disgrace! If you want to do a proper biological survey, one year or two years would be minimum for an area of such significance. You have to go in the various seasons. You have to pit trap or you have to collect species in different seasons. Two weeks is a total farce.

National parks are set aside for the enjoyment of the community and the conservation of our flora and fauna. Any mining activities are entirely inappropriate and will be met with strong community opposition in the metropolitan and south west communities. The people of Western Australia hold this area in trust not only for Western Australians and Australians but for the whole world.

I certainly do hope that for this tacky short-term deal there is deep thought. There have been examples in the past where a bad decision made in parliament has not gone through, that it is has not received royal assent. I certainly hope that that is the case in this particular instance. I know there is a lot more to say, and I hope there will be other people supporting this argument but that is the reality. It is an indefensible decision. It is an indefensible lack of process and it totally puts the lie to any statements that have been made by the Western Australia government in relation to their respect for environmental values, their respect for any other values except the profitability of an overseas investor.

As I mentioned in my call for this to be debated in the first place, there were powers that could have been used by the previous governments and there are powers that can be used by this current government. Whether or not you wanted them, the powers exist. That is why we are debating this in the Senate today.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not repeat what I have already said to the house. I conclude in noting that much of this beautiful park is on the register of the National Estate. What this proposal points to is that so far as the Western Australian government is concerned, a national park is only a national park as long as they don't require it for something else. That is what I find particularly objectionable about the proposal to excise an area close to the largest and certainly spectacularly beautiful freshwater lake in that region for sandmining.
—The proposal includes adding another 1,000 hectares to the park.

—It does not change the location of the mining, senator, with the greatest respect. That's a foolish interjection. As is the habit of the Court government, it has put aside all of the other intrinsic values of the area, whether tourism or environmental, to proceed with the excision of a portion of this park so that an overseas company can proceed with its application to mine for mineral sands. That is the bottom line of this.

SPEECH.PARA: This, after all, is the state government which laid down the blueprint for the Howard government in environmental fraud. In the lead-up to the 1993 state election, the Liberal shadow environment minister, Phillip Pendal, promised a new dawn for the environment and posed for photographs with members of the conservation movement. Following the election, Mr Pendal did not get a ministry and the Court government immediately considered drilling for oil in the fragile and pristine Ningaloo Marine Park as well as having gutted the state Environmental Protection Authority of its powers.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who wrote this stuff for you, Bob? Read it with a bit more passion. Someone else wrote this for you.

—Western Australian members would be forgiven for having a sense of deja vu about the Howard government's environmental performance. This proposal for mining, as I have just said, is to take place adjacent to Lake Jasper, which is the biggest freshwater lake in the south west.
—It is not a proposal for mining. You got it wrong again.

—I wonder if the continual interjections from across the road can cease, Madam Deputy President. In and around Lake Jasper there are declared rare flora and other flora, many mammals and significant species of birds. There are also examples of endemic fresh water fish that have disappeared from other parts of south western Australia and a number of invertebrates that are not found in any other places. The Aboriginal heritage value of the site is also well recognised with some underwater archaeological work being undertaken.

SPEECH.PARA: In the Western Australian parliament last week the state opposition proposed a motion to halt the excision pending a report from the CSIRO on the hydrology of the Lake Jasper area and the likely impact of mining on this lake; an environmental assessment of the proposal to mine in this area at the level of an ERMP; the requirement that ministerial conditions arising from the ERMP include revegetation to acceptable native vegetation standards so that the locations may be incorporated in the park at a later date; and a statement by the proponent outlining its commitments to secondary processing of the mineral sands mined.

Clearly, under any circumstances, these were reasonable requests of any government with an interest in applying appropriate environmental standards. Significantly, the former Liberal shadow environment minister, Mr Pendal, now turned Independent, supported the first clause and expressed his concern about the importance of Lake Jasper. The real issue is what happens now that the Court government's bill to excise a portion of the park for sandmining has passed through the malapportioned Western Australian Legislative Council.

There is no public confidence in the ability of the state Environmental Protection Authority following the changes that were made to it by Premier Court and a string of appalling decisions. For example, in concert with the state environment minister, Mr Foss, the EPA made the extraordinary decision that there was no need to have a formal environmental assessment of a major road tunnel which is to cut from near the Swan River to the Mitchell freeway on the northern side of Perth—another grand plan of the Court government which is proceeding despite the objections of the local community.

It is beholden on the Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Parer, to advise the Western Australian government that he will not grant a mineral sands export licence until the most rigorous environmental assessments have been undertaken. In the interests of the environmental integrity of the area, he should resist his natural inclination to approve mining proposals before they even hit his desk.

The Western Australian community is looking to the Howard government to display higher environmental standards than those of the Court government. So far, the Howard government has cut the environment budget by 13 per cent, despite John Howard's explicit election promise not to cut it at all; increased the woodchip export licence ceiling and will now allow the clearing of native forests on private land for woodchipping; approved a 1,500 bed Oyster Point resort development adjacent to a world heritage area; failed to advance Australia's response to the greenhouse threat; supported the development of new uranium mines in Australia; and tried to abandon the Commonwealth's controls over the export of certain minerals, including mineral sands. By withholding the mineral sands export licence, the Howard government now has an opportunity in respect of this issue to lift its game. The community is waiting and watching.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I support this move by Senator Margetts to protect one of the most delightful places in Western Australia, and indeed Australia. It is as important to the national parliament as it is to the state parliament because the D'Entrecasteaux National Park is of national significance and is listed on the Australian Heritage Commission's list of the national heritage.

SPEECH.PARA: I simply want to read into the Hansard a letter from an archaeologist at the Western Australian Museum to underscore the archaeological significance of Lake Jasper, which is targeted by the sandmining imperative which has led to the Western Australian parliament rescinding part of the D'Entrecasteaux National Park. This comes from Mr Charlie Dortch, who is speaking as an individual but works at the Western Australian Museum. He says:

Lake Jasper is Western Australia's largest and most significant fresh-water lake, and is also the locale of an ancient and unique underwater cultural landscape. My aim here is to show how that over a few short years the lake's once pristine condition has deteriorated, and to confirm its great age and unique cultural heritage.

He first went to Lake Jasper in 1988 when carrying out an archaeological survey. He found tree stumps and stone tool scatters in the lake's inshore zone that were partly exposed at low water levels. He says:

At the time the lake and its environs unquestionably were in pristine natural condition. Over the next seven years, I directed WA Museum diving teams investigating the 4 km² lake floor. In six diving seasons, our team showed that the lake floor is a submerged ancient landscape that had been occupied by human beings, as shown by the presence of stone tools and tree stumps in growth position to depths of ten m. In 1994, we learned that Lake Jasper's deepest and still not fully sounded part, which is at a depth greater than 17 m, was a much smaller lake that long pre-dated the filling of the existing lake.

In other words, in ancient times there had been a smaller lake. The Aboriginal community of this region occupied an area which is now largely submerged. That was their life over thousands of years. He goes on to outline the serial incursions on the lake, not least the extension of motorised aquatic sports.

He details how this lake does not have an outflow. It does not have a creek or river flowing from it. It simply is a natural sump and the water drainage from it is into the subterranean component of the lake. Rubbish going into the lake—the detergents, oil and so on from those water sports—has no way of escaping. It sinks to salify the lake and degrade the archaeological landscape as well as the natural values of the lake.

On top of that, he confronts the prospect of this proposal for sandmining in the lake's near vicinity and the unknown outcome of that. I think most Australian citizens would be outraged too, if they were able to take part in this debate, at the potential impact of a venal approach to a vital component of Australia's national park system. What they are after is to make a few dollars and the state will get some paltry sum, like $12 million or $17 million in royalties overall, to degrade one of the most beautiful little places in Western Australia.

I support totally Senator Margetts' imploring the Senate, as a national conscience, to act on behalf of those people fighting to protect this area. The Western Australian state parliament, no doubt lobbied by the mineral sands industry, has said, `We will put the natural values, the archaeological values, second to the quick dollar for this overseas sandmining interest.' It is the wrong way to go. This parliament in Canberra has the power to alter things, to protect an environment, when a maverick state government fails to do so.

PARA.BREAK: Senator Margetts has pointed to the use of the corporations power. Let me just say to the Senate that, if it is good enough to use the corporations power—as recent governments have done—to say to the Victorian government, `We'll move on you. If you don't legislate to allow banks to charge interest on credit cards, we'll use the corporations power,' then it is surely good enough to use that same power to protect something of inestimable and timeless value to this nation and to all future generations. Let's get our priorities right here. That corporations power is avail able. We have national responsibilities to the environment. Here we have the opportunity to make a stand in the Senate in defence of that environment.

SPEECH.PARA: I totally support this motion. I hope the Senate will support it. I hope that, as an outcome of that support, the Howard government will do the right thing, by using the powers it has available to it to protect this vital part of the national estate. The consequence of not acting is a continued deterioration of Australia's environment. The Howard government will take responsibility for that. When it comes to the subject of excision of national parks, we come to a pretty low ebb in terms of our national responsibilities to the environment.

If we cannot make a stand in this national parliament on protecting national parks—which, by the way, are under threat in New South Wales at the moment from the woodchip industry, which wants to incise national parks so it can move in and raze some of the last great stands of forests in New South Wales—then nothing is sacrosanct. Nothing is inviolable. I again say: how come we can use inherent powers of the constitution to guarantee banks can charge interest on credit cards but we have failed so far to use those same powers to come to the protection of this great country's natural environment? I support the motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think there are a number of points that need to be responded to. I do not intend delaying the Senate. I think if Senator Margetts wanted to have this debated—and I respect that she indicated that it would be declared formal—the debate could have taken place during general business. It would have gone through very quickly just on the voices we heard this morning, except that Senator Harradine quite properly suggested that he wanted to hear a debate before he cast his vote. That is all well and good, but this debate could have taken place during general business. It certainly was not listed for general business, and I do not know whether Senator Margetts sought to make this a general business debate.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a very vital issue, but where Senator Brown and, I think, even Senator Bob Collins made a mistake is that there is the corporations power. Senator Brown, in particular, is saying that we should use that power. To make an analogy, that power does exist. It is probably the equivalent to a Ford GT‐HO five‐litre V8 engine. But when you have a power the other thing—

TALK.START.PARA: —I never saw it like that.

—It is a new idea, Senator Collins. But what you need between that power plant of the Ford GT-HO five-litre V8 engine is an axle. Of course, one of the things we do not have is an axle, which you might say is analogous to some legislation. There is no legislation under the corporations power that would enable this parliament to say to the Western Australian parliament, `We don't like the way you are drawing the boundaries of your national parks.' I well agree with Senator Brown and many other senators around this place about the unique values of Lake Jasper, the inherent beauty of the D'Entrecasteaux National Park. It is a fantastic and most beautiful part of the state that I call home.
—What about the export power?

—I will get to that, Senator Margetts. The Manager of Government Business in the Senate (Senator Kemp) is already winding me up, just when I am getting wound up myself. I said by leave in my intervention in the debate, when we said that we would actually support this motion being made formal, that there is that export power.
—You could require an environmental assessment; you are not doing it properly.

—Senator Margetts, we will, when we have the power to do that, require that assessment. But at this stage—and I will talk very slowly and use very simple words—the Commonwealth has absolutely no power to get involved. Firstly, there is no proposal for mining. There is a proposal that has gone through the Western Australian parliament to make an excision from a national park. At some stage, there will—
—Fair go!

—Senator Collins has been a minister for so long that he knows all about it. Senator Collins does not wait until something gets on his desk. He does not abide by the law of the nation. He will presume that one day in the future he will have a piece of paper coming to his desk. He is probably going to sit at his ministerial desk and practise taking action when some triggering activity comes to his desk.
—We know the name of the company. What are you on about?

—Of course we do, Senator Collins. We know the name of the company, but we actually have to go through a legal process. If we want to propose—and maybe the Labor Party proposes this with the support of the Greens—that we abolish all of the state parliaments and that we abolish all of the legal processes, I am sure people here would advocate that very genuinely. I am sure Senator Brown and Senator Margetts would like to get rid of state environmental protection agencies and get rid of all of the processes that are done at the state level and actually set up a massive bureaucracy here in Canberra to do all of that work.

SPEECH.PARA: The reality is that we have set pieces of legislation that we do have to abide by at the moment. They may be wobbly, they may be shaky and they may not work very well, but the reality is that the WA state parliament, whether we like it or not, has the legislative and constitutional control over the national park. They have passed a piece of legislation that it seems a majority of senators may not like.

They will then, I presume, receive a formal proposal to mine within that area. There will then be an environmental impact assessment process triggered at the state level. There may then be a proposal that comes before the federal government in relation to the export of those sands. We will then trigger the due processes under the Australian Heritage Commission provisions, which Senator Collins has already outlined. The minister may then have some power to act. But what Senator Collins is proposing—and I do not even think he genuinely proposes this—is that somehow we sort of overturn that whole process and find some way for the minister to act in the meantime. The minister does not have that power to act. There is no head of power and, where there is a head of power, there is no legislation.

The Commonwealth government puts those views. We suggest that the proposal, as set out in the motion, not only lacks any constitutional validity, but also it just overturns the whole process. If you want to propose, just to sum up, that here in Canberra we establish a system whereby we will be the judge and jury of every single proposal for economic development and environmental protection in Australia, then that is the serious proposal that is incorporated in this motion.

I am sure some people genuinely hold those views; they genuinely believe that perhaps the environment in Australia could be a bit better protected with a mega‐bureaucracy and mega‐power here in Canberra with the ultimate control of this parliament whereby none of us trust what any of the states do ever again. I suggest that that is not the practical approach.

This government's approach is to cooperate with the states, to work with the states. The federal government is already in close consultation with the various authorities in Western Australia, and the Australian Heritage Commission has worked, as Senator Margetts knows, through the assessment processes in 1991 and 1992 in this area. We have listed these areas.

The Commonwealth is taking its responsibilities seriously. We do care about what happens in those national parks, but we can only act where we have the power and the legislation to do so. I think you assume that, because we have a corporations power or an external affairs power, we can just use that power by edict. Unfortunately, what you do need is a bit of legislation—as I call it, the axle connecting the V8 power to the outcome, which is some action on the ground. That power does not exist.

BREAK.PARA: The export power does exist. I have said that this government may be required, at some stage in the next few months or next few years, to use that power. And, if that is the case, I think that the Minister for the Environment, where he is required to act, will act in the best interests of Australia and Australia's environment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murray, Sen Andrew

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion. What we find here is really a debate about a lack of political will. What we are trying to do is encourage the government to exercise political will in this matter. We maintain that there is a conflict of interest here between tourism and mining.

SPEECH.PARA: There have to be areas of Australia kept sacrosanct from miners and loggers. That is not an anti-commercial or anti-employment doctrine because tourism is the great unsung beneficiary of the protection of these areas. That conflict of interest really needs to be brought to the fore.

The Australian Democrats are extremely concerned about this matter of attacking national parks both in WA and nationally. We are deeply concerned by the recent movements of the Western Australian government to pave the way for sandmining activity within the park and adjacent to Lake Jasper.

We are deeply concerned by what appears to be a nationwide push by conservative governments in the main to open up our small, and it is small, national park and nature reserve estate to all types of development—D'Entrecasteaux National Park in general and the Lake Jasper area of the national park in particular. The senators who have spoken have already identified it as of enormous value and importance.

Recent research shows that the Lake Jasper wetland ecosystem, which would be irreversibly degraded and destroyed by any sandmining activity in the vicinity—and Senator Margetts has made the correct point that this kind of mining is exceptionally aggressive—is one of the most important freshwater wetland ecosystems remaining in the south‐west of WA with large numbers of water bird species, endemic freshwater fish species, frog species, aquatic invertebrates and many other species and plant communities of great importance.

The proposed mine will undoubtedly cause irreversible disruption to the hydrological system which underpins the Lake Jasper wetland ecosystem. As you know, our water systems overall throughout Western Australia are under enormous attack from salt problems, and this is just another problem to add to the hydrological problems we have. Any mineral sandmining in the Lake Jasper wetland system would result in the contamination of the water system by sediments and by radioactive products—and I emphasise that. We have had a problem in Western Australia with the radioactivity of mineral sands, both of which would cause irreversible damage to the wetland ecosystem. The area also has very high Aboriginal heritage values which have been increasingly well documented.

In economic terms, the park and Lake Jasper already have established economic values for tourism. Tourism is the industry of the present and the future. We have large and growing numbers of nature based tourists visiting the area. This then has major flow-on effects for the local centres such as Walpole, Northcliffe, Pemberton and Augusta. The impacts of any mine in this area would cause major disruptions and impacts on local communities. It would have a negative effect on the burgeoning nature based tourism industry. It would cause a massive further impact in terms of transport by road of the mineral sands.

The lower south-west is already reeling—and I mean that word `reeling'—under the effects of increasing road transport related to sandmining. Any new mine in this area would be extremely disturbing for local communities. Small business and small tourist businesses in particular have complained to us about the wrong emphasis of the state on mining and logging. The transport by heavy trucks over long distance and mineral sands will spread the impacts right through the lower south-west and up to Bunbury. This will all have consequences for the flourishing tourism industry.

Recent sandmine approvals at Jangardup and Benup, both in close proximity to the D'Entrecasteaux National Park, have provoked great fear and anger amongst local communities because the push for mineral sandmining across the south coast is so clearly at odds with the lifestyle and the best long-term economic and social interests of the south coast community.

Last week's decision by the Western Australian government to fast‐track the passage of a national park excision bill through parliament was, and is, reprehensible. It is our view that the population of Western Australia would be strongly opposed to this, if asked. By its passage of this bill, the WA government is demonstrating its disregard for the environment, for national parks, for areas listed on the Register of the National Estate and for the principles of ecologically sustainable development.

By passing this bill, the WA government is saying that it is prepared to subject the community of WA to all the anxiety and trauma and needless expenditure of time and energy that will be required to ensure that mineral sandmining does not proceed in this most remarkable of natural areas. We heard yesterday from Senator Eggleston what a wonderful outpouring of wealth we have in Western Australia. There is plenty enough mining going on; we do not need to wrack into yet another natural area.

It is important that this parliament discuss this matter at this time so that the federal government can act quickly to head off what will otherwise be a protracted conflict between the WA community and the mining industry, which will, in turn, bring discredit upon the mining industry and on the mining company involved—Nissho Iwai Corporation of Japan. I emphasise, incidentally, the word `corporation'. It is urgent that this government take action now and exhibit some political will. As the guns legislation proved, if their heart is in the right place, they have the ability to act.

This government must immediately make it clear to the WA government and Nissho Iwai that it is serious about its express commitment to the environment. It must, therefore, inform the WA government immediately that it is prepared to intervene in any lawful way possible to prevent any possibility that this crazy, incredibly destructive mining proposal will proceed. The Australian Democrats ask you, Senator Campbell, on behalf of the government, to please exercise some political will in this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank those members of the Senate who have spoken and clarified the matter for me somewhat. The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment, Senator Campbell, raised the question as to the powers which the Commonwealth government has in respect of intervening. There are a number of powers, including the corporations power. As the parliamentary secretary has indicated, there is no legislation which would enable the Commonwealth to call on that power at the present moment.

SPEECH.PARA: I am just a bit worried about the extension of the corporations power to some other areas, including, for example, industrial relations. We have suffered considerably as a result of governments utilising that power for the purposes of interfering, as it were, in industrial relations. There are other powers, as has been suggested here, including the export power, where there are laid down procedures which can be and have been exercised by the Commonwealth in respect of the preservation or the protection of the environment. What has been indicated here is quite correct—any lawful means—but as Senator Campbell has said, they are limited at this stage.

Having heard what has been said, I just want to indicate that I am not prepared, at this stage, to vote for the proposal whilst it contains subparagraph (ii) and the words at the end of (b) say `or any other national park'. Nothing has been said in this debate which clarifies that for me. I understand that there are small mines in some national parks in various states to which there is no environmental objection. I may be wrong there. I am wondering whether the Senate would accept the following amendment. I move:
Paragraph (a)(ii), omit the paragraph.
Paragraph (b), omit ", or any other national park".

That would focus on the issue in hand, that is, the legislation of Western Australia which seeks to excise a large part of the D'Entrecasteaux National Park in the south‐west of Western Australia and facilitate the mining of mineral sands by Cable Sands, and paragraph (b) would stand intact with the exception of those four or five words at the end. I hope that is acceptable to the Senate. I feel it is probably in the interests of Senator Margetts and that it would focus on this particular issue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —To close the debate, I thank the speakers for their contributions today. I think it is true that any government which has the political will would be able to put forward legislation that would provide the axle, as Senator Campbell calls it. Let us look at a model. Perhaps we can. There are examples where there was, supposedly, a head of power, but where there is a will there is a way. The uniform national gun laws were one example where, whether or not there was a national power, there was a national result. In the case of such things, there is the ability to do this.

SPEECH.PARA: The principle of the Commonwealth‐state regional agreements with regard to the environment is that the Commonwealth retains the role, if not the obligation, to intervene if proper standards are not met. How anyone in their wildest dreams could indicate that proper standards are being met by this proposal is beyond me. What we have here is a national park for sale.
