Any statements that are made about why anybody should want to look after other ecological values in Australia, when we have X amount of national park, obviously fall into tiny shattered pieces when you talk about the impact of a valued part of a valued park in Western Australia. People would have to be totally ignorant of the values, other than somebody's dollar values, if they could not see that this decision is short‐sighted and damaging for our future generations.

In relation to Senator Harradine's proposal, part (ii) was stated as a statement of fact—that there are currently 22 national parks in Western Australia that have exploration licences or temporary reserves applying to them, with many more applications being made for exploration licences in national parks. In relation to this debate, that statement of fact remains a statement of fact, but I can live with it being removed. Obviously, from the Greens' point of view, the D'Entrecasteaux National Park, like any national park, should not be an area where mining takes place. I understand that people have different views. If the majority of the Senate supports the motion by removing `or any other national park', we will revisit that further argument on another day. Once again, I commend the motion in total to the Senate and I hope there will be majority support for this very important motion.
Amendments agreed to.
Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Tambling) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling, Sen Grant

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard .
Leave granted.
The various provisions of the bill should be seen in the context of the Government's commitment to quality, diversity and innovative change in the higher education sector.

A number of amendments provide supplementation for price movements. This supplementation covers items such as superannuation expenses, teaching hospitals, special capital projects, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander support funds, 1996 expenditure for grants to open learning organisations and operating grants in respect of the years 1996, 1997 and 1998.

The Government is committed to providing flexible funding for research projects in higher education institutions. To achieve this objective, amendments are to be made to subsection 23(1) of the act to broaden the range of research proposals that the Minister may approve including research training.

Amendments to section 20A of the act will create a facility for providing advances of operating grants for a wide range of purposes. This will increase the overall flexibility of funding arrangements for higher education institutions. Subject to parliamentary scrutiny, the Minister will be able to issue guidelines that will establish the overall amount to be paid as advances as well as the type of activities that will be funded.

The bill provides for the streamlining of administrative procedures of the Open Learning Deferred Payment Scheme. The concept of "semester" is replaced with "study periods" to reflect the structure of the open learning scheme.

The bill also makes amendments to subsection 106AA and subsection 106AB. Currently an open learning agency will process an application for the deferred payment scheme without the inclusion of the client's tax file number. The amendments will mean that clients will be ineligible for the deferred payment scheme if they do not provide a tax file number.

An amendment to section 106E broadens the current obligation of the agency to provide information to the minister to include statistical and other information relating to clients undertaking units of study. The amendment will result in the agency being subject to the same obligation as higher education institutions. These amendments will enhance the Commonwealth's ability to monitor the scheme's effectiveness and ensure proper accountability.

The bill will provide funding to trial the development of an Indigenous University Network. The framework will include improved student support services, up to four Indigenous teaching and research centres, an Indigenous electronic network, and the development of open learning style educational packages for Indigenous people in correctional institutions and other places with restricted access to higher education.
Other amendments to the act will:
. Remove the requirement for taxpayers to include the amount of HECS debt when lodging their income tax return. The Australian Taxation Office already has access to this information;
. Update the definition of "qualified accountant" in section 3; and
. Update table A and B of section 4 of the act to accurately reflect current higher education institutions recognised for the purposes of the act.
This bill reflects the Government's commitment to a relevant, high quality education system which is striving for excellence and innovation in teaching and research.
I commend the bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Carr) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: BILLS RETURNED FROM THE HOUSE OF REPRESENTATIVES

PROCTEXT.PARA: Message received from the House of Representatives intimating that it had agreed to the amendments made by the Senate to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Amendment Bill 1996 [No.2].
AIRPORTS BILL 1996
Consideration resumed from 11 September.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that the bill, as amended, be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling, Sen Grant

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —Further to the discussion that ensued on this bill yesterday, I advise that the government proposes to bring forward further amendments which have been circulated in the chamber. They are supplementary amendments that I propose to move on behalf of the government. They are numbered 1, 2, 3 and 4 and they relate to clauses 4, 38, 47A and 47B of the bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The government has agreed to a special request from the Premier of Western Australia to extend the cross‐ownership restrictions to the Airports Bill to separate control of Perth airport from Sydney airport on the same basis as Melbourne and Brisbane airports. In supporting statements made in conjunction with the introduction of the legislation, such as in the second reading speech, the government indicated its continuing support for individual ownership of airports and encouraging diversity in lease ownership and management of federal airports, while having regard to the response from potential investors and other leasing objectives.

The government has recently reinstated cross‐ownership provisions which separate Sydney, with Sydney West, from Melbourne and Brisbane airports in the form included in the Airports Bill 1995, and did so in amendments moved at the beginning of these committee hearings.

The amendments which the government made by reinstatement of the cross‐ownership restrictions ensure the separate ownership and control of the airport lessee and any airport management companies of Sydney and Sydney West from Melbourne airport, and Sydney and Sydney West from Brisbane airport. The cross‐ownership limitations apply to both the airport lessee company and the airport management company. Separation is achieved by both a 15 per cent limit and a practical control test. The government has also already advised that it will make it a condition of the lease of the first stage airports that bidders must bid for Melbourne, Brisbane and Perth airports individually.

The government has now given further consideration to the position and the treatment of Perth airport, which, along with Melbourne and Brisbane, is one of the major airports to be leased in the first phase of airport sales. Given that bids for Melbourne and Brisbane will be sought separately from each other and from Perth, it seems only logical that cross‐ownership provisions reflect this as well; thus all of the first phase airports will be kept separate from Sydney.

It now seems clear that there will be a stronger field of bidders for the phase 1 airports than originally expected. There has been an increase in the number of international operators and consortia interested in acquiring airport leases since cross-ownership rules were first proposed by the previous Labor government. There is also a greater appreciation of the airports being excellent investments for institutions and funds managers.

As a result, and in addition to support for the government's move to achieve diversity of ownership of phase 1 airports, market conditions are now quite strong; thus we see no commercial reason against the extension of the cross-ownership restrictions to include Perth. However, I should say that this should not be seen as a precedent for other future airport lease sales. Therefore, I seek leave to move the amendments as tabled which ensure the separation of control of Sydney with Sydney West from Perth airport.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

BREAK.PARA: (1) Clause 4, paragraph (c) of the seventh dot‐point, omit "and Sydney/Brisbane", substitute ", Sydney/Brisbane and Sydney/Perth".
(2) Clause 38, paragraph (c) of the first dot‐point, omit "and Sydney/Brisbane", substitute ", Sydney/Brisbane and Sydney/Perth".
(3) Clause 47A, after the second dot‐point, insert:

PARA.TAB: Airport‐operator companies for Sydney and Perth form a pair .

BREAK.PARA: (4) Clause 47B, at the end of the table add:

ROW.ENTRY: the airport-lessee company for Perth Airport
the airport-lessee company for Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport
an airport-management company for Perth Airport
the airport-lessee company for Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport
the airport-lessee company for Perth Airport
an airport-management company for Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport
an airport-management company for Perth Airport
an airport-management company for Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport
the airport-lessee company for Perth Airport
the airport-lessee company for Sydney West Airport
an airport-management company for Perth Airport
the airport-lessee company for Sydney West Airport
the airport-lessee company for Perth Airport
an airport-management company for Sydney West Airport
an airport-management company for Perth Airport
an airport-management company for Sydney West Airport

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens (WA) and the Australian Greens will be supporting this amendment. From the point of view of Western Australia's having an entire airline route, whether it is Perth and Brisbane or Perth and Melbourne, with both airports, under the control of one lessee was not a very exciting prospect. As I have said before, I fail to see that a large private monopoly is going to be more efficient than a government monopoly. Therefore, I am happy to support this amendment, but of course I still do not like the bill as a whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —The one thing that I would like some further clarification on from Senator Tambling—and I indicate to him that we will be supporting the amendment—is that it seems very much a case of government on the run. That certainly would be the perception. This is a major issue. These are major assets. I do not think all this chopping and changing indicates that the government has any particular clarity of view.

SPEECH.PARA: So I would like to hear a little more from Senator Tambling about why Perth suddenly screamed in here this morning. I make the obvious point: why not Adelaide? Why not Townsville? Why did we not have Perth yesterday, but suddenly we have Perth today? What is it that makes it now rational or reasonable to suddenly have Perth on the list and not, for example, the two airports that I have just mentioned?

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously, the Democrats would want to add in all of the airports we could think of in terms of preventing cross-ownership. So we have the same question as Senator Collins: why Perth? We are obviously of a mind to support it, but we want more reasons. I must point out that the government were fairly cranky with the Greens for delaying the passage of the bill with countless amendments and now, all of a sudden, they have come in and wanted an amendment of their own.
—It's not a small amendment either.
—That is right. I think Senator Tambling may need to apologise for criticising other people for their amendments as well as giving us the explanation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling, Sen Grant

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the questions that have been asked by both Senator Bob Collins and Senator Woodley with regard to these particular amendments. The issue has been under consideration by the government since the matter was raised by state governments in their submissions to the Senate committee in the consideration of this bill. There were important arguments advanced at that time as part of the committee considerations. They were certainly well addressed.

SPEECH.PARA: Whilst it is certainly acknowledged that they are major issues and major assets, it is important to consider the views of the respective state governments. As I said in my initial comments, it was important to recognise that the Premier of Western Australia had made a special request to reinforce the views that had been previously put by the Western Australian government, and those views have been taken into account.

In considering the matter regarding the various airports that Senator Collins raised, it is important to note that we have reviewed the issues relating to capital cities. In this regard, both the Premier of Tasmania and the Acting Premier of South Australia have also been consulted. The legislation that has eventuated here today meets the requirements of all three state governments that have been consulted. It also needs to be borne in mind that we are dealing with the phase 1 airports in this regard, which are those that are in the first phase and are essentially the capital city airports.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane, Sen Winston

TALK.START.PARA: —I will just make a very brief comment in relation to the questions that have been raised here in view of the fact that I was chair of the committee that dealt with this particular matter. It is fair to say that at those hearings the issue was raised in the Western Australian government submission in terms of cross-ownership for Perth. I do not believe it was raised by the other state governments, although I would actually have to check the record absolutely precisely with regard to that particular point. I do not believe it was.

SPEECH.PARA: The position the committee took as far as that was concerned was in relation to the answers that were given to us by the representatives of the government at that particular time. They were concerned that, if cross-ownership were applied to Perth, there would not be, or potentially would not be, sufficient competition in terms of the situation that exists.

Since then, it has evolved from the Perth situation that three major local Perth conglomerates have come forward who wish to compete for Perth, its particular position and what exists. As a result, representations were made, as has already been said, by the Minister for Transport in WA, by the Premier, by some of my federal colleagues, obviously, and by me with regard to the new information that has come forward. As a result of that particular information, I am satisfied, as are my other colleagues, that there is now sufficient competition available in terms of those three particular conglomerates.

We expressed a number of other concerns, but I will not go into them at this particular time because it will only prolong this particular debate. The key point is that those three local conglomerates are very reputable companies, which operate in Western Australia. They are Western Australian companies. In particular they will provide that necessary competition that is required as far as Perth is concerned. I just wish to reinforce that particular point: there was no request made by either the South Australian government or the Tasmanian government with regard to this particular matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just in respect of that helpful interjection in the debate by Senator Crane, which I do not question for a minute, correct me if I wrong, Senator Tambling, but it is my recollection that the Premier of Victoria was opposed to common ownership of Melbourne and Brisbane. If that is so and if I am right about that, in terms of the Victorian position being that they wanted restrictions placed in respect of the Melbourne‐Brisbane axis—and apparently did not get them—what distinguishes that situation from the one you have just provided for suddenly this morning?

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised that the arrangements that were already put in place in the bill in earlier amendments, which Senator Collins will recall reinstated the previous provisions of the Labor administration and the Labor Party's 1995 bill that impacted on Victoria, were certainly consistent. They have been discussed with the Premier of Victoria, who I understand is happy with the arrangements.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question is that the bill, as amended, be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night when we reported progress we had a response from the parliamentary secretary to a question that I had raised relating to the payment of local government charges and state government taxes. The parliamentary secretary gave a statement in response to that question of mine and also a response to the interventions by Senator Bob Collins and Senator Calvert as follows:

SPEECH.PARA: I am advised that under the Federal Airports Corporation Act 1986 the corporation is subject to Commonwealth income and wholesale sales tax and state payroll tax. The FAC also makes ex gratia payments to local authorities in lieu of rates in respect of leasehold improvements on airports for which it rebills its clients. The FAC does not pay rates in respect of general airport land. While the Airports Bill does not address the issue, the operators of leased airports will be required to make payments in lieu of rates, as the FAC currently does. These obligations will be imposed by provisions in the airport leases.

More generally, the application of state laws imposing taxation to the airports when operated under long-term leases from the Commonwealth is unclear. The application of state taxation laws to the airports will be addressed shortly by the High Court.

That raises a number of questions. Firstly, are we to assume from that that in the leases there will be a requirement that the operators will be obliged to pay local government charges, including rates? Secondly, what about state laws which are not taxation laws—for example, state laws relating to what businesses could be operated and the times in which those businesses could be operated and, for example, licensing arrangements? Will the operators be required to observe all of those state laws? Will this be required of them in the leases?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling, Sen Grant

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —With regard to the first series of questions addressed by Senator Harradine and the matter of rates and ex gratia payments, et cetera, that are currently paid for by the FAC and that it would be the intention of the government to have a similar regime with regard to in the future, I again draw Senator Harradine's attention to the issues that both he and Senator Calvert addressed to the Senate legislation committee on Tuesday, 6 August, when these matters were addressed in considerable detail.

SPEECH.PARA: On that particular occasion there was the reference that I referred to last night of the federal government positions that had been previously enunciated by the former minister—the then Senator Gareth Evans—with regard to the standing position of the Commonwealth on the particular position, and I reinforced and restated that particular position. Similarly, the officers of the Department of Transport who appeared at the Senate committee on Tuesday, 6 August gave detailed answers referring to the leases. In particular, I refer to the response by Mr White on page 301 of the Hansard of the Senate committee. In addressing this matter, Mr White said that, for legal reasons, it cannot go in the legislation, but that provisions can be put into the individual airport leases for each of the airports which would require airport operators to meet the government's requirements in that area.

BREAK.PARA: With regard to the question that Senator Harradine addressed with regard to the issue of licensing and the operating hours, et cetera for commercial operations, this is a matter that would be determined by close collaboration and consultation between the Commonwealth authorities and the state authorities.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is obvious that the minister wants us to buy a pig in a poke. I am not all that happy with the situation at all. It is obvious that I am not going to get anywhere here. I will just go on to another area. If honourable senators read the transcript and read the Hansard , we have been told absolutely nothing. If I have ever heard a Sir Humphrey performance, I have just heard it: yes, we will ensure that the leases will contain provisions which will ensure that they will meet the government's requirements—whatever they might be. I can only ask: what are the government's requirements?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling, Sen Grant

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —Part 11 of the Airports Bill 1996 allows the Commonwealth to introduce regulations to deal with a range of other on‐airport activities: for example, commercial trading, vehicle movements, gambling and smoking. If no regulations are introduced, state laws would apply in these areas.

SPEECH.PARA: During the consultations that I have referred to between Commonwealth and state, the Department of Transport will be seeking to establish the state views on all the matters covered under part 11 of the Airports Bill. That includes, of course, the control of liquor, commercial trading, vehicle movements, gambling and smoking. These are matters that will be done, as I said, in collaboration with and consultation between the Commonwealth and the state agencies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine, of course, is absolutely correct in that in the space of the last 15 or 20 minutes, Senator Tambling, on behalf of the government, has told us nothing. The question of local laws in respect of shopping and gambling and all these sorts of things is not a new issue; this issue came up again and again. Of course, it became a very prominent issue in respect of the Perth airport under the current arrangements with the FAC. That simply demonstrates the sensitivity of the issue and the importance of it in terms of all these changed arrangements. What I would like to know is: what is the government's general approach and general attitude toward this important question? Will the government have a predisposition to want to have the airports run by local state and territory laws or will the government have a predisposition to have control itself under Commonwealth regulations or laws? What is the predisposition of the government? What is the general approach it is going to take on these issues?

SPEECH.PARA: One example of why this might be important is the case of the Melbourne airport. What if, for example, Hudson Conway became the successful operator—as they certainly indicate they wish to be—of Tullamarine? Would the government then be minded to allow a casino and gaming on the premises? The Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Tambling) would be well aware that this certainly is not the first time this issue has been raised: such proposals have been raised before in terms of gaming machines in airport terminals.

It is an important question and we know nothing about it. In terms of what the government's requirements might be, it is a blank page. What will the predisposition of the government be on this issue? Will it, in general, be looking to have state and local laws running what will effectively be completely private operations no longer with a real Commonwealth involvement in terms of management. Senator Margetts pursued this matter in debate yesterday. It was finally clarified that the Commonwealth will have no further management role; you would not expect it to have one in these airports once they are privatised. What is the general position of the government in its approach on this? What will the situation be, for example, with Melbourne airport and gambling?

Senator TAMBLING (Northern Territory—Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development) (11.36 a.m.)—The issues in this particular area are being regurgitated again by Senator Collins. It is important to recognise that in the process of establishing what will flow from this legislation it was very important that these discussions did not pre‐empt the passage of the legislation itself. It was very important that the legislation and the fate of the legislation needed to be determined.

Let me say firstly that there is an important principle with regard to the airports leasing legislation and its processing. Secondly, it is very obvious that the Commonwealth does not wish to be involved where, obviously, it does not need to be in many of these areas. Therefore, it is important that, subsequent to the passage of this legislation, there is extensive collaboration and consultation between the Commonwealth and the states .
I draw Senator Collins's attention to the evidence of the Senate committee when this matter was addressed on 6 August. In response to questions that were put, Mr White of the department said:

. . . final decisions have not yet been taken but I think it is the intention of the government to consult with the states and to give the states the opportunity to put their views as to whether state law should apply or not and then to take a final decision on those matters in the light of that advice. Today, the committee has heard the views from a number of states on those matters. Clearly, these views signal, from those states at least, what their response is likely to be. For example, the matter of gambling was raised, and perhaps that ought to be commented on explicitly.

If there are no regulations issued under this part of the bill, then state laws in relation to gambling would apply, and it would be open to the states to control matters of licences and so on, on airports—as they do in off‐airport locations in that state. If that were the outcome, there would be no concerns for the states or the parties that were involved with such licences that there could be any undermining of those licences in exclusivity clauses attached to them through action that the Commonwealth would take. Alternatively, if the Commonwealth were to take action to put in regs then, of course, those positions would be protected.
I believe these matters have been addressed on previous occasions. It certainly will be the intent of the government to work very closely with the states in these matters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —If I could just press Sir Humphrey once more, and I know when I am licked. As Senator Tambling knows full well, that longwinded exposition does not actually advance our knowledge on this thing by one single centimetre.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Commonwealth does do this, and if it does not do that, these things might happen. We certainly know what the predisposition of the states is. That is the one piece of information Senator Tambling read out which is correct. But that is all contingent on what we do not know—that is, what the position of the Commonwealth might be, whether it will want to keep to itself, for example, the question of casino operations on airport terminals and gambling. But as I say, I know when I am licked.

There is one further question that I do want to ask. I assumed that if we had passed this legislation last night—which I was expecting we would—we would have been back in here today re‐amending it with Perth. Is the inclusion of Perth now likely to have any financial impact on the leases, and has any work been done in determining whether there is likely to be an impact—which, clearly, if there is going to be an impact, would be a negative impact—on the sale?

TALK.START.PARA: —In response to Senator Collins's specific question, I am advised that it is not anticipated that it would have any significant impact of a financial nature.

—Can I just press Senator Tambling only once more on this. Was this on the basis of an off the top of the head remark from the minister or the head of his department? Was there actually an examination made by somebody competent to know whether there would be a financial impact or was this simply a reassuring statement to make in the Senate during the passage of the legislation?
—I would indicate that my answer was on the basis of advice from the airport sales task force.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, I am a bit like Senator Collins. Obviously it is a waste of time proceeding here in trying to get specific details of the government's attitude and what would be included in the leases. Bear in mind that it has been a bit of a hotchpotch arrangement up to date as to what airports would pay what amounts to local government, and it has been the subject of discussions and negotiations where the government has had the whip hand. That is a problem. Obviously the government has had the whip hand because it had no legal obligation to pay local government charges and taxes. I will leave that there.

SPEECH.PARA: I come, however, to another issue which relates to the future of the Hobart and Launceston airports. Might I say that the aerodrome local ownership plan arrangements that have been put into effect with Burnie and Devonport seem to be working quite well. Frankly, Tasmania is very concerned about the possibility of the Hobart and Launceston airports going to an entrepreneur who would not have the interests of the state at heart. It may be that the whole thing could be run down and it could cause a great deal of problems.

The importance of the Hobart and Launceston airports is enormous. One hundred per cent of persons who travel to Tasmania do so by sea or air. Eighty-nine per cent of travel to Tasmania is by air and 11 per cent is by sea. The committee will appreciate why we are most concerned about the ownership of the airports. The Tasmanian Regional Development Organisation has listed a number of matters which, because of the time, I will seek leave to incorporate in Hansard. These have been talked about not only in this chamber but also in the committee stage and elsewhere. The Parliamentary Secretary is aware of these matters. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a one‐page document of the Tasmanian Regional Development Organisation in respect of the future of Hobart and Launceston airports.
Leave granted.
Tasmanian RDO—Future of Hobart and Launceston Airports

1. The Tasmania RDO believes that it is vital for the economic future of the State that Hobart and Launceston Airports be owned and operated in the best interests of all users of the airports and their regional communities. The RDO endorses the findings of studies by both the Hobart and Launceston Airport Committees which recommended that the two airports should be owned separately and operated as low‐cost airports in the regional interest.

2. TasRDO also supports the conclusions of the two Airport Committees, and of the State Government, which unanimously oppose the transfer of key regional infrastructure such as airports to private sector companies which would operate the airports for profit maximisation and in potential conflict with the overall interests of the regional community.

3. TasRDO believes that regional airports should be controlled and managed by appropriate legal entities that are representative of the regional community and responsive to the needs of that community while capable of implementing effective and efficient management practices.
4. TasRDO believes that the Commonwealth, in granting to separate, regionally‐representative groups the leases over Hobart and Launceston Airports, should ensure that the airports are transferred:

PARA.TAB: Debt‐free and at no cost;
With provision of a one‐off capital grant to each lessee for essential maintenance and upgrading, and
Under a similar form of ownership to the Aerodrome Local Ownership Plan, and to a lessee which has no ownership interest in any other Australian airport.

SPEECH.PARA: 5. TasRDO welcomes the co‐operative approach of the Port of Launceston Authority and the Hobart Metropolitan Councils Association in their proposals to the Commonwealth seeking separate, local, community‐based ownership of the two major Tasmania airports.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the minister appreciates that we would wish to have an arrangement similar to the aerodrome local ownership plan that is operating quite well in Devonport and Burnie. We think that should also be the way to go in Hobart and Launceston. We are also anxious that the ownership of Hobart and Launceston is not in the one pair of hands, that the lessees be different organisations. As the Regional Development Organisation has indicated, we are very anxious to see that the airports are transferred debt free and at no cost with the provision of a one-off capital grant to each lessee for essential maintenance upgrading and under a similar form of ownership to the airport aerodrome local ownership plan and to a lessee which has no ownership interests in any other Australian airport. We are particularly interested that the airport should be controlled and managed by appropriate legal entities that are representative of the people in the areas. I ask the minister to respond.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling, Sen Grant

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to respond to a number of the issues that have just been raised by Senator Harradine. I also met yesterday with representatives of the respective regional development organisations in Tasmania. They obviously left with me a very similar statement to the one that Senator Harradine has just incorporated in the Hansard. They made patently clear to me—I can assure Senator Harradine—that, I think it was, some 87 per cent of the tourist visitation of Tasmania was dependent upon arrivals at Launceston and Hobart airports. Obviously, significant and major financial impacts flow to the entire Tasmanian economy from that issue.

SPEECH.PARA: So the government is very mindful of and has had a number of discussions on this matter with the Tasmanian government. I know that a number of my colleagues, in particular Senator Calvert, have been vigilant and strong in regard to these issues. I draw Senator Harradine's attention to the policy of the Liberal and National parties that was outlined in the document entitled The Tasmanian package prior to the last election. That policy statement included the position on airports, which read: `A coalition government will support the separate and preferably local ownership and operation of Hobart and Launceston airports.' As Senator Harradine would know, that is still the very clear position of the government. Along with a number of the other initiatives, both financial and social, that were outlined with regard to Tasmania, the government has been very carefully implementing those issues both in the budget and through policy development.

BREAK.PARA: With regard to the specific issues that Senator Harradine has just addressed, particularly the leasing of Hobart and Launceston airports, it is government policy to sell long-term leases over all FAC airports. Airports in phase 1 of the leasing exercise are to be sold by the end of the 1996-97 financial year. Hobart and Launceston are not in this group and will be considered later. As part of its commitment to local ownership and operation of airports, the government has announced its support for Hobart and Launceston airports to be leased separately. The government has said that if the two leading bids for one of the airports are tied it will grant the lease to the bid with the highest level of local participation.

The Commonwealth is aware of the importance of Hobart and Launceston airports to the Tasmanian economy. Careful consideration has been given to state and regional interests by the government in finalising its leasing and regulatory strategies for federal airports. I know that the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, John Sharp, has written the Minister for Finance, John Fahey, requesting that he consider not only the early leasing of the two airports but also that the airports are leased separately. Mr Sharp and Mr Fahey, as the two ministers responsible for the leasing process, are dealing with the leasing issues.

Senator Harradine also addressed the issue of, and drew his own view to, the obvious relative merits of the ALOP as it has impacted upon other airports in Tasmania. It is the government's intention to seek investors in airport leases who have the long-term financial capacity to sustain and improve those airports. This must be consistent with the views of state governments and local authorities, who see airports as the key to regional development.

If we get bidders who are less than financially strong, or if we took the bid process towards subsidies at the outset, as would be the case with the ALOP style schemes, we will be condemning regional airports and people who have such high aspirations for them to a culture of dependency on Canberra. It is not our first preference to go the ALOP route for Tasmania or other less prominent airports elsewhere in Australia.

In the committee stage, Senator Bob Collins raised this issue specifically with regard to Alice Springs and Townsville airports. If after having sought strong bidders we find none in fair and open contest, the government will have to look not only at what options are open to allow those airports to go into local hands but also at ensuring they are sound investments for the future.

As I said just a few moments ago, I was very pleased with the interesting discussions held yesterday with the representatives of the regional Tasmanian organisations, who certainly stressed the involvement of the local authorities in the ownership proposals. Senator Calvert has repeatedly discussed these issues with me. I know that he has engaged in a series of discussions with local government authorities throughout Tasmania. I am pretty sure that I am not giving away his confidences when I say that he has encouraged them to look very carefully at either capital involvement or joint ventures, or other arrangements that might be appropriate and attractive to Tasmania.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate having heard the detail that Senator Tambling has just given in respect of these two important airports for Tasmania. I can assure Senator Tambling, who I know is anxious about getting the legislation through, that I had always intended to leave this particular matter to this point of the debate. I would say that it will be the last point at which I intrude. It relates to my very close concern for and interest in—which I am sure I share with Senator Tambling—the future of Darwin and Alice Springs, which are equally crucial to the Northern Territory.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Harradine was raising the question of the airports in Tasmania in the very important role that senators have of raising concerns in the Senate that directly affect their state or territory. I have to say to Senator Harradine that in a real sense—not in an absolute sense—Independent senators are in a far more flexible position to exercise the role that this Senate was supposed to be created for; that is, to protect the interests particularly of the smaller states.

I say `in an absolute sense' because, even though those of us who are proud to belong to the mainstream two parties in Australia continually raise issues of legitimate concern to our own parts of Australia from time to time, obviously we do not have the same flexibility that Independent senators have. The concern that Senator Harradine raised in respect of the two airports in Tasmania—and answered to some extent of detail by Senator Tambling—demonstrated the importance of that role.

Mr Chairman, I raise this issue, and this is an appropriate matter to raise it on, because I have seen some ignorant editorials in newspapers in my life from time to time—I have seen some fine editorials, too. I do not know whether this article has been drawn to Senator Harradine's attention or whether he has seen it, but I have seen no more ignorant editorial than the editorial that was published in the Daily Telegraph Mirror of Wednesday of this week, which referred to you and also to Senator Harradine.

I have never seen a more profoundly ignorant article. It is a great piece of self‐indulgence. I have said it before: the most self‐indulgent job in Australia is to come into work of a morning, have your first four cups of coffee—I do—sit down in front of a keyboard and bash out any kind of idiocy on a screen and have it reprinted 150,000 times and distributed all over the country. It is a wonderful role to be an editor of a newspaper. I would love to be the editor of a newspaper. But I think that you first have to spend about 10 seconds on considering what you write.
I draw attention to this editorial in the Senate. The final paragraph says:
In what is essentially a two‐party system of government, Independent Senators such as Harradine and Colston are anomalies.
Thrown up by an unintended quirk of the electoral system, Independent senators are an annoyance we are forced to tolerate.
But they should not have ideas above their lowly station.
Listen to this:

BREAK.PARA: Their duty in the Senate is to be seen and not heard. Let them be so.

All I can say in response to the editorial writer of the Daily Telegraph Mirror —and the circumstances are different—is that, if Senator Harradine is in this Senate as `an unintended quirk of the electoral system'—

TALK.START.PARA: —A long one!

—Indeed, Senator. He has been thrown in here by this `unintended quirk' since 1975 by election, after election, after election. The reason I thought this editorial was so profoundly ignorant was that it ignored these very issues that are of close concern to the areas of Australia that we represent which it is an important role for senators to canvass here.

BREAK.PARA: I now want to take the opportunity to do so. I have restrained all of my remarks to this point of time in the debate, quite properly with the responsibility that I have got to get this through on behalf of the opposition. My final concern—I make no bones about it, whether it is a quirk that has put me here or otherwise—is raised as a senator for the Northern Territory. Senator Tambling is in a unique position to give me—I hope—an equally detailed response on Darwin and Alice Springs that he gave to Senator Harradine.

Basically my concern, Senator Tambling—and I am sure it is shared by you—is this: I have already declared my heresy in this debate. I have said already that I personally did not want to sell these airports. I did not want to sell the FAC. It was a government decision taken at the time, and I was party to it, which I supported as a loyal member of that government. But the reason for my concern is very simple: the Federal Airports Corporation, unlike, I regret to say, some other publicly owned operations in Australia, is a highly successful publicly owned corporation. The measure of its success is as amply demonstrated in the Northern Territory as it is anywhere else in this country.

Senator Harradine made the point that 100 per cent of visitors to Tasmania go by either sea or by air which, as far as I am concerned, was always one of those truths that I held to be self-evident, but that is certainly not the case in the Northern Territory. But—and this is why it is important to make this point—in a lot of ways places like the territory do have parallels with Tasmania because of the extreme distances, and of course the top end of Western Australia has the same situation, that people have to drive therefore placing enormous importance on air travel. As Senator Tambling knows, that is certainly the case in the Northern Territory where the lion's share of our visitors also come by air as they do in Tasmania.

One of the great successes of the Federal Airports Corporation has been to run in a truly entrepreneurial fashion—and it has—a number of airports around Australia that provide a national system of high quality terminals in this country. And don't tell me there is not a national interest in preserving that. In other words, it is not simply a nice terminal in Hobart or an efficient terminal in Darwin. There is, in my view, a real national interest to be protected in having in our major cities and gateways in Australia a national system of high quality airports. I do want to take the opportunity of commending what I think has been a superbly professional job by the Federal Airports Corporation in doing that.

The cold hard facts are, and Senator Tambling knows it, that if it had not been for the FAC negotiating with the then government to take on Darwin and Alice Springs those two world class facilities we now have there would never have been built. The point to make is that they were built off the budget. The FAC, I might also add, has had significant success in bringing what were then absolute economic basket cases back into profit or at least closer to the black line than they were before. They have done it at the same time as maintaining, to all of our benefits, some of the lowest landing charges anywhere in the world whilst building these high quality airports.

Senator Tambling knows exactly where I am coming from on this, and that is why I want him to respond in respect of Darwin and Alice Springs. You cannot overstate the benefit that those two first class facilities at Alice Springs and Darwin have had to the tourism industry in the Northern Territory. You cannot. When you consider the facilities that they replaced, the benefits we have had from them have been enormous and continue to be. We would want to see some restraint kept on landing charges under new operators who simply did not have the complete freedom to look simply to their bottom line.

There is not a natural marketplace operating with airports, as Senator Tambling knows. If you don't like the charges at Darwin, you can't just waltz 50 kilometres down the road and land at the other airport because there isn't one and there isn't one for 1,500 kilometres. It is simply not a marketplace situation that exists, and Senator Tambling knows it. We want an assurance that there will be reasonable charges after these airports are leased and that we will not have a situation where the charges are instantly hiked up or even hiked up over a progression of time because the charges all have to be borne by the people who want to come and visit us.

I want an assurance from Senator Tambling that in respect of the airport terminals at Darwin and Alice Springs there will be some consideration given to local ownership. In exactly the same way as Senator Harradine wants to see that situation in Tasmania, I want to see it in the Northern Territory because there is no question in my mind that the best interests of the local community then are served. If you have a local consortium they are far more tuned into the fact that they cannot simply regard the bottom line as being the only thing they are concerned about. They have to have regard to the flow‐on effects of any punitive charges that might be placed on airports.

I basically want an assurance from Senator Tambling and some detail as to how the government will ensure that the current successful operations of the Darwin and Alice Springs airport will continue and that the sale of those airports will not change the current status quo. No‐one but a fool would want to change it because of the highly successful way it is currently operating.

Senator TAMBLING (Northern Territory—Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development) (12.06 p.m.)—I thank Senator Collins for the comments that he has made. Very obviously, we share many of the issues from a parochial and Northern Territory point of view. I acknowledge them.

I will say two things at the outset, firstly with regard to the comments that Senator Collins made about the roles of editors in Australian newspapers—people who are invited to be editorial commentators. I look forward to the day when Senator Collins retires and becomes an editorial writer. It will probably depend on whether he retires before me or not as to who will get the upper hand in comments that might flow subsequently through the Northern Territory news and whether we are commenting on each other.

I share his concerns that the attack on Senators Harradine and Colston were most inappropriate and unfair in the way they were elucidated. I think when you talk about the role of Independent senators it is important to acknowledge that Independent senators certainly do have a particular role.

The only comment I have made that I think the editor may have picked up is that Senators Harradine and Colston are very prudent, succinct and tactful in the particular issues they pursue in this place. I only wish Senator Margetts would learn something from their tactics, particularly with regard to the time taken for debate in this chamber, in order to achieve very effective results. If Senator Margetts perhaps understudies them a bit more, she will find that there can be a tactical improvement in many areas.

PARA.BREAK: Senator Bob Collins asked some very specific questions with regard to the issues of this legislation that do need to be addressed, particularly with regard to Darwin and Alice Springs airports. I think it is important to acknowledge that Minister Sharp has already instituted a number of reviews and inquiries that will have an important aspect of future operations of airports around Australia. In particular, I draw attention to Minister Sharp's reference to the House of Representatives standing committee of issues relating to the use of international freight and the use of regional airports and their particular involve ment. I think that is equally important to be acknowledged in this particular issue.

BREAK.PARA: I note Senator Collins' comments about how particular airports—similar to those raised by Senator Harradine with regard to Launceston—do have an impact in regard to other regions throughout Australia. Like Senator Collins, I share that feeling with regard to the Alice Springs airport about which the international debate arises from time to time because of its very important strategic link to central Australian tourism—in fact, to all Australian tourism because so many tourists come through that particular airport.

Senator Collins, I would be pleased to indicate that the way in which we would process and deal with regional interests, whether they be in Launceston or Alice Springs, will tax the government equally and will have the attention particularly of government in the leasing and regulatory strategies that we will put into place in dealing with all of those issues.

I think it must be acknowledged that with regard to Darwin airport there is a peculiar situation. Like Canberra airport, Darwin's is a joint user airport that is shared with the Department of Defence. That produces challenges, problems and other issues that cannot be as easily identified as those at some of the other commercial airports around Australia. There has to be that third party, the Department of Defence, brought into any arrangements that may be made. Whilst there would certainly be an intent on the part of the government at this point in time to look at the opportunities that will arise with regard to the commercial activities at Darwin airport, they will have to be handled sensitively, having regard to the particular instances of those issues.

Senator Bob Collins addressed the issue of relating to reasonable charges and ensuring that we could be assured that the government is very mindful of the impacts that do apply in those areas. I draw the Senate's attention to the fact that the government has determined that there will be price caps over the next five years and, in particular, pricing oversight arrangements to be very particularly addressed. If I can take Senator Collins back to our election commitment, the government developed proposals for pricing oversight of airports post-leasing, which I now summarise.

A price cap will apply to all charges for aeronautical services as currently covered by the definition in the FAC Act. The ACCC will administer the price cap at major leased federal airports. There will be scope for operators to seek approval for charges for necessary new infrastructure investment, subject to support from principal users. The price caps at individual airports will be reviewed before the end of the first five-year period.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was that a core promise?
—Yes, of course.
—I am relieved to hear that.

—Good. I indicate also to Senator Collins that this pricing oversight issue has now been canvassed and addressed in a paper that has been circulated to all of the major industry groups, players and in particular to state and territory governments. We would certainly invite response and reaction to that from those parties, and of course Senator Collins if he wishes to comment on any of the issues that have been canvassed in that regard.

BREAK.PARA: I can assure both Senator Harradine and Senator Collins that the issues that relate to regional areas, as they have particularly been raised for Tasmania and the Northern Territory, do have the wide and full support of the government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say that I do find it somewhat galling to be patronised in the way that I was in the previous speech: if only I would sit and learn from other people I might be a well behaved senator. I have to say that a lot of people actually appreciate the hard work that we do. Many of the issues that have come out in this debate might not have come out at all unless we had done that hard work. I have to also remind everybody that if this bill had gone through when the Labor Party were putting it through, many of these issues would not have been addressed at all. Last year we were saying, `We are rushing this through and there are a number of issues which really have not been addressed.' Quite clearly from this debate, that is the truth.

SPEECH.PARA: Yesterday I canvassed some issues and we found out, as was again mentioned by Senator Bob Collins today, that in fact responsibility for management now lays in the hands of the lessee. If I was renting a house, which I currently am in Canberra, there would be some expectation that I be responsible, for instance, for keeping the garden neat and tidy, for mowing the lawn if there was a lawn, and for basic maintenance that was not the responsibility of the owner.

Considering that people will be making money out of buying leases of the FAC airports in Australia, one would like to think that, despite what we heard yesterday, there is some monitoring role—there would actually be some requirement to fund management. That means that if you purchase a lease in an area which has remnant bushland or wetlands or areas of important natural value, then you would actually include in the lease some requirement that management is funded.

What I am asking now, as a result of yesterday's statements, from the government is that there be in lease conditions of airports, particularly where there are areas of important remnant bushland or wetlands, biota, and Aboriginal lands obviously, that need to be looked after, a requirement for funding to be set aside for the management. This could include funding that could be made available to community groups if they wish to assist in the management.

I do not think that is an unreasonable thing. I think, if we were to go into a situation where people can buy a lease and they can monitor it going down, they could perhaps allow rubbish, as in Perth airport, and car bodies and so on to continue. They could allow people to come in with four‐wheel drives and continue to rip up remnant bushland. What I would like to see today is perhaps some assurance from the minister that in lease conditions there will be a requirement for management to be adequately funded. I do not think this is unreasonable. I think it is a proper expectation we should have if we are going this further step of privatising FAC airports.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —I appreciate the comments that Senator Margetts has just raised. I indicate to her that it would certainly be an expectation that any lease management arrangement that is put in place will require those operating to be fully and properly responsible for most of the issues that are properly addressed for the assets that are under their control. I will certainly draw Senator Margetts's comments to the attention of the department so that they can be looked at alongside the drafting of both the regulations and the particular lease conditions as they are developed.

—I have one final point to make. Similar to the previous comments we have made about assurances and non-assurances, under the Corporations Act, I believe that—if there is no actual requirement written into the lease conditions, if they are not required to do so—the company's purchasing airports may well not be able to set aside extra money to provide for management. It is my understanding that they may actually be sued by their shareholders if they use money other than for commercial reasons if they are not required to do so. If this is the case, it is not just a matter of, `We will look into it,' once again, it is a matter of an assurance—that an adequate funding of management will be part of lease conditions.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —I would draw Senator Margetts's attention to the environment strategies that have been included in the legislation.
—We have looked at those, and there is no requirement for management funding.

—I do not think this bill is going to address each and every specific dotting of i's or crossing of t's that Senator Margetts would require. However, we are certainly very mindful of the responsibility of all parties, whether it be the Commonwealth or the operating companies, in this regard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine, Sen Brian

TALK.START.PARA: —I must say to the parliamentary secretary that I am concerned about the fact that on 6 September Minister Fahey did indicate that the tender process would continue to be applied and would be applied to the Hobart and Launceston airports. In the final analysis, I do not know how this is going to be done. It has to be acknowledged, I think, that there are specific situations in regard to Hobart and Launceston. I hope the government will ultimately acknowledge that.

SPEECH.PARA: I must just make a comment about Senator Bob Collins raising the matter of an editorial. What paper was that in?

TALK.START.PARA: —Wednesday's Daily Telegraph . Just remember that you are not allowed to speak, according to this editorial.
—That is right. Actually, I would not mind a situation whereby Independent senators are seen but not heard, provided that we were paid. I doubt whether we would be.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me just say this, since it has been raised, about the media: I feel that their focus should be more on government. I am quite firmly of the view that it ought be recognised that in our bicameral system the governments are made and broken in the House of Representatives. The more the focus is taken off the House of Representatives, the more they can get away with. I believe they should be more accountable to themselves in the House of Representatives. I believe the press does not do the system much good by focussing so much on the Senate. Having said that, I would just like to reiterate what we all know; that is, that the Senate is, essentially, a house of review. It is our obligation to undertake that task, and we all do it. It might take a bit of time, but we all do it.

There are a couple of other functions of the Senate, as have been mentioned by Senator Collins. The composition of the Senate is such that it does give acknowledgment to the smaller states and their need to have an adequate and equal voice in this particular chamber. We also have the role of protecting the rights of individuals. That has been a cherished role of this place over a long period of time. We have an audit role which requires us, of course, to thoroughly examine government expenditure. We will be doing that all next week at the estimates committees.

I want to make it perfectly clear that none of us would have our position of influence—for good or otherwise—if there were not a situation in this chamber wherein each one of us has devolved upon us a very grave responsibility. That applies not only to Senator Colston and me but to every one of us here. I know that members of the major parties and also members of the Australian Democrats and Greens, within their party systems, recognise this. It should be borne in mind by the press that, if they focus on Independents in this place, they are certainly not seeing the whole picture or even 50 per cent of the picture but are merely seeing what may be 10 per cent of the picture. After all of the decisions have been made within the parties, it comes to certain votes being crucial in this chamber. The press does not focus on the developments that take place within the particular parties until the stage where the matter may become public in this chamber.

I apologise to the committee for making those comments. I would like the press to start focusing on somebody else apart from me for the practical reason that we are getting absolutely heaps of letters from everybody around Australia on every conceivable subject. I do not have the staff to handle that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Them's the breaks, Brian!

—Yes, they are the breaks. What does concern me is that the media coverage builds a false expectation in the minds of the public that an individual has enormous power in the parliament. That is just not correct.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling, Sen Grant

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Harradine's initial comments related to this bill and I appreciate that he took the opportunity to talk about the other issues concerning the media. I address the question he raised which related to the process of the airport sales. It is acknowledged—and it is very important to recognise it—that when the Commonwealth is disposing of an asset which it in effect holds in trust on behalf of all Australian taxpayers, in the process of any disposal or change of arrangements such as leasing of airports, we must achieve an outcome which is normally best achieved by a competitive tender process.

SPEECH.PARA: I sought to indicate that it would be the government's intention in the first instance to test that market—very properly—and to ensure that it sees what interest there is. We often have to be careful not to talk down the interests of regional areas which are developing. Very often, we can tend to prop up and provide a special kiss and cuddle arrangement that tends to shield the development of very proper commercial activities in remote and regional areas. I think there is a very strong advantage in ensuring that commercial operators extend their ambit and their aim into looking away from the parochial capital city bases that so often preoccupy the funding or commercial operators.

As the Minister for Finance, Mr Fahey, indicated, we will go through the tender process to be applied. However, I have already acknowledged that we have to recognise the special circumstances and arrangements of regional areas. As I have indicated earlier to Senator Harradine, I have also received a number of representations from colleagues and various regional development organisations in Tasmania with regard to this particular area.

We will look very carefully at the leasing and regulatory strategies to monitor them very carefully to see how they develop in the first phases of the sales program. As I have said, our policy commitment is very clear, particularly with regard to Tasmania. We have talked a lot about the separation of Hobart and Launceston. We will certainly look for that preference for local participation and local ownership from the community in Tasmania.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

DEBATE.TITLE: TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT (INTERNATIONAL TAX AGREEMENTS) BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 9 September, on motion by Senator Kemp:

BREAK.PARA: That this bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on the Taxation Laws Amendment (International Tax Agreements) Bill on behalf of my colleague Senator Sherry. The bill seeks to provide the legal authority for an international taxation agreement between the province of Taiwan and the nation state of Australia, an agreement which was signed on 29 May 1996. The agreement is in line with 36 other agreements currently in force with other countries. The purpose of concluding such agreements is to improve trade and investment flows by agreeing which nation has the right to tax certain types of income. In this manner, the threat of punitive double taxation is overcome.

SPEECH.PARA: In office, Labor presided over a major expansion in the number of agreements entered into. This agreement is consistent with that process and, as such, it will be supported by the opposition. As this is a non‐controversial piece of legislation, I will keep my comments on the bill brief. But it is well recognised that the government's legislative program is currently behind schedule and the Labor Party is concerned to ensure that there is no suggestion of undue delay.

However, as this matter relates to taxation arrangements for business transactions, we do raise a concern about government policy, particularly for the export of uranium to the province of Taiwan. It is a funny way to engage Asia, this government's aspiration, by exporting uranium to Taiwan, knowing that not only will this actively antagonise the fastest growing market that Australia has in its region—the People's Republic of China—but also it is a market in which government to government relations impact heavily and crucially on trade and investment flow.

We have got concerns about the whole manner in which the Minister for Foreign Affairs, the member for Mayo (Mr Downer), has discharged his responsibilities in this area. Before the election we said that one thing that could be guaranteed about the member for Mayo and also the present Minister for Trade (Mr Tim Fischer) was that if they took on responsibility for running Australia's diplomacy, they would be noticed in the region. Given the way they have pursued this issue, that aspiration has been met.

Without taking up much more time on this bill, I reiterate the point I made earlier: investment flows between countries are critically important, given the degree of exports that Australia sends to countries in our immediate region. In government, we were very keen to ensure that these sorts of agreements were put in place as a way of facilitating, as a way of stepping out of the process of trade flows, as a way for the government basically to encourage more and more interaction, particularly within our region. This legislation embodies and gives effect to a taxation agreement totally in line with the sorts of agreements that we entered into. Because of that, we support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown, Sen Bob

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not oppose the legislation, but having been in Taiwan in the last two months, I want to make some comments. Firstly, it is high time that we reviewed Australian policy regarding the recognition of Taiwan as an independent entity in the community of nations. One of the drawbacks of not doing so is that Taiwan is forced to enter into de facto bilateral arrangements such as this. The shortcoming in that is that it is not party to many important international agreements. I want to concentrate on environmental and social justice agreements. It is not party to many of the world agreements which would put upon the Taiwanese authorities the obligation to look after their environment in a way which the rest of the world sees as essential in the 1990s.

SPEECH.PARA: What I saw in Taiwan was a dam building project for 14 dams on an island half the size of Tasmania to capture waters running off a mountain range up to 4,000 metres high which runs down the eastern side of the island. The island has 22 million people packed onto it. It is seen as one of the tigers as far as the fast growing economies of Asia are concerned. But the environmental conditions on the island, the environmental wherewithal of Taiwan, are simply horrendous.

In a southern city, I was taken to the largest river flowing to the ocean, where Taiwan has what is called the great wall of garbage. For kilometres, there is garbage piled 30, 40, 50 metres high, being bulldozed into a U‐shaped valley, simply changing the course of the river. That is illegal. It has illegal operants in charge of it. I am talking here about gangster organisations which are able to undercut legitimate landfill operations on this island which is desperate for areas in which to dump its rubbish.

Meanwhile, in the river itself, other illegal operations are sandmining, to the extent where the major bridge across the river is being undercut and undermined, its foundations having been exposed for 3, 4, 5, up to 8 metres, by the effects of these illegal sandmining operations. And they are flaunting this in front of government. Nobody does anything about it, except a very brave, small band of environmentalists who end up with death threats and being threatened into silence as a result of their efforts.

Senator Bolkus spoke about the concern that Australian uranium ought not be finding its way into Taiwan. In earlier months of this year, the Taiwanese parliament, the Yuan, had a special vote on a fourth nuclear power station. It took three government members crossing the floor to vote down the prospect of another nuclear power station in a country where Tai Power, the huge power corporation, does not know what to do with its nuclear waste from the existing three power stations.

It has been looking at dumping that waste in the Marshall Islands. It has been looking at all sorts of non-domestic means. Its latest plan is to find a block of land on this highly populated island to dump its waste, at least as a temporary measure.

By the way, that vote in the Yuan in Taiwan took one member being brought into the parliament on a stretcher. His problem was he had objected to the social and environmental effects of a construction operation in Taipei so the gangsters got him and cut the tendons in his arms and legs. He was in intensive care and had to be brought out of there on a stretcher to vote on that vital vote against the fourth nuclear power station.

TALK.START.PARA: —Haven't they got a pairing arrangement?

—I do not think we should be too flippant about the very important message I am trying to bring to this Senate—that is, while we are making trading arrangements like this to benefit business with Taiwan, we ought to take some responsibility for the struggle of the Taiwanese people to protect their environment and to be able to exhibit their democratic rights, which they cannot do at the moment without fear of physical damage to themselves as well as suppression of the point of view they want to put forward. Taiwan is a democracy emerging from a dictatorship.

SPEECH.PARA: I was pleased to visit the nascent Greens Party, the newest Greens party in Asia. As I said two days ago in this place, it exhibited that sort of fearlessness which is attendant on environmental efforts in Taiwan by last year floating a boat out into the impact zone of the mainland Chinese government's rocket tests off Taiwan when China was trying to frighten voters in the lead-up to the presidential elections in Taiwan.

I visited the Bin Nan wetlands on the south‐west corner of Taiwan. Here we have some 3,000 hectares out of 80,000 hectares of wetlands left in this tiny island. These wetlands, amongst other things, are used by birds migrating from Siberia and Japan to Australia each year. They are disappearing at an awesome rate. This 3,000 hectares at Bin Nan is proposed as an industrial estate.

I can cite a couple of impacts of that besides the loss of those important bird habitats. It will mean the damming of some of those rivers coming out of the mountainous eastern region of Taiwan, in particular the damming of the Yellow Butterfly River, which is famed around the world for the efflorescence of butterflies, 50 million of them, a couple of times a year in an amazing natural phenomenon which would be obliterated were the dam at Meinun to proceed in Taiwan.

The water table in the area of these wetlands is falling at a rate of up to eight metres as water is sucked out from underground to supply, in particular, the burgeoning industrial needs of this tiger economy. We have to accept here in this luckier country some responsibility in entering into taxation arrangements favouring trade with Taiwan to heed the calls of the Greens, the environmentalists and the average citizens of Taiwan.

I can give one more example of the plight they find themselves in. On the day I left Taiwan, a headline in the English language newspaper was an injunction from the police commissioner in Ilun city—a million people or so in central Taiwan—that if residents continued to object to a landfill being gouged out of their suburb, he would send in 1,000 police and they would be arrested as trespassers and trouble makers. My heart goes out to those people on that tiny island who are trying to protect what little there is left of a decent living ambience, let alone the natural environment of what has been, and what remains in remnants, a magnificent, spectacular and particularly beautiful island in times gone by.

I would urge the government to rethink its policy towards Taiwan's lack of recognition in international fora. That is going to become mightily important in the years ahead if we are going to see the Taiwan authorities take on their responsibilities for protecting their domestic environment not only for the improved livelihood of 22 million citizens but also because the Taiwanese environment is of global significance.

Let me end by saying that I would like to hear from the government that it is considering falling in with the sympathy of the majority representatives of the Taiwanese people who voted against that fourth nuclear power station by prohibiting the export of uranium from our shores into the nuclear power proposals of Tai Power and the consequential hazard they mean for the people of Taiwan, if not for all the people of the Pacific region.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson, Sen Brian

TALKER.NAME: Senator GIBSON
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer)

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a non-controversial bill and, as Senator Bolkus said before, simply puts into effect an agreement with the Taipei economic and cultural office and the Australian commerce and industry office so the reciprocal and double tax agreements that apply to other countries will apply between Australia and Taiwan. I thank senators for their contribution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition supports the Mutual Assistance in Criminal Matters Legislation Amendment Bill 1996. In August 1994 the former Attorney-General, Michael Lavarch, issued an issues paper to a whole range of bodies with a request for comment in this area. All but two recommendations in the issues paper were accepted.

SPEECH.PARA: In mid-1995 the previous government approved the introduction of legislation to implement the recommendations of the review paper, plus a number of additional technical matters and two additions specifically requested by the previous Attorney-General. One was to have a specific death penalty refusal ground in the act. That has now been accepted by this government. There was also a provision enabling a defendant to be able to apply to a foreign country for assistance. That is also in this legislation.

In essence, the drafting instructions in this bill were settled by the previous government. Though the bill was not settled whilst that government was in power, this government seems to have picked up all of those drafting instructions. As a consequence, we support the legislation.
