DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN LAW REFORM COMMISSION BILL 1996AUSTRALIAN LAW REFORM COMMISSION (REPEAL, TRANSITIONAL AND MISCELLANEOUS) BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 10 September, on motion by Senator Parer:
That these bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —The opposition supports the Australian Law Reform Commission Bill 1996 and the Australian Law Reform Commission (Repeal, Transitional and Miscellaneous) Bill 1996. The bills draw on the recommendations of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in its 1994 report entitled Law Reform: the challenge continues . I compliment my colleague Daryl Melham for chairing that committee and for recommending quite a number of changes which helped to reconstitute and modernise the Australian Law Reform Commission. The bill is in line with the recommendations of that committee's report, recommendations which were acceptable to the previous government.

SPEECH.PARA: As a consequence, we support this legislation. In doing so, Senator Vanstone, I do not know whether you want to answer some of these questions at this particular stage or in the committee stage. We are concerned as an opposition that there have been funding cuts of half a million dollars to the Law Reform Commission. In the then opposition's pre-election statement there was some discussion about what the impact of cuts to the Law Reform Commission would mean and what the implications would be. The then opposition was asserting that the total impact of the cuts would mean that some reports of the Law Reform Commission would not be published. What we would like to know now is, given a greater level of cuts, what terms of reference of the ALRC will be affected by the level of cuts. Can you also identify what other implications the cuts will have to the Law Reform Commission. Having said that, we would like those answers, Senator Vanstone, but we do support the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Bolkus for his contribution.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The bills.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —There were a number of questions I raised in my second reading contribution. I think Senator Vanstone undertook to give some answers to them. I note that at the moment she is trying to get some information from the officers.

SPEECH.PARA: While she is doing that, can I say that the Law Reform Commission in its some 20 years of existence has done a great deal to enhance and to promote law reform in this country. This body was set up by the previous Labor Attorney‐General Lionel Murphy in the term of the Whitlam government in the early 1970s. It is a body which, in the eyes of most observers, has continually worked over that 20‐year period in a very productive way to advance law reform within Australia.

It has had some eminent chairpersons and some very competent staff over that period. It is a body which has ensured that the policy makers of this country will in the future ensure a continued vibrant existence for it. We have seen over the period of its existence, reports into a whole range of areas—reports which have led this parliament and governments to consider issues which have been quite important in the area of law reform.

It is fair to say that the challenge of law reform is a continuing one—continuing because of not just changes within our own society but also changes in the general global context in which we operate. Reports focussing on the rights of children, on the rights of women and on the broader concepts of patents and designs have been quite critical. The continuing issue of law reform with a view to access to justice issues is one that I am sure the Law Reform Commission will also focus on in the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator VANSTONE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Bolkus, I do have some information for you. I am advised that no current references are affected by the reductions. The Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) has discussed these matters with the commission. It is agreed that the Commonwealth will maintain the viability of the commission.

SPEECH.PARA: There will be some reduction in workload in the future—that is, perhaps not as many references as might otherwise have been able to be taken on will be taken on—but no current references are affected. New references are in train. Recently it has been given a new reference in relation to the archives. I understand the Attorney‐General has a further reference under consideration.

With respect to the remarks you have just made, the proposed legislation is in itself a demonstration of the government's commitment to having a viable law reform agency which is able to advise it on keeping Australia's laws up to date. I think that has been common ground between the major parties for some time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —You may not be able to answer this now, but we will have an opportunity in estimates next week. I would like information on what staff reductions will be made because of the cutbacks and also on what references the Law Reform Commission may have anticipated taking up in the immediate future which it will now not be taking up. I would like some information on, for instance, what references the commission was reasonably expecting to pursue that will be dropped in the future because of this funding shortfall.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday I undertook to check whether there were questions contained in Senator Faulkner's supplementary question on the dental health program. I had initially ruled the supplementary question out of order on the basis that it did not appear to me to contain a question, but I then accepted Senator Faulkner's re‐statement of his intended question, which was then answered by the Minister for Social Security, Senator Newman. The statements and the unparliamentary expression were certainly not in order.

INTERJECT.PARA: There are three points I would make about the matter: questions should be confined to questions and should not contain statements; unparliamentary language should not be used; and it is sometimes difficult for the chair with the level of noise which was maintained during that question yesterday.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I inform the Senate that Senator Parer, Minister for Resources and Energy, will be absent from question time today. Senator Parer will be presenting the Minex awards at the Minerals Council dinner in Perth. During his absence, I will take questions relating to the portfolios of Primary Industries and Energy, and Industry, Science and Tourism.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Vanstone in her capacity as Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Minister, I refer to your performance on the 7.30 Report last night in which you finally set a jobs target for the government. Asked whether unemployment would drop under your policies, you said:

QUESTION.PARA: Gee, we won't get re‐elected if it doesn't.
Minister, given that unemployment has now increased to 8.8 per cent, what target do you think you need to meet in order to guarantee your re‐election?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Faulkner for his question. I am pleased he is actively watching the 7.30 Report when I am appearing. Because he was actively watching it he will understand quite clearly what was said. The question that was put to me was: well, if you get your major structural changes through. As you would well understand, Madam President, if a government cannot get its major structural changes through, then not a lot is going to change. I responded with respect to that that I would not expect we would get much joy from the electorate if things do not improve. I would have thought that was axiomatic and simple and that anyone would understand it.

ANSWER.PARA: But the key point that you might like to bear in mind, Senator Faulkner, is that we went to the last election with clear policies that we wanted to implement—clear policies that indicated what structural change needed to be made. First and foremost amongst those were changes to the industrial relations legislation. Month after month we see figures on the trend—which is, of course, the most important figure to look at; more than the seasonally adjusted figures that jump about on a month to month basis—that show we have a very stable and flat labour market.

That should tell even the likes of yourself, Senator Faulkner, that something needs to be done to make a change. We had five years of growth under the previous government and still unacceptably highly levels of unemployment. That should tell you that policies needed to change.

We need this industrial relations legislation passed. We need the unfair unfair dismissal law wiped out, and we need to replace it with a fair unfair dismissal law. What you and your colleagues and the Democrats might like to bear in mind, Senator Faulkner, is that you can sit there in opposition as long as you want and be as difficult as you choose. You can collectively, if you want to, with a bit of other support, block these major structural changes that the economy desperately needs to bite into unemployment, but I give you this prediction as well: if you do not support the changes, if you block the changes that need to be made, the electorate will judge you just as harshly.

TALK.START.PARA: —My supplementary question relates to part of the answer given by Senator Vanstone in relation to the industrial relations reform agenda of this government. I ask you, Minister: hasn't Professor Wooden, the author of the NILS report—which was commissioned by you—said that the workplace relations legislation will have no impact on jobs growth this century? Minister, is that why you will not specify a target?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Not at all. I did see those remarks attributed to Professor Wooden. I have not spoken to him myself, nor have I seen anything in writing from him. But let me tell you something else the Professor said. The Professor also said that the predictions made by the National Institute of Labour Studies were not on the basis of a continuation of Labor's policies. How, for the life of me, the Professor managed to come to that conclusion, I do not know, because, as you well know, when an economist makes a prediction they make a prediction on certain assumptions. I can assure you of this: the National Institute of Labour Studies predictions were not based on structural changes taking place in the economy. They were, therefore, based on the economy being structured as it is now and I thought the Professor's remarks in that respect were most out of place.

ANSWER.PARA: I was of a mind to ring him about it. I have not had the time yet, but I may do so. I just remind you that you can get one view from one professor and one from another. That, I gather, was an off the cuff view of the Professor, because he was not asked by us to comment on the consequence of industrial relations changes as we intend to implement them. He was not asked to comment on that, and I presume he therefore has not given it serious consideration. (Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —My question without notice is directed to Senator Alston, the Minister for Communications. Minister, what were the main outcomes of the APEC ministerial meeting on the telecommunications and information industry that you hosted last week? How do you assess the benefits to Australia from the event?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Alston, Sen Richard

TALK.START.PARA: —The APEC ministerial meeting of telecommunications ministers last week was indeed a very significant event: 17 APEC economies were represented at the highest level and there was a very high degree of unanimity about some of the major issues. Almost all of the member economies were very much committed to proceeding down the trade liberalisation path as quickly as possible. Many of them have concerns to ensure that that progress is matched by economic development and human resources development. There was a general recognition that the old models of state owned monopolies were indeed in most instances already obsolete and that plurality and competition were going to be very important issues for the future.

ANSWER.PARA: I also stress the significance of consumer benefits being the paramount concern. Certainly, the ministers were very interested in issues such as technical conformance and, in particular, the transparency of universal service obligations. I stress once again that there was a very clear understanding on the part of all representatives of the APEC economies that universal service obligations are part and parcel of the landscape, that all countries must have them, that there is a need for ongoing cross‐subsidisation. It is simply a matter of setting the rules of the game and the telecommunications carriers have to play by them. It was indeed a very significant conference and made considerable progress towards goals which we all aspire to in terms of greater competition leading to lower prices, better quality of service and more products.

It is also true to say that there were a couple of other interesting developments. One was when the Mexican minister for telecommunications informed me that Mexico has significant interests in not one—as I had previously thought—but both Cuban telecommunications carriers: the fixed line carrier and the mobile carrier. When I asked him if this was a Fidel aberration, he told me that no, it was not. In fact, his discussions with Cuban ministers indicated that there was a very high level of understanding of the need for much greater competition in the utility field generally.

But I suppose the most significant event was that several representatives of APEC economies came up to me during the conference and asked me why it was that the ALP in this country was now blocking the partial privatisation of Telstra when the ALP in government had privatised almost everything in sight. I made it clear that the logic of this position was quite beyond me. One of them told me that he had had discussions with people he described as leading members of the ALP frontbench, several of whom he said he had previously thought were quite intelligent people. It was a very short list and I have to regretfully advise Senator Schacht he was not on that list.

He said to me that what they had told him was very disturbing indeed. I think it has significant implications for the region because the answer was, `Look, you've got to understand this is political.' There it was, Madam President. At a very significant international conference, I was being told that representatives of significant APEC economies simply could not understand why the ALP was being so opportunistic and not putting the national interest first when they recognised that there were enormous benefits to be gained from going down this path. I have to say that I found it very difficult to defend the position that was being taken. I made it clear that ultimately I was confident that logic and commonsense would prevail and the weight of public opinion would ensure that we ultimately got the right result. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Short, the Minister representing the Treasurer. Minister, why did you mislead the Senate yesterday? In response to a question from Senator Bishop, you said:

QUESTION.PARA: If there is a repackaging of salary packages, that will not necessarily have a negative impact on the revenue because if, as the senator suggests, there is more into the FBT area—

Minister, aren't you aware that motor vehicles are concessionally taxed and, in some cases, can attract only seven per cent FBT when they travel more than 40,000 kilometres a year? Secondly, the use of packaged investment loans will now become even more attractive to those earning more than $85,000 because they do not attract any FBT. Minister, why did you mislead the Senate? What will the revenue loss due to salary repackaging be or don't you believe people in this income bracket will now actively seek to repackage their salaries?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Labor Party's spokesman for superannuation scaremongering for that question. He will never be forgiven for the unsubstantiated, totally untrue assertions about superannuation that he made during the election campaign which deliberately caused unnecessary and huge fear for millions of Australians. He will never ever be forgiven and forgotten for that. I find it quite amazing that Labor has become so irrelevant in such a short time and devoid of so many thoughts.

ANSWER.PARA: I thank Senator Sherry for his question because it does give me the opportunity to welcome again the opposition's support for the introduction of the contribution surcharge on higher income earners. I also note in doing that that this government inherited from Labor an inequitable and complex superannuation system which was all its own doing. The surcharge introduces a greater fairness into the system than has been there at all during Labor's previous reign.

Now it is true that the proposal does provide a challenge in its implementation. But given the overall system benefits, it is a challenge worth taking on and the industry benefits significantly from the tax concessions applying to superannuation, and with those come regulations and costs. So far as the question that Senator Sherry asked in terms of repackaging is concerned, it is true that repackaging could occur—
Senator Panizza interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —As always happens, and I thank Senator Panizza for that interjection, because it has been happening over many years as superannuation arrangements have changed and changed under Labor. There is nothing new about repackaging of salary packages as circumstances change and one would expect that to be the case.

ANSWER.PARA: What we have made crystal clear, both the government and yesterday the tax commissioner in a speech in Sydney, is that if the salary repackaging does occur to a significant extent and in a way that could cause revenue loss and leakage through, in effect, a rorting of the system, then the government will consider the matter at that time and take whatever measures are necessary and appropriate to protect the revenue. That in no way at all conflicts with anything that I said here yesterday or on any other occasion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Doesn't that mean that in effect you are foreshadowing an increase in the FBT tax?
—The answer is no.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer and the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, everyone is aware of the gross neglect of Australian families under 13 years of Labor and how much the gap between rich and poor widened during that time. In the light of this, could you please enlighten the Senate as to how much better off families will be as a result of the recent reduction in home loan interest rates and how much better off they will be as a result of the Howard government's family tax initiative.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Troeth for that question, which enables me to point out the very stark contrast between what happened to Australian families, the lifeblood of our nation, many of whom are also small business people, under Labor's 13 years of misrule and what this government has already put in train to correct that situation. It is true, as Senator Troeth has acknowledged in her question, that Labor's policies when in office effectively ignored Australian families. Not only did they ignore Australian families; the impact of the policies that they did introduce caused enormous damage to Australian families. During that period, and as a result of Labor's incompetence, home mortgage rates rose to 17 per cent, which dashed many families' hopes of buying a home and even forced many families into extreme financial hardship.

ANSWER.PARA: We all remember the so-called recession we had to have, which was a recession we should never have had to have and which forced unemployment up to 11 per cent. Nor will we forget the savage increase on families in recent budgets in terms of sales tax increases and the like. Indeed, in the 1995 budget the sales tax burden on families increased by no less than $60 per week. So that is the former government's record.

The Australian people acknowledged that overwhelmingly on 12 March when they threw that lot out of office comprehensively and showed that Labor, by 2 March, had become as irrelevant then as it is now. That was acknowledged by the Secretary of the Labor Party, Gary Gray, when he said:

We couldn't campaign on a positive policy agenda because no-one believed us; they thought that we were liars. We couldn't campaign on our record because by and large the perception of our record was that it was stuffed.

I think most Australians said amen to that. In stark contrast to Labor's neglect, under this government we have already seen welcome falls in home loan rates. Variable home loan rates offered by the major banks since earlier this year have fallen from 10.5 to 9.25 per cent. That is a fall in interest rates of 10 per cent and delivers a benefit of $88 a month on a $100,000, 25-year loan.

Fixed home loan rates have already fallen since the budget, delivering a very substantial benefit to families taking out these loans. For example, five-year fixed home loan rates offered by the Commonwealth and NABS have fallen from 9.75 to 8.95 per cent. We are, therefore, helping Australian families to achieve their dream of home ownership. We also delivered on 20 August in the budget our electoral commitment to Australian families in the form of major assistance to families with young children, a tax initiative which was a $1 billion a year injection into the paypackets and pockets of Australian families. We have also assisted them in numerous other ways, for example with private health cover. (Time expired)

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. Minister, in answer to a question on the dental health program yesterday Senator Newman—and I quote her directly—said this:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . funding runs until the end of December this year, so it is for 3½ years that we are honouring that commitment to that program.
Government senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —The previous day—
—Order! Senator Faulkner, I will ask you to start again in a moment, because it is not possible to hear you.

—I raise a point of order, Madam President. I have not heard one word of what Senator Faulkner has said. If you would not mind asking him when he reads it perhaps to hold his head up so I might hear what he is saying.
—On the point of order, Madam President, if Senator Short would prevail on his colleagues to observe decorum in this chamber he might hear, because Senator Faulkner is talking quite loudly.
—There is no point of order. Senator Faulkner, when we have quiet, I will ask you to start your question again.
—Thank you, Madam President. Yesterday, in answer to a question on the dental health program, Senator Newman—and I quote her directly—said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . the funding runs until the end of December this year, so it is for 3½ years that we are honouring that commitment to that program.

She also said the previous day that it `was a finite four-year program'. Minister, can you explain to the Senate why the health portfolio budget statement records savings—from a program which, according to Senator Newman, ends this year—to the tune of $112.84 million in 1997-98, $114.53 million in 1998-99, and $116.48 million in 1999-2000—a total of $343.85 million? Minister, are these phantom savings which corrupt the budget bottom line, or was Senator Newman just plain wrong again?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, let me say that questions concerning the health portfolio ought to be directed to the appropriate minister. Secondly, let me say in response to Senator Faulkner's question that the answers that Senator Newman provided to questions yesterday or perhaps the day before were, as I understand it, absolutely right. I have not one word to add to or detract from what Senator Newman said.

ANSWER.PARA: I thought that I heard Senator Faulkner say something about corrupting the budget bottom line. For someone from that side who was in government for 13 years to talk about corrupting the budget and corrupting the budget bottom line is hypocrisy of the greatest order.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, on a point of order: Senator Short has already indicated that he cannot answer the question. He should sit down if he cannot answer it—yet again.
—There is no point of order.

—Quite obviously, Labor cannot take it. They cannot take it because they know in their heart of hearts that they corrupted the budget process right through their years in office. Over the last five years alone they corrupted the budget bottom line by $70 billion—stuck it on Bankcard—and ran up debts of $100 billion a year by the time they had left government. The interest bill on that alone this year is over $9 billion. That is not much less than what we are spending on defence and education as a Commonwealth government.

ANSWER.PARA: Now the Leader of the Opposition, supported by Gareth Evans—although you never know where he stands on these things, and you never hear from the shadow minister for finance—is proposing a further corruption of the budget bottom line of $18.8 billion over the next four years, which will blow the nation's accounts out of the water even more than they have been blown out of the water in the last 13 years of Labor incompetence and mismanagement.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, on a point of order: I am one senator who would like to hear the answer to the question. The question to the Assistant Treasurer was whether an amount of close to $400 million—
—I have answered it.
—No, you have not. The question was whether that amount which is in the budget papers, for which the Assistant Treasurer is responsible in this chamber, is fake savings or real savings.

—As stated by Senator Collins, that was the question but it did include in the concluding remarks a reference to the corruption of the budget bottom line. It would seem that Senator Short is spending more of his time on that than the former part, but he would be entitled to do so. There is no point of order.

—I answered the question in the first minute of my answer, and the answer to the question was that the details that were provided by Senator Newman yesterday, and I think the day before—but certainly in the detailed answers she gave yesterday—were absolutely correct and require no further amplification or detraction one way or the other. That is what I said the first time round.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. We have heard that the Commonwealth dental health program is apparently a non-existent program. Minister, how do you extract savings from a non-existent program?

—As I said before—and Senator Faulkner obviously is not listening—in my opinion Senator Newman answered the question absolutely accurately and comprehensively yesterday. I have nothing further to add.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. What are the government's objections to the human rights clause of the Australia-EU trade and cooperation agreement? Why does Australia now believe that we cannot `observe universal human rights'? Which universal human rights does the government intend not to observe or believes that we are not observing now? Are those rights related, for instance, to Australia's treatment of our indigenous population or to Australia's stand on greenhouse gas emissions?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I was listening to Triple J this morning, so I missed the AM program.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition senators interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—I am a strong supporter of Triple J.
—Turn around and tell that to Senator Alston.
—You want to close it down, Robert.
—I cannot get a fair go around here, Madam President.
—Order! Just wait a moment.

—I missed the AM program in which I understand a European Union trade official raised the issue of Australia's reluctance to include a human rights clause within what is a draft trade and cooperation agree ment between our country and the European Commission. The reason, I understand, is simply that—it is a draft agreement about trade and economic cooperation.
—No human rights in trade!

—We actually believe Australia has a good record on human rights. We are proud of our record. We have not only signed up to all the major conventions on human rights but we adhere to them and we furthermore promote that record internationally and proudly, Senator Bourne, and you do as well. It is good. We fail to see why we would therefore need to include within a trade agreement with the European Union a specific obligation upon ourselves that relates to our obligations under human rights conventions.
—Why was it good enough for John Major and not for you?

—Who was it good enough for? The one it was good enough for apparently was Gareth Evans, who had been negotiating this for the last two years. Gareth Evans may well have felt that he needed to parade our credentials in some way to the European Union; we believe our record stands. Our record is well known. Our record is well respected.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the minister for that answer. I ask him further: is it the case then that this is a draft framework for all EU trade and cooperation agreements, which I understand it is? If that is the case, wouldn't it then be right and proper for Australia to insist that a human rights clause be included because then they will be included in future EU agreements? Don't we believe that if our record can stand up to this sort of scrutiny everybody else's should as well and we should be pushing that at every single opportunity?

—If there were a way in which we could use our influence to improve human rights performance elsewhere, then I would support that. My note here speaks of a bilateral agreement between Australia and the European Union. I find it hard to understand how Australia would be negotiating a draft framework agreement for the European Union. Nevertheless, I will go back to the minister and see if I can get further information on the specific question that you now raise. If I can add something usefully next week, I will do so.

—My question is to the Minister for Social Security. Will you acknowledge that your budget papers indicate that, as a consequence of your changes to the treatment of superannuation for the over 55s, 54,000 people will have their social security benefits reduced and 12,900 will have them cut completely? Do you acknowledge that most of these people will therefore be forced to depend on their superannuation to survive? Can you explain how these people will use their superannuation investments or, as your colleague Senator Short put it yesterday, `avail themselves of their superannuation' without drawing down and eroding that investment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The budget numbers are of course accurate. They are the estimates of what will be the event. The reason for giving numbers of some people who will be affected and some people who will lose entitlement—and over the totality of Australians with superannuation over 55 they are very small numbers—relates to the fact that they are people in positions where they can contribute to or totally support themselves in their early retirement.

ANSWER.PARA: I find it extraordinary that the Labor Party is continuing to run a scare campaign which essentially means that they are trying to advocate on behalf of the most well‐to‐do elements of Australia. I had an example given to me just yesterday by Senator Calvert, for example, who said that a bank employee came to him complaining about this new measure. Why does he complain? Because next year when this measure comes into place he is going to have to be much more reliant upon his own resources instead of those of the taxpayer, which he is currently enjoying. He took early retirement from his bank and had $285,000 in superannuation.

BREAK.PARA: It seems to me that that is the group of people the Labor Party is speaking for. If so, it is a pretty good example of what has happened to this country. Continually over the last few years special interest groups, particularly people at the higher end of town, have been advantaged by a Labor government. That is one of the reasons why the battlers of Australia decided they were going to tip Labor out. Those who were getting on in life and raising children were finding it extraordinarily difficult and they could see their taxes assisting people at the top end of town. The frustration that that led to was enough to tip Labor out of government.

We are saying that people on low superannuation incomes in fact will not be affected or minimally affected, depending on their circumstances. We are doing nothing more than introducing the means test at 55 for people who have been out of work for nine months that they will have to face at 65. If they are effectively retired, there is no injustice in that whatsoever. The taxpayer should not be asked first to support them, only to top up the support that they may need if in fact their superannuation is in the middle levels. As I said earlier, I think it is extraordinary that Labor continues to argue that people who are on high incomes and with high assets should somehow still be entitled to support from the battlers. It is just beyond comprehension.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. In order to allay the concerns of the thousands of Australians who are contacting us to protest about the inequity of this measure, will you guarantee that no-one who is affected by this measure will be forced to draw down their superannuation investments in order to maintain an income equivalent to the level of benefit they would previously have received?

—I think it is a continuing problem with the Labor Party that they do not seem to understand the difference between capital and income. It seems to be a pretty clear indication of where the problem lies. Nobody is suggesting that these people are going to have to draw down on their assets. If they choose to, it is another matter.

BREAK.PARA: A question was asked of Senator Short yesterday about paying off the mortgage. Of course, the superannuation funds which are used to pay off your mortgage are exempt under the current means testing rules. Those opposite are trying to suggest that there are somehow some new, devious and sinister proposals in place. Existing proposals for those at 65 will apply to those at 55.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. The minister may be aware that Ansett is considering abolishing first‐class travel. Could the minister inform the Senate what savings might be made were MPs, public servants and others to travel business class instead of first class? Will the government, considering current budget stringencies, consider an immediate abolition of the use of first‐class travel by people who are being paid for out of the public purse?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Short, Sen Jim

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Brown for his question. He did give me some advance notice of this question and I am in fact responding on behalf of the Minister for Administrative Services rather than the Treasurer because it falls into that area of responsibility. First‐class travel entitlements for parliamentarians derive from a determination of the remuneration tribunal. Records of public servant travel are held by individual agencies and a consolidated estimated cost reduction is not available.

ANSWER.PARA: The government is committed to reducing costs, and currently we have processes in train to cut the travel costs of federal parliamentarians and their staff. There have, outside of that, already been some savings achieved by a redesign of airline schedules. For example, commuter services between Canberra and Sydney are now all economy, I understand, as are most Canberra-Brisbane services. This is now true of most Canberra-Melbourne services as well.

In terms of what the government is putting in train to look at cutting travel costs, in part they involve the establishment of a preferred travel service provider contract. Tenders were invited on 31 August for such a preferred travel supplier arrangement covering domestic and international air travel by federal MPs and their staff. Lower fares, better discounts, reduced administration and potential use of frequent flyer points for additional discounts are being sought. Prospective tenderers were briefed this morning, I understand, and establishment of these new arrangements is expected by early November, initially covering a two-year period.

The government has already implemented a new policy restricting the use of frequent flier points by parliamentarians and their staff to official travel only, thereby reducing the cost. Australian Public Service wide statistics are not readily available, as I said, but an example would be the Department of Administrative Services where, of an annual volume of some 15,000 trips, less than four per cent are first‐class travel and by personal choice business class is used in lieu of first class three times as often. Significant discounts are achieved by the Australian Public Service under the preferred travel service provider arrangements being adopted for parliamentarians, and additional savings are also achieved by a departmental policy of planning travel to take account of discount fares and best fare of the day arrangements under the preferred travel service provider contract.

In addition to this comprehensive review of its travel policies, the government announced many measures in the budget to further streamline the operations of the Department of Administrative Services, including the sale of five government businesses and the corporatisation of one other, the sale or refinancing of Dasfleet's 18,000 vehicles, the sale of 11 commercial properties in the Commonwealth property portfolio, realising approximately $100 million this year, and a $20 million reduction in Commonwealth advertising for 1996-97.

In addition, of course, since coming to power in March the Howard government has cut the number of government portfolios from 30 to 28 and cut the number of ministerial staff from former Prime Minister Keating's 365 to 294—a cut of 20 per cent. The number of private consultants, which were 40 under Labor, has been reduced to just one under this government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I ask the minister if he would clarify his answer by telling the Senate whether or not the government rules out the option of abolishing the use of first‐class travel by MPs and public servants. Is there any impediment to doing that because it is a tribunal matter?
—Senator Collins is listening to this.
—I reckon he should have to come from Tassie on a push bike, Ron.

—I ask the minister, in light of that trite interjection, whether it is not a good thing for us to be seen to be travelling at least in business class and economy? I have used the first‐class option, but I think we could conjointly move under these current circumstances, could we not Senator, to remove it from the options for us to travel.

—Members and senators are of course free to choose what class of travel they wish to use. If they want to travel economy or business class, they can do so. Indeed, for three or four years I did to try to set a good example to my colleagues. I found myself so lonely out there that I came back to first class. I repeat to Senator Brown that the question of first-class travel entitlements for parliamentarians derives entirely from the determination of the remuneration tribunal and, of course, that is an independent tribunal.

—My question is directed to Senator Short, the Assistant Treasurer. In answer to my earlier question about the Commonwealth dental health program, you, Minister, asserted on no less than three occasions that Senator Newman was absolutely correct in stating that the Commonwealth dental health program was to terminate at the end of this year and, in fact, that all your government had done was bring this forward by six months. Given that this places a very serious question mark on your budget figures, I ask you to explain again to the Senate how you can claim savings in the budget state ments of $343.85 million. How do you claim savings of $343.85 million against a nonexistent program?
—Senator Faulkner can try as hard as he likes, but I have already answered that question on two occasions. I have no intention of repeating the answer for a third time.
—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Perhaps Senator Short might care to explain to the Senate how this fits with John Howard's `Charter of budget honesty'.

—I am glad Senator Faulkner has given me the chance to comment on the `Charter of budget honesty', because the two words `budget honesty' are pretty alien to the Labor Party. They have never had an honest budget in their life. I was delighted—and I agreed completely, for once—with one of the leading economic commentators, Terry McCrann, who claimed on budget night that this budget was the first honest budget in living memory. You can turn your back on me if you like, Senator Faulkner—you normally do when you do not like it—but the fact is that this Howard government has reinvented the term `budget honesty' and is going to carry it through in its entirety.

—I would like to ask a question of the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone. The question is: the Austudy regulations, which were disallowed by the Labor Party last Tuesday, will have a serious effect on over 1,000 rural and regional families in Australia. Could the minister explain to the Senate the extent of the effects of such a move? Does it further demonstrate the degree of self-proclaimed relevance deficiency syndrome, RDS, under which the opposition is suffering?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Eggleston for that question. Madam President, as you would no doubt be aware, earlier this week some Austudy regulations were disallowed by this chamber. I have no quibble, obviously, with the chamber's right to do that—it is a good and sensible procedure to have—but what Australians need to recognise is that the regulations that were disallowed were not regulations put out initially by this government; they were regulations put out by the previous government, the people opposite. Those regulations were a reflection, in part, of the previous government's last budget—their 1995-96 budget families package.

ANSWER.PARA: What that means is that the decisions that were embodied in those regulations were decisions taken by the cabinet members, as they then were, now shadow cabinet members—at least some are—which they endorsed. They are decisions which were taken to the caucus and which were endorsed. These regulations were taken out to Government House and approved by the Governor-General, and the name on the bottom was `Hon. Ross Free'. When I mentioned that these were, in fact, the previous government's regulations, people opposite said, `Oh, well, he's lost his seat.' But I saw a couple of days after this that they were wheeling him in to try to get him back in. I bet they have not told him they have just discarded the regulations that he put through.

Of course, the story goes a little bit deeper than that. Initially when we heard that Senator Harradine wanted to take over a motion to disallow these regulations, we did not have much time. Obviously we rang the previous government and said, `Look, these are your regulations. What are you going to do? Are you going to support your regulations?' I was told there was a powwow being held. It was a powwow with Senator Carr and Senator Bolkus, and someone else joining in. They would make a decision about what to do. Then we got the phone call, `Yes. They're our regulations. We'll support them.' So I thought, `Well, that seems pretty sensible—

TALK.START.PARA: —Who told you that?
—I understand it came from Senator Evans's office as a consequence of that meeting.i
—Well let's get it clear.

—I understand that your whip's office told one of my staffers you were going to support the regulations. So I come into this place and it is my understand ing—if I am wrong, I will happily correct that, because that could be a communication breakdown—that, nonetheless, your regulations—
—I don't mind correcting you.

—You assert I am wrong. You just wait until you find out. They are your regulations and you want to, in fact, disallow them. What have you done? You rang back in a hurry and said that, no, you were not going to support the regulations, that you would support the disallowance of your own regulations. It was a snap decision—presumably to curry favour with Senator Harradine.

ANSWER.PARA: What have you done? You have wiped out extra assistance to over 1,000 rural families. You either knew you did it, and you did it deliberately because you wanted to wipe out the extra assistance to rural families—this is extra Austudy payments to families who are on drought relief concessions—or you did not know. No wonder Senator West is keeping her head down. She trips out to western New South Wales. She says that she is a senator for rural New South Wales. You participated in striking down some regulations that offered benefits to 1,000 rural families. You either knew you did it—in which case it is a disgrace—or you did not know, and it is equally a disgrace.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to Senator Newman, Minister for Social Security. Minister, are you aware that people who are forced to draw on their superannuation earlier than they had contractually agreed to are often required to sign a statutory declaration that they have retired and often incur an early withdrawal penalty? Do you think this is fair for those people over 55 who your government is forcing to draw on their super to support themselves while they wait for the old age pension? Will you legislate to ensure that they will not have to make these statutory declarations and that they will not incur penalties?
—It is good to have an intelligent question from the opposition on superannuation, at last.
—It's pretty unusual.

—It is unusual; thank you, Senator Short. I share Senator Reynolds's concerns about people who have difficulty accessing their superannuation. There are, in fact, some people—not the majority—who cannot access their superannuation. It is our intention to look at what measures we can put in place to protect those people. Nevertheless, the majority of people can access them, and will be expected to do so.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, you have referred twice, I believe, in this question time, to very small numbers. I wonder, if you have access to that kind of information, if you can provide that information to the Senate so that we know what kind of numbers we are talking about.

—One of the earlier questions did in fact refer to numbers. I think it was Senator Mackay who used some numbers out of the budget papers. I was acknowledging that I was pretty confident that she was quoting accurately on those particular issues. However, there will obviously be a lot of opportunity for taking this up further at the estimates committee hearings next week. I expect that that is where you will come and follow the issue through, Senator.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, Senator Vanstone. Can you confirm, Minister, that the budget changes to Austudy will affect 125,000 Australian students? And can you also confirm that, under the coalition's plan to increase the independent rate age from 22 to 25 years, the point of assessment will be at enrolment? That means that a student who enrols in a four-year degree at age 24 will still be considered dependent upon their parents when they are aged 27 or 28. Is that the case, Minister?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —As to the exact numbers of figures that would be affected, Senator Stott Despoja, I will get those figures for you and break them down into the various changes that will be made: one, vis‐a‐vis the change in the age of independence from 22 to 25, and the other of course students who might be affected by the revamping of the actual means test. Even though I do not give this credit to members sitting directly opposite, I would at least assume that you would not count in the families affected those families who have been rorting Austudy, families with million dollar houses and getting Austudy for their children. I do not think even you would agree with that, and you would not want those numbers included as people affected that you were concerned about. I understand that, and I will get those figures for you.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the age of independence, whether it starts from enrolment date or otherwise, this matter has been raised in the other chamber. You may or may not be aware of that. I will get you the Hansard of that. I am not sure whether a public statement has been made with respect to this, but I will tell you this at least: there is absolutely no intention on the government's part to create the sort of situation that might cause havoc.

If there are anomalies in the way that we have indicated we want to shift back to the 25 age, we will in fact consider those and look at them. We are happy to talk to you sensibly about that because the intention is to ensure that people who are at home and are being cared for by their parents do not receive Austudy. If there is an anomaly—or you might choose to call it a mistake—we will happily discuss that with you.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Thank you, Minister, for that answer. Would you agree, Minister, that it is an absurd and a ridiculous situation that, if the point of enrolment is the point of assessment, students who are 30 years of age should be considered dependent upon their parents? Is that not an absurd situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you for the supplementary question. I have had a mind to cast my eye over the adjectives you use, Senator, to describe various government policies and things you disapprove of. It is quite an interesting list, but you might extend it a bit because it is becoming a bit boring. There is a bit of repetition of adjectives. Someone with your high level of training, I would have thought, could extend the range. I tell you this: if one of Alan Bond's children was living at home, and was 30, I would not think it appropriate if they got Austudy.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services, Senator Newman. Can the minister confirm that over 30,000 Commonwealth seniors card holders will no longer be eligible to receive free hearing services through Australian Hearing Services as a result of the changes in the budget? Further, can the minister explain how the government reconciles these changes to eligibility requirements with its pre-election commitment to maintain all current Commonwealth concessions?
—I will have to get an answer to that from the Minister for Health and Family Services and get it back to Senator Foreman as soon as I can.

—My question is to the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill. Shadow Treasurer Gareth Evans admitted last month that many middle income Australians felt badly treated under Labor and, of course, the Labor Party National Secretary admitted that the Labor government had lied to the electorate. In contrast to the abysmal Labor record on assisting low and middle income earners, can Senator Hill inform the Senate how the government has delivered on its commitment to restore fairness and equity to the Australian community in its budget? In particular, what was the reaction to the government's move to introduce a higher Medicare levy for wealthier people who failed to take out private health insurance?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hill, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable senator for the question. As she said, the now Mr Evans, formerly Senator Evans, former government minister—the one suffering relevance deprivation—said, with the wisdom of hindsight, `A great many Australian families earning between $30,000 and $40,000 a year felt badly treated under the Keating government.' That is not surprising. That is, as you say, Senator Knowles, a little more delicate way of expressing what Gary Gray, the Labor Party Secretary, in effect the boss of the Labor Party, said recently when he said, `We couldn't run on our record because they thought our record stunk.' That is what he was talking about.

ANSWER.PARA: He was talking about the great mass of middle Australians who felt so badly let down by Labor, not surprisingly. It was not only Labor that gave us record unemployment but also Labor gave us falling living standards and a growing gap between rich and poor. The legacy of the last Labor government was to leave a growing gap between rich and poor in this country, undermining that great egalitarianism that we all regard as so important. Senator, you will remember that Hugh Mackay said, when Labor was in government, `One thing this Labor government is giving Australia for the first time'—

TALK.START.PARA: —No‐one is listening to you.
—Senator Bolkus, you might be proud about it, but not many of your colleagues are—`is the development of a new under‐class.' That was the legacy of Labor.

ANSWER.PARA: In comparison, this government has sought to provide a fair budget and to give the battlers of this country a fair go. In particular, we directed our taxation benefits to lower and middle income families with family benefits of $1 billion of tax relief, particularly for families with dependent children at the lower end of the scale. Add to that the benefits that we have given to self‐funded retirees who have been taxed at a lower threshold than pensioners earning exactly the same income. We have given those pensioners greater certainty for the future by funding their pensions at 25 per cent of male average earnings in the forward estimates. The benefits that we have given in the form of a tax rebate for health insurance adds up to a very fair deal for the less well‐off within our community. I remind you of the extra $20 million we have provided for emergency relief for families and the $19 million we have provided in funding to tackle the terrible problem of youth suicide.

Also, we have launched an $8 million youth homelessness program providing $37.6 million over the next four years for a national respite plan for carers. It is not surprising that this budget was lauded by respectable press in Australia as a fair go—a fair budget for those who suffered most under the previous Labor government; a return to a fair go for low, lower and middle income earners, those Australians who deserve the support of government. They get it from the coalition in a way that they certainly did not get it from Labor.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, you did not get around to answering the last part of my question: what has the reaction been to the government's move to introduce a higher Medicare levy for wealthier people who fail to take out private health insurance? Was it actually ever thought of by anyone in the Labor government?

—I ran out of time, but I am more than happy to note that it is of great embarrassment to the Labor Party that the penalty being put on high income earners who are not contributing to private health care, in other words, those who are expecting their health to be covered by the public purse, was put on by the coalition government. That is something that Labor should have done but never had the courage to do. They have been reminded by none other than former Senator Graham Richardson, who informed us in the Bulletin that that was actually his intention. He wanted to do this but he could not get the support of his colleagues in the Labor Party to tax the rich. The Labor Party would not do it. It had to come from the coalition. Why did he say they were not prepared to do it? He let the cat out the bag. He said Labor was uncomfortable with private health care. (Time expired)

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Health and Family Services. Are you aware that Medibank Private is preparing an application for premium increases of $190 a year for top cover for a family? Has Medibank Private provided advice to the minister of this proposed price rise? In light of Dr Wooldridge's desire expressed on the 7.30 Report , to have the full benefit of the tax rebate passed on, will he be refusing the application of this government‐owned health insurer?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised by the Minister for Health and Family Services that the story in yesterday's Australian —which appears to be based on a rumour—that Medibank Private is to propose a premium increase was drawn to his attention. I am also informed that no such application had been received by his department and, of course, the timing of such premium changes would be commercially sensitive. The minister would consider proposed increases from any fund after consultation with the Prime Minister and Treasurer and, if the minister believed that they are justified having regard to the prudential financial management, he would not disallow them.

ANSWER.PARA: I am also advised that past increases for Medibank Private all occurred during the previous government. Medibank Private last increased its premiums in Victoria in November 1995, in all other states except Western Australia in May 1995 and in Western Australia in October 1993. Medibank Private is subject to the same price pressures as the industry generally, including the 39 per cent premium rise brought about by the former government's policies. It might well seek to increase its premiums to meet prudential solvency requirements and, if it does so, it will be treated on exactly the same basis as any other fund.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. The Prime Minister also made the following comments:

QUESTION.PARA: I think people in the industry ought to understand that we will be looking askance at applications for increases during the currency—
of the inquiry. Further, he said:

BREAK.PARA: I would be disappointed if there were any further applications during the time the inquiry is going on.
In light of—

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Madam President: this is an interesting little speech, but it is certainly not a supplementary question.
—On the point of order: I notice from the clock there is a considerable amount of time allowed for Senator Neal to complete her supplementary question.
—To ask her question.
—To ask her supplementary question and complete her supplementary question. I would ask you to rule her question in order.
—There is no point of order.

—In light of the Prime Minister's comments regarding his views about applications for increases in premiums during the time of the ongoing inquiry, if an application was received from Medibank Private for an increase, would the minister approve such an application?
—I do not have anything to add to the very detailed answer I gave Senator Neal before. She should go and study the Hansard .
—Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

DEBATE.TITLE: ABORIGINAL AND TORRES STRAIT ISLANDER COMMISSION AMENDMENT BILL 1996 [No. 2]

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Herron, Sen John
SPEECH.MINISTERIAL: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

TALKER.NAME: Senator HERRON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —During the debate on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Amendment Bill yesterday, Senator Margetts asked me several questions in respect of information that may have been provided on the ATSIC elections which I did not answer in full and which I now want to clarify.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Margetts asked whether there was any document available to senators which would provide information about exactly what people understood it was they were nominating for. When this question was posed, I was advised by officers of ATSIC that both the Australian Electoral Commission and ATSIC had distributed information about the ATSIC elections. Without having the relevant documents readily available for reference, my responses reflected the broad advice I was given on the content of those documents. That was that the Electoral Commission publications addressed issues regarding how and where to participate in the elections and the ATSIC publications addressed issues regarding the importance of participating in the elections.

I was not aware at the time that each publication included details of the number of councillors to be elected in each ward as applied at the time the publication was produced and distributed. Having now had the opportunity to examine the documents, I have since learnt that ATSIC and the Australian Electoral Commission have distributed documents which contained information on the number of regional councillors that would be elected based on the provisions of the act at the time the information was distributed. I undertook to provide the Senate with the documents once they had been delivered to me. In the circumstances that those same documents were tabled yesterday by Senator Margetts, this would not now seem necessary.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Faulkner, Sen John

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answers given by the Assistant Treasurer (Senator Short), to questions without notice asked by Senator Faulkner today, relating to the dental health program.

What we have had clearly exposed in this chamber over the last two days is a clear conflict between two ministers in this government—two inexperienced ministers in the government, two ministers who fumbled, bumbled and stumbled their way through on this issue, both desperately trying to protect their own ministerial interests.

BREAK.PARA: The trouble is, of course, it is not possible to do that because there is a clear conflict between them. On the one hand, the Minister for Social Security, Senator Newman, proudly proclaimed—and I quote her words during question time yesterday:

In fact, the funding runs until the end of December this year, so it is for 3½ years that we are honouring that commitment to that program. I am sorry if I misled the Senate in any way. It was quite inadvertent.

Senator Newman tried to make political capital out of the point that the Commonwealth dental health program was to end in 1997. The Assistant Treasurer, Senator Short, desperately tried to wheedle his way out of the hole in which he had dug himself because the Howard government has tried to extract savings from a non‐existent program.

That is the issue that has been exposed in question time today. Of course, they are embarrassed, because the Commonwealth dental health program represents nothing more than another broken promise of the Howard government. It has been exposed in here that this mob want their cake and want to eat it, too. Not only do they want to end the program, not only do they want to ensure that through the cessation of the Commonwealth dental health program any Commonwealth responsibility and support for the dental care of poor, disadvantaged and low income Australians ends, not only have they perpetrated a very cruel and mean budget measure, but they want to claim savings from a program that they say is non‐existent.

You cannot have it both ways. Senator Short and Senator Newman cannot both be right. If you go to the portfolio budget statements of the Health and Family Services portfolio, on page 149 we see part 7: `the cessation of the Commonwealth dental health program'. It outlines the savings over the forward estimates period: in 1996‐97, savings of $55.6 million; in 1997‐98, $112.8 million; in 1998‐99, $114.5 million; and in 1999‐2000, $116.5 million. They are the savings that are being claimed in the Health and Family Services portfolio.

It is absolutely simple. These are phantom savings. But if they are not phantom savings, Senator Newman has misled this chamber time and time again. Both these ministers cannot be right. One of these ministers is categorically wrong. One of these ministers has misled the Senate in a very heinous way. One of these ministers is about due right now to be carpeted by the Prime Minister, Mr Howard.

It is quite possible, given the performance of both these ministers, that they are in fact both wrong. There is a lot of explaining to do on this. You cannot claim phantom savings. If Senator Newman is right about the cessation of the Commonwealth dental health program, Senator Short is wrong. If Senator Short has any credibility at all, poor old Senator Newman has misled this Senate on three occasions. This is an incompetent team. This is the most ineffective ministerial team we have seen. This is a pathetic performance from a pathetic government. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Campbell, Sen Ian

TALKER.NAME: Senator CAMPBELL
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for the Environment and Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Sport, Territories and Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —Two Saturday nights ago, I went to a quiz night to raise funds for a local preschool. I say to honourable senators and anyone else who is listening to this debate, it was an interesting quiz night because it was actually multiple choice. It would have been a lot easier for the Leader of the Opposition in the Senate (Senator Faulkner) to get the answer right.

SPEECH.PARA: I would not have wanted Senator Faulkner on my table because he is the sort of guy who will look at the four alternatives and, because he cannot decide which one is right, say they are all wrong or one of the other ones might be wrong. So, Senator Faulkner, do not invite me to a fund raiser quiz night for the New South Wales Left faction of the ALP because I will not come to your table. I like winning; I do not like losing.

This guy was a minister in the former government, a minister in the defeated and disgraced Keating Labor government. He knows what forward estimates are about. This bloke actually knows a lot about forward estimates, a lot more than most of the people on the other side of this place. He talks about phantom savings. The Leader of the Opposition in the Senate is the phantom. He knows all about phantom savings.

In his own environment portfolio budget when he was the minister, this caring and sharing sort of latter day Green former minister for the environment, Senator Faulkner, identified savings in the environment and environment related programs of $55.7 million. There was a $55.7 million cut to the environment in the forward estimates when he was minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. I put it to you that Senator Campbell has canvassed a range of issues, including quiz nights and all sorts of interesting things. I know that you ruled yesterday during taking note of answers to questions that it is reasonable for senators to range broadly across issues, but I put it to you that, on this particular occasion, it would not be unreasonable to call the senator to order to at least make some attempt to make his comments relevant to the motion that is before the chair.

—On the point of order: rulings in the past on these matters have been that these debates are wide ranging. Secondly, I was, Mr Deputy President, as you will know because you are listening carefully to the debate, speaking specifically about forward estimates, which is what the debate is about, and the Senate Leader of the Opposition's own experience in relation to forward estimates and savings. That is how my argument is developing.
—While the debate may be far ranging, it should be initially related to the answer that the Senate is discussing.

—I will continue to talk about the forward estimates and the long experience of the Senate Leader of the Opposition in forward estimates. This is the man who came to the Australian public and said that in the environment portfolio, this crucial issue, he actually found $55.7 million worth of savings against a relatively meagre budget in the forward estimates for 1996‐97.

BREAK.PARA: This previous minister also has experience in the sports budget. He has the great honour of going down in the history of Australia of having reduced the sports budget in the forward estimates by $34 million, a one-third reduction in the sports budget in an Olympic year—a brilliant performance. The previous minister and now Leader of the Opposition in the Senate seeks not to understand.

Getting back to the quiz night, he cannot understand because he will not hear or he does not know. The fact of the matter is the dental program did have provision made in the forward estimates for a number of the outyears. The previous government had not made a decision to continue the dental health program by the time they so ignominiously lost the election in March.

They cared so little about the dental health program in November and December and in all of the cabinet and ministry discussions leading up to then that they chose not to make a decision about the dental health program. Six months down the track, we get this absolute false indignation. They are using language like heinous and disgraceful and disgusting. They are saying things like, `Poor people can't get their health treatments and the states won't pick up the tab.' They care now, six months later, but when they were in government in February, March, April, May, June, July and August, right through to Christmas last year, right through to March, as a cabinet and as a Labor government, they chose not to make a decision and not to replace the funding for the dental health program.

The fiscal reality, the reality that Senator Short had to deal with and dealt with—as did Senator Newman in an absolutely consistent way—was that provision had been made in the forward estimates. The previous cabinet had not made a decision, but there was provision in the forward estimates. This cabinet made a decision. They have made a lot of very good decisions. Where the previous government failed to make decisions, we actually took some hard decisions.

We took some hard decisions that will impact upon the services that a number of people across this country receive. We all know the reason is that we were left with something like an $8 billion come $10 billion black hole—we were spending $8 billion to $10 billion or more a year as a nation than we could afford. We were tabbing it up on the bankcard to the tune of $100 billion a year ensuring that future generations of Australians would have to pay higher interest rates and higher taxes than they need to so we made these decisions.

The reality, the nub, of this issue is that those forward estimates had been made. They were in the budget. We took a decision and they are savings against those outyear forward estimates. They are real savings. What Senator Short has said is absolutely accurate. What Senator Newman has said is absolutely accurate. There is no discrepancy or inconsistency in what they say.

The only discrepancy and inconsistency is between how the former Minister for the Environment, Sport and Territories behaved when he was in government and how he talks now he is in opposition. He is talking about phantom savings. He is the expert when it comes to phantom savings. That is why he should now be called the phantom Leader of the Opposition in the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sherry, Sen Nick

TALKER.NAME: Senator SHERRY
TALKER.ROLE: Deputy Leader of the Opposition in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —We have just heard from Senator Campbell—the new assistant Treasurer, one assumes, because Senator Short and Senator Newman fled the chamber when we started to highlight the amazing discrepancy in the budget papers. Aside from wandering around sports nights, quiz nights, the Left of the Labor Party and sports funding, after some three or four minutes Senator Campbell finally started to justify why the new government had abolished the Commonwealth dental program. The Commonwealth dental program, as everyone is aware, particularly the 55,000 people in my home state of Tasmania who have been beneficiaries of this program, is a very effective program. He attempted to justify that by talking about the government's approach to the budget.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Campbell failed to mention the fact that on the one hand Senator Newman has come in here and said publicly—indeed, I have seen letters she has written to people explaining why the program had to be abolished—that Labor was not going to fund the program past its four‐year period. That was her initial explanation. She then came in here on the second day and corrected herself, saying that it was due for completion at the end of this year, in December. That is her claim; that is her justification for the apparent abolition of the program.

Then the opposition, on checking the budget statements, notes on page 395 that it is listed as a saving not just up until the end of this calendar year but its effect on outlays—this is for a program that, according to Senator Newman, does not exist after this year—is a saving of $112.8 million in 1997-98, $114.5 million from 1998 to 1999 and $116.5 to the year 2000. That is a total of $343 million from a program that, according to Senator Newman, does not exist.

The new government makes a great deal about its so-called charter of budget honesty. It is an amazing approach to budget honesty to claim that you found the saving of $343 million from nothing. According to Senator Newman and Senator Short, who continues to assure us that Senator Newman is absolutely correct, this dental program apparently was not going to run past December this year but the new government has manufactured savings of $343 million over the next three years. That is an interesting practice of accounting procedures. If these are the new sort of accounting procedures that are to be practised under the so-called charter of budget honesty, absolutely no-one who was reputably audited in this country would get away with that sort of approach of claiming that there is a program that does not exist, and that is why it is not continuing, and saying you can save $343 million.

What was Senator Short's response? He assured us that this new creative accounting is absolutely spot on and there isn't a problem. They have found $343 million in savings for a program that does not exist. Senator Short is the Assistant Treasurer. He will front up to estimates next week. It will be a long haul for him if thinks he can give this sort of explanation to the Labor opposition—this sort of creative accounting. Senator Short will have to front up next week and explain how you can manufacture $343 million in savings from a program that does not exist.

It goes to the heart of the integrity of Senator Short and Senator Newman to attempt to assure this Senate and the Australian people that they can manufacture $343 million from nothing. This is just a continuation, particularly from Senator Short, of a series of misleading answers to specific questions, or non-answers in Senator Short's case and in Senator Newman's case. They will not answer questions. When they do answer questions, they contradict each other. When they do go to industry associations and conferences, they do not answer questions. When they do attempt an answer to a question, they give the wrong answer.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz, Sen Eric

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to join in this debate. One of the very interesting things is that there has been no renunciation from the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Faulkner) and the Deputy Leader of the Opposition (Senator Sherry) of the assertion that they would have abolished this program. Here they are trying to whip up hysteria within the public about what we are allegedly doing when they are not denying the fact that if by some strange quirk of fate they were given another go on 2 March 1996 they would have abolished the same program.

SPEECH.PARA: How can you come into this place and expect to be taken seriously? Gary Gray got it right: the people of Australia thought you stunk when it came to the question of credibility on making promises. You are trying to whip up this hysteria within the community when you yourselves would have abolished it. You are trying to hide from that fact and trying to pick at aspects of the budget. What they are doing day after day is repeating the same falsehood, setting up the same straw men and knocking them over. They have to learn that mere repetition does not fill the void occasioned by the absence of merit. There is no merit in your argument. Just by repeating it time and time again does not provide merit to your argument.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are not getting an answer.

—Senator Sherry says that he is not getting an answer. I would have thought you would have got answers, but the problem is that you do not like the answers you are getting. The people of Australia are saying to you overwhelmingly that this budget has been a great success. They like this budget. You know it and I know it. So you go running around the community saying, `How can we undermine the credibility of the budget?' You repeat these assertions that have no basis in fact, hoping that if you repeat it often enough somehow the population may believe you.
