SPEECH.PARA: Through you, Mr Deputy President, Senator Sherry has cried wolf too often in his very short term as Deputy Leader of the Opposition. Before the budget he was running around carrying on and trying to scare the community about alleged changes to superannuation, which never occurred.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the $500 million new tax?

—Your credibility is nil—it is gone. You have no credibility whatsoever. Having failed on superannuation, Senator Sherry will not be deterred. He will not be deterred because he failed on that front: he will try to do it again with the Commonwealth dental health program. When he fails on that he will undoubtedly try some other measure and he will fail on that as well.

SPEECH.PARA: The situation is that this budget is a very good budget. The program that the Labor opposition today have picked upon is a program that they themselves would have abolished. Listen to that: there is no denial from the Labor Party. Their silence is acknowledging the truth. The previous government had taken no decision on future funding for the program beyond 30 June 1997. There is no denial of that in any shape or form.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where do your savings come from?

—When you, Senator Sherry, announced the program with great fanfare, did you ever tell them that you were not going to continue the program in the unlikely event that you were re‐elected? Absolutely not.
—On a point of order: in responding to that question, Senator Abetz has opposed—
—You have a point of order; you cannot ask a question.
—We intended to continue the program.
—Do you have a point of order?
—It is a point of order, because—
—No, it is not.
—Under the Senate rules, when a senator poses a question like that to a senator we can respond.
—You know that is not a point of order.

—Senator Sherry's abuse of the procedures of this place is reaching a stage where, I would suggest, he ought be taken aside privately and spoken to so that people can get on with their speeches and their contributions without his silly interruptions. Each time it starts hurting Senator Sherry, he gets up on a frivolous point of order to try to disrupt the flow. But the people of Australia can see through that sort of sham, Senator Sherry, and they will not accept your tactics any more.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise also to speak on the motion to take note of Senator Short's answer. Despite some of the frivolous remarks and the matters raised by members of the government in this debate, it is of great concern to the many members of the community who have taken advantage of the dental health scheme funded by the federal government to date that the government has seen fit to abolish the program in this budget.

SPEECH.PARA: For some time we have been trying to elicit some real information about what the effect of these budget cuts might be but, despite some of the personal abuse and irrelevant matters raised by those on the other side—both by Senator Newman and by Senator Short—we have been unable to elicit the information that the community would like to know, that is, what the effect of abolishing the dental health scheme will be.

I originally asked Senator Newman what the effect of abolishing the program would be. She responded only by saying that the former Keating government introduced a four‐year program which was to come to an end this coming year. She then added a little bit to it the next day in response to a question from Senator Faulkner, when she said:
In fact, the funding runs until the end of December this year, so it is for 3½ years that we are honouring that commitment to that program.

The difficulty is that she has failed to appreciate that the people who have relied on this program to date are really concerned about what it is going to mean for them. What it means for the health card holders and the pensioners is that they will return to the situation that they were in before this Commonwealth program was introduced.

This program was introduced because access to dental care for those who are not very well off was very poor. People in the community who were less well off only had access to dental care when they were in severe pain or when they were having their teeth extracted. The federal Labor government, which believed in equity in access to health, thought it was appropriate that these funds should be provided. In fact, these funds were successful in that they reduced the waiting list from two years or more to, in most cases, about one month. That meant that health card holders and pensioners had real access to care: not just emergency care and not just extractions. The abuse of those people—those people who are less well off and who really require our assistance—has been exacerbated by the way this matter has been dealt with here in the Senate.

Despite the fact that Senator Newman's only defence was that the program was to conclude at the end of the next financial year, the government has sought to make hay on the deprivations of that group of people by claiming to have made budget savings. They have claimed budget savings in years—according to Senator Newman—when the dental health program did not exist. It started off with savings of $112 million and $114 million and then, in the year 1999, $116.5 million.

Not only has Senator Newman failed to provide for and to protect the people in our community who need assistance, not only has she deprived them of a service that they desperately need, not only has she relegated them to having no real dental care and to having extraction care rather than dental health treatment, she has also jumped on top of them and sought to gain political advantage by claiming these budget savings from them. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray, Sen Robert

TALK.START.PARA: —On the same matter, Mr Deputy President: the sanctity of the forward estimates has always been something that the Department of Finance has protected with immense zeal over the years, always to the regret of existing governments, I have to say. The moment you have a glimmer of an idea of expenditure, and you express it in a formalised way, they put that in the forward estimates. Therefore, the treatment of forward estimates documents has to be done very seriously.

SPEECH.PARA: In this matter, I suspect Senator Newman's view was correct up to a point: that limited programs are carried in the forward estimates. Unless and until the government makes another decision that they are not continued in forward estimates, it is always an option of government to put them in forward estimates the moment they make a formal decision. What we have here is a forward estimates program, going over this financial year and the following three years, that has savings from a program that was not previously in the forward estimates.

It was absolutely interesting today that the times when Senator Short was invited to answer this question he failed to answer the question. He always stays around for the noting of answers so he can debate these matters, but today he disappeared at the rate of knots. The reason why is that he cannot answer it. He would have been much better coming in here and saying, `I don't understand why the forward estimates show a saving of over $340 million in the outyears when my colleague has said that it was due to end.' He should have said, `I will go back to the Department of Finance and bring in an explanation here.'

All he could do was refer to Senator Newman's answer each time he was challenged and say that it was correct. He brought no intellectual ability or analysis or anything else to the answer other than the weak response, `Surely Senator Newman is right, and I agree with her.' Where is the intellectual rigour of the Assistant Treasurer? He has come into this chamber in the six months of this government and has failed to understand and comprehend questions. All he can do is go on with bumptious rhetoric, inept polemics and abuse based on his MPI speeches of the last 10 or 12 years. I cannot believe that this person, who is an ex‐Treasury official, has no grasp whatsoever of portfolio matters.

I see my Victorian colleague sitting over there. He was quite an energetic shadow minister but he is not in the ministry. How did he miss the ministry when Senator Short occupies that waste of space? It is absolutely incredible. I wonder what the Kemp brothers did wrong, I really do. Even Senator Kemp over there, from his previous incarnations, would understand the concept of outyears in the estimates, but Senator Short has no grasp of them. I say this: he can run today, but at the estimates next Wednesday he is going to have to answer those questions.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee

That the time for the presentation of the report of the Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade References Committee on the proposed abolition of the Development Import Finance Facility (DIFF) scheme be extended to 15 October 1996.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp, Sen Rod

TALKER.NAME: Senator KEMP
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Security)

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to the report of the Economics References Committee entitled CSIRO: the case for revitalisation: administration and funding of rural research . I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
THE GOVERNMENT'S RESPONSE TO CSIRO: THE CASE FOR REVITALISATION
A report by the Senate Economics References Committee
December 1994
STRUCTURE AND ADMINISTRATION OF CSIRO

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that the Board of CSIRO must take a stronger role in the leadership of CSIRO. Accordingly, the Board's current review of the management structure should, as a priority:
1.1 restructure the CSIRO to reduce the layers of management, including the need to modify or eliminate the Institute structure;
1.2 introduce a `business line' model of structure based on having direct communication with the workplaces within CSIRO;
1.3 institute a similar mechanism for staff appointments to the CSIRO Board as applies under the Australian Broadcasting Corporation Act 1983;

1.4 set up a new administrative structure around the Chief Executive Officer to replace the Executive Committee based on the Board leaving internal administrative matters to the Chief Executive Officer and such new structure;
1.5 introduce a world best practice program of management across the Organisation, including industrial participation;
1.6 clarify its formal reporting mechanism to the Minister; and
1.7 as part of this process of streamlining of administration, report on how excessive accountability can be reduced.

SPEECH.PARA: The CSIRO Board undertook an Evaluation of Management and Structure during 1995. The recommendations of the Senate Committee and views from customers and stakeholders including staff members were considered. A new mode of working more flexibly and collaboratively, and with better customer focus, is now being implemented.

The Divisions will remain the key operational units in CSIRO. They will be grouped strategically into Sectors, such as food processing or wool and textiles, to focus on the needs of specific research users; and into Alliances, such as agribusiness, which will facilitate CSIRO's relationship with a group of sectors. The Institute structure remained in place alongside the new structure, during the transition period, to 30 June 1996. The Government will consider any recommendations made by the CSIRO Board as a consequence of the evaluation, which bear on its management and structure as specified in the Act.
In terms of the specific recommendations the Government's response is, in the order that they were made:
1.1 Agreed: CSIRO has been restructured to reduce layers of management, including eliminating the layer of administration associated with the Institutes.

1.2 Agreed: The new structure and arrangements enable direct communication with workplaces through participation of all Deputy Chief Executives in Board meetings and all Chiefs of Divisions in Executive Forums, so that they can inform and involve their staff in consideration of major issues
1.3 Rejected: The new arrangements involve senior staff directly in the discussions of the Board and provide for improved communication with staff in Divisions.
1.4 Agreed. The Chief Executive and Deputy Chief Executives deal with corporate administrative matters in the new structure.

1.5 Agreed. In addition to the new arrangements for better communication with workplaces, CSIRO has a Consultative Council which regularly considers, and reports to the Board on, matters affecting or of general interest to CSIRO staff members. The Council comprises persons nominated by the Board to represent the management of CSIRO and representatives of organisations of staff members. The Consultative Council through its Human Resource Policy Subcommittee has formed a Working Party on Industrial Participation and Best Practice. The Working Group has examined Industrial Participation across the Organisation and in other organisations and recently prepared a draft document to replace the 1989 Industrial Participation Plan.

1.6 Agreed. Under the Act it is the responsibility of the Board to ensure the proper and efficient performance of CSIRO's functions; to determine the policy of the Organisation; and to give direction to the Chief Executive. The affairs of the Organisation are to be conducted by the Chief Executive in accordance with the Act and with any policies determined, and any direction given, by the Board. Both the Chairman of the Board and the Chief Executive, as a member of the Board, report to the Minister. In the current Triennium Funding Agreement, CSIRO agreed to report to the Minister, in its annual report, on performance, including the use of performance indicators.

1.7 Agreed. The new arrangements for management and structure place responsibility and accountability more directly with the research Divisions; the layer of administration and detailed accountability associated with the Institutes has been removed.

PARA.EMPHASIS: If the CSIRO Board is unable to address the foregoing reforms in its report, the Minister for Industry, Science and Technology should consider establishing an independent assessment of the above proposals.

SPEECH.PARA: Noted. No further action is warranted by the Government.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that CSIRO reinstate the high priority ranking of rural research and ensure that the share of appropriation funding of rural research is increased commensurate with that ranking.

SPEECH.PARA: Noted. Priorities for the allocation of research expenditure within CSIRO are the responsibility of the CSIRO Board. The Government anticipates that the Board will continue to give rural research and development a high priority. The Government considers that building on Australia's existing comparative advantages is an important part of CSIRO's role. In highlighting rural research, the Government notes the importance of the Organisation's responsibilities to other key sectors of the economy such as manufacturing, minerals and energy, information and communications, and the environment.
Over the five years to 1994‐95 CSIRO consistently invested approximately half of its total funding in rural‐related research, which includes both agribusiness and environmental aspects.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that the Government commission an independent study of the system of rural levies, which would focus on:
. how they are applied to research in both on‐farm and post‐farm sectors, and;
. how the system could be expanded to include industries not currently contributing to, but benefiting from, CSIRO research.

SPEECH.PARA: Noted. The Government considers the May 1995 Industry Commission report on Research and Development negates the need for a further study of the system of rural levies. The inquiry consti tutes a comprehensive assessment of the issues raised in the Senate report in 1994.

Noted. CSIRO has a policy of rationalising sites to reduce overheads and thereby free funds for research. To ensure the efficient performance of the Organisation, the CSIRO Board must be allowed to consider the restructuring of its Institutes and the disposal of assets, when appropriate. This should be done in consultation with stakeholders and staff, bearing in mind what is best for the research effort and funding imperatives. Specific comments follow.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that the Division of Wool Technology postpone any decision to amalgamate its two laboratories until the question of the direction of wool industry funding becomes more clear.

SPEECH.PARA: Rejected. CSIRO conducted an extensive review into its delivery of wool related research entitled `Strategic Review of Future Directions for CSIRO's research for the Wool Industry'. This review, comprising external members, recommended the relocation of the Division of Wool Technology's Ryde Laboratory to Geelong. This relocation was endorsed by the Boards of CSIRO and the International Wool Secretariat and is being implemented.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that CSIRO retain the site and infrastructure at Long Pocket. The Committee further recommends that CSIRO direct appropriation funding towards the half‐life refurbishment of facilities at Long Pocket within the next three years.

SPEECH.PARA: Noted. The CSIRO site and infrastructure at Long Pocket have been retained and funds identified for the half‐life refurbishment of the facilities. CSIRO is currently working with Queensland Government bodies to examine the possibility of co‐locating research providers in a Queensland Applied Science Precinct, possibly on the Long Pocket site.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The committee believes that Longford and Arding should be retained by CSIRO for continued field research and recommends that the CSIRO Board immediately make public its decision not to sell either property.

SPEECH.PARA: Noted. A Joint Management/CPSU Working Group has reviewed the financial position of the Division of Animal Production and has recommended the rationalisation of the Division's infrastructure. The aim of the restructure is to restore the financial viability of the Division.

On 1 July 1996, the CSIRO Chief Executive after consultation with staff, stakeholders and the CSIRO Board announced the decision to relinquish for sale the Arding and Longford field stations near Armidale and to sell surplus land at Prospect. The future of the Chiswick Research Centre at Armidale will depend on the Organisation's financial position and will be reviewed after one year for signs of a recovery in grower research funds or other external earnings, or the Organisation's ability to attract a suitable tenant to share the laboratory and infrastructure costs. The decision to retain Chiswick recognised local concerns, the concerns of customers, and the availability of a modern laboratory building to house staff. It will allow up to 25 staff to remain in Armidale. Two projects from Armidale will be relocated to Prospect (NSW) and Floreat Park (WA) (Parasitology and Controlled Release of Veterinary Pharmaceuticals, respectively).
Further, the Committee recommends that the Commonwealth Government provide adequate Landcare funding to allow vegetation rehabilitation work to be carried out on Longford and Arding.
Noted. See comments above in response to Recommendation 7.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee believes that Yalanbee should be retained by CSIRO for continued field research and recommends that the CSIRO Board immediately make public its decision not to sell all or part of the property.

SPEECH.PARA: Noted. A small part of Yalanbee is surplus to current and projected future requirements and is in the process of being sold; the rest will be retained.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that CSIRO, in collaboration with industry and Government, formulate a package of mechanisms to buffer research programs from wide fluctuations in rural industry research levies.

SPEECH.PARA: Noted. CSIRO needs to and does have regard to the characteristics of the industries for which it provides services, including whether those industries are subjected to cyclical influences. It is for CSIRO, in collaboration with the industries concerned, to manage its research programs. To this end, CSIRO is working with the rural R&D corporations to foster a higher degree of stability in rural‐related research planning, as demonstrated in the strategic alliance CSIRO is presently developing with the International Wool Secretariat.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that the CSIRO Board conduct an assessment of the way in which the 30% funding target has altered the ratio of fundamental to applied research.

SPEECH.PARA: Noted. This issue was addressed by the Australian Science and Technology Council (ASTEC) as part of the `Review of the Operations of the External Earnings Targets for Commonwealth Government Research Agencies', tabled in Parliament in

December 1993. The Review found "there was no evidence of a dramatic shift in the balance of strategic basic and applied research in CSIRO at the organisational level that can be attributed to the external earnings target".

The Government will be less prescriptive in relation to external funding targets. It supports contract work with industry towards applied solutions provided such work complements CSIRO's strategic research programs.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee believes that, in some sections of CSIRO, the demands of obtaining external funds are placing considerable stresses on scientists and that this is hampering their research. The Committee recommends that CSIRO address this problem by developing multi‐disciplinary teams within Divisions to assist with obtaining and retaining external funds. The Committee further recommends that management play a stronger role in external fund raising.

SPEECH.PARA: Noted. CSIRO management recognises that the demands of obtaining external funds may cause some stress to staff but also that such interactions with research users are a vital part of orienting research towards actual needs. When evaluating this aspect of performance CSIRO management takes into account factors such as the state of relevant industries and the stage of particular research programs. The new management and structural arrangements facilitate the development of multi‐disciplinary teams and the effectiveness of participation by senior staff in developing relations with research users and raising funds.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that the CSIRO Board commission a study to determine further ways in which CSIRO can limit its legal liability arising from commercialisation of its research.

SPEECH.PARA: Noted. CSIRO has taken significant steps to improve its overall commercial performance and minimise its commercial exposure. The Organisation aims to involve commercial partners as early as possible in research and development so that commercial risk is carried appropriately by those partners. The CSIRO Commercial Practice Manual has been developed to provide guidance to staff on a broad range of commercial issues. Confidential reports on current and potential areas of dispute are provided regularly to the Board and to the Minister.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that CSIRO clarify its respective roles in `commercialisation' and `development' and make its policy in these areas clear to its staff and its stakeholders.

SPEECH.PARA: Noted. The Government sees the Organisation's role as primarily in strategic research, working with Government and industry to ensure the maximum contribution of science and technology to improving economic and social outcomes. Contract work with industry towards applied solutions will be supported provided such work is consistent with CSIRO's strategic research programs. CSIRO should encourage or facilitate the application or utilisation of the results of its or any other scientific research.

The roles and responsibilities of staff involved in commercial activities are defined in the CSIRO Commercial Practice Manual . Whilst this Manual is regarded as commercial‐in‐confidence, CSIRO is preparing a complementary document on doing business with CSIRO for distribution to customers and stakeholders.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that CSIRO examine ways in which its research results can be transferred to the rural sector, given the demise of State extension services.

SPEECH.PARA: Noted. CSIRO has a primary responsibility to encourage or facilitate the application of the results of its research but does not have its own extension service. It operates through and with the established extension agencies. The links between the people involved in extension activities and researchers are extremely important and CSIRO is committed to fostering such relationships. CSIRO is increasingly looking to work with private sector extension agencies, R&D Corporations and with landholder groups, including Landcare, in information delivery, as well as promoting a more collaborative and iterative relationship with State Departments. Nevertheless, technology transfer is often much more expensive than research and development, and this caps CSIRO's activities in this area.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that the role and responsibility of CSIRO `communicators' be more clearly defined and that the CSIRO ensure that people employed as communicators either have the necessary skills to do the task or that they receive appropriate training for the position.
The Committee recommends that CSIRO ensure that those scientists who are required to communicate regularly with stakeholders and the public have the necessary skills to do so.
The Committee recommends that CSIRO review the procedures used for approval of media releases with a view to increasing the speed with which they can be issued.

SPEECH.PARA: Noted. The Government considers that in CSIRO, as in any well managed organisation, training and procedures should be in place to ensure that information presented to the media is accurate and fully representative of the Organisation's policy.

While such standards for media releases must be maintained, the Organisation has undertaken a review of its communication skills and implemented a number of reforms which will enhance the timeliness and effectiveness of all communication activities. CSIRO has for some time had communication training in its Leadership Development and Research Management Programs. Further training courses are being organised and networks of Divisional and Corporate professional communicators established.

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that the CSIRO Board address the problems of employment insecurity, poor conditions of employment, low career status, excessive accountability, stresses of fund‐raising, ineffective industrial participation and low morale among its research staff as a matter of urgency.

SPEECH.PARA: Noted. CSIRO offers employment conditions which are competitive internationally. The attractiveness of the Organisation as a place to work is demonstrated by its ability to attract and retain staff. Some of the problems raised by the Committee relate to issues effecting public sector R&D throughout Australia and the provision of adequate, long term funding. Nevertheless, the working conditions and general well‐being of all CSIRO staff is a major concern of the CSIRO Board and the Chief Executive.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to the report of the parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities on the annual reports of the Australian Securities Commission and other bodies 1993-94. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
Mr Derrick Abbott
Secretary
Parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities
Parliament House
CANBERRA A.C.T. 2600
Dear Mr Abbott

I refer to the Report on the Annual Reports of the Australian Securities Commission and other bodies: 1993‐1994 which Mr Smith tabled on behalf of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities on 23 October 1995.
In its Report the Committee recommended that:

1. when statutory members or senior staff of the ASC are recruited from private enterprise they be required to make a full, confidential disclosure of any arrangements with previous or future employers;
2. the Attorney‐General give consideration to applying the same requirement to other relevant government departments and agencies.

Changes made to the Administrative Arrangements Order following the Federal election have had the effect of transferring responsibility for the Australian Securities Commission and the Corporations Law to the Treasurer.

I am able to report that the issue addressed by the Committee's first recommendation is one that is already under consideration by the Government. The Ministerial Council for Corporations had before it, at its meeting in Darwin on 29 March 1996, draft provisions which would, among other things, expand the provisions of section 123 of the Australian Securities Commission Act 1989 (the ASC Act) to require disclosure of:
. any agreement, understanding or expectation, entered into or arising at any time before or during the term of the member's appointment, that the member will, when he ceases to be a member—

PARA.TAB: (a) resume a previous business relationship (whether or not that relationship existed immediately prior to the member's appointment); or
(b) enter into a new business relationship; and

SPEECH.PARA: . any severance arrangement or ongoing financial arrangement that takes account of such an agreement, understanding or expectation.

Members of the Ministerial Council for Corporations generally favoured the introduction of such provisions which will be considered by the Government in the context of the next miscellaneous corporate law amendments bill.
These proposed amendments would, in my view, completely address the first recommendation made by the Parliamentary Committee in so far as that recommendation relates to members of the Commission.

The Committee's first recommendation also relates to the senior staff of the ASC. The ASC is currently reviewing the adequacy of disclosure requirements imposed on its staff. Officers of my Department have brought to the attention of the ASC the non‐legislative system for the registration of interests of senior staff of statutory authorities introduced in 1984. I note that some staff of the Commission are appointed under the Public Service Act 1922 while some (including the Regional Commissioners) are employed under contract.

When the Commission has completed its review, Commonwealth officers will prepare a paper for the consideration of the Ministerial Council on the extent and adequacy of the disclosure of interest provisions imposed on staff of the ASC, as requested by the Council in July 1994. In this context I shall specifically ask my officers to examine whether any additional requirements are needed to ensure that senior ASC staff make the additional disclosure outlined in the Committee's first recommendation, keeping in mind the special position of the ASC and the desirability of uniform disclosure requirements across the public service.
As to the second recommendation, there are non‐legislative systems for the registration of private interests of statutory officeholders and officials.

The Prime Minister will advise Ministers that officeholders and officials completing statements should include in them information about any arrangements regarding future employment or business relationships if those arrangements might give rise to conflicts of interests. Ministers will be asked to bring this advice to the attention of departments and agencies as appropriate. They will also be advised of the amendments to the ASC Act now under consideration, since consideration of similar amendments may be appropriate in some other cases.
Yours sincerely
BRIAN GIBSON

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to the report of the parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities on derivatives. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
REPORT ON DERIVATIVES

PARA.EMPHASIS: GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE REPORT BY THE PARLIAMENTARY JOINT COMMITTEE ON CORPORATIONS AND SECURITIES

SPEECH.PARA: 1. The Parliamentary Joint Committee on Corporations and Securities is established under Part 14 of the Australian Securities Commission Act 1989 . Its duties are set out in section 243 of the Act. They include the duty to inquire into, and report to both Houses of Parliament on, activities of the Australian Securities Commission or the operation of any national scheme law and to report on matters that appear in each annual report prepared by a body established under the Australian Securities Commission Act and to which the Parliament's attention should be directed.

2. In November 1994 members of the Committee visited the Sydney Futures Exchange (SFE). After the visit the Committee decided, pursuant to its power to inquire into the operation of national companies and securities scheme laws, to consider issues relating to the regulation of derivatives markets.

3. In March, 1995 the Committee held public hearings with the SFE, the Australian Stock Exchange (ASX), the Australian Securities Commission (ASC) and the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee on the subject of the regulation of derivatives.
4. The collapse of Barings Bank in February 1995 gave additional focus to the Committee's hearings.
5. The Committee's "Report on Derivatives" was tabled in Parliament on 20 November 1995.

6. In the Report the Committee was mindful of the fact that the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee is currently conducting an in‐depth review of the regulation of derivatives both on and off exchange and that aspects of derivatives regula tion are currently being or have recently been considered by other bodies in Australia and overseas. It noted in particular:

. two leading reports issued after the Barings collapse (the report of the Board of Banking Supervision of the Bank of England and the Price Waterhouse report commissioned by the Singapore Ministry of Finance);
. the Windsor Declaration on measures to strengthen global supervision of future markets;
. cooperative initiatives of the Futures Industry Association (US) to coordinate an international review of safeguards and control mechanisms in the futures industry;
. the recommendations of the Futures Industry Association Global Task Force on Financial Integrity;
. the review of procedures being undertaken by the SFE in light of the Barings collapse;
. the release of exposure draft ED 65 on financial instruments; and
. the report of the House of Representatives Banking, Finance and Public Administration Committee on the role of the Reserve Bank in the supervision of derivatives trading by banks.
7. The Committee also made the following recommendation:

PARA.EMPHASIS: The Committee recommends that the ASC include in its Annual Reports a synopsis of the types and volumes of derivatives being traded in Australia and recent regulatory developments.

SPEECH.PARA: 8. The Government supports the Committee's recommendation. It appreciates that the Committee sees a need for a Government authority to report on this issue, given the concerns expressed in the Committee's report.

9. The publication of a synopsis of the types and volumes of derivatives being traded, together with details of regulatory developments, could provide an overview of the operations of derivatives markets for the benefit of members of Parliament, regulators, market participants and other persons who have a need for information in this area. The ASC has itself drawn attention to the importance of having available comprehensive and up to date information on the operation of derivatives markets in general.

10. At the same time, it must be appreciated that the Corporations Law currently confers only a limited jurisdiction over derivatives on the ASC. The ASC regulates derivatives only if they fall within the current definition of "securities" or "futures contract" in the Corporations Law. The great majority of products traded on over the counter ('OTC') markets, namely interest rate and foreign currency contracts, are specifically excluded from the Corporations Law and regulation by the ASC. Under current law the ASC could not require bodies which deal in products not subject to the Corporations Law to provide information about the trading of such products. If information about only those derivatives currently classified as "securities" or "futures contracts" and regulated by the ASC were to be included in the ASC's Annual Report, it may present a misleading picture of the Australian derivatives market. As the Committee notes, a comprehensive review of the regulation of derivatives in Australia, including the extent of the ASC's jurisdiction over derivatives trading, is currently being undertaken by the Companies and Securities Advisory Committee.

11. The Government also notes that information about the types and volumes of derivatives being traded in Australia is currently compiled and published by a number of bodies including industry associations such as the Australian Financial Markets Association (AFMA) and self regulatory organisations such as the SFE and the ASX. The latter trade derivative products on their exchanges and publish data on such trading on a regular basis.

12. AFMA has conducted an annual statistical survey of derivatives markets since 1993. Its 1995 Report provides comprehensive data on all sections of Australian wholesale financial markets and includes data on exchange traded markets.

13. The Reserve Bank also publishes details of the types and volumes of derivatives being traded in Australia. It has for some years published information about banks' involvement in derivatives markets. Data on the total off‐balance sheet business of all banks are presented quarterly in the Reserve Bank Bulletin . It proposes to extend its data collections in association with the proposed introduction of a capital charge to cover banks' exposure to market risk. In 1995 the Reserve Bank conducted a survey of foreign exchange and derivatives markets in Australia (covering both bank and non‐bank institutions) as part of a global survey co‐ordinated by the Bank of International Settlements The results were published in December, 1995.

14. In addition, the Insurance and Superannuation Commission has instituted a new Quarterly Survey of Superannuation which will collect information on direct derivatives usage by the largest 1,100 superannuation funds (essentially those with assets in excess of $10 million). The extent to which superannuation funds are indirectly exposed to derivatives will be highlighted from mid 1996 through ABS quarterly asset surveys of life insurance statutory funds and investment managers.

15. The Government does not wish to discourage the compilation and dissemination of such information by these bodies. They are well placed to collect and disseminate data for the financial sectors they represent. The statistical and survey data currently available allows considerable scope for understanding the types and volumes of derivatives transactions within Australia. Nor does the Government wish to duplicate the efforts of these bodies.

16. Nevertheless the Government considers that the policy objective underlying the Committee's recommendation can be met by the ASC reporting on the extent of derivatives trading in Australia in its future Annual Reports, as well as on regulatory developments in relation to the trading of derivatives.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the government's response to the report of the Joint Statutory Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings on radio and television broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings. I seek leave to incorporate the document in Hansard and to move a motion in relation to the document.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows—
GOVERNMENT RESPONSE TO THE JOINT COMMITTEE REPORT ON THE BROADCASTING OF PARLIAMENTARY PROCEEDINGS

The Government supports the majority of the recommendations of the Joint Committee's report. The Government gives in principle support to the enactment of new legislation to cover the arrangements for broadcasting parliamentary proceedings. However, it will consider the recommendation for amending the Parliamentary Proceedings Broadcasting Act 1946 in the context of drafting priorities.

The Government does not support the recommendation to provide absolute privilege only to compulsory radio broadcasts which are required by the Act. The Government considers that absolute privilege should also be extended to non‐compulsory live broadcasts where broadcasters are unable to exercise control over the content of the broadcast and therefore lack protection against possible court action for contempt. Without such an extension the broadcasters may be reluctant to broadcast wider parliamentary proceedings such as committee hearings.
The Government supports the extension of the functions of the Joint Committee as recommended by the Committee.
The Government notes that the report makes a number of recommendations which impinge on areas that are the responsibility of the ABC. Issues of programming (other than those relating to com‐
pulsory broadcasts) are a matter for the ABC. The Government wishes to acknowledge the significant contribution which the ABC has made to broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings over many years.
The Government supports continued use by ABC of the Parliamentary Broadcasting Network (PBN). It also supports recommendations aimed at increasing awareness of Parliament and its proceedings.

The Government notes the recommendation that access to compulsory radio broadcasts of parliamentary proceedings be made progressively available to all Australians. This will be considered in the context of future budgets.

ROW.ENTRY: 1. The Parliamentary Proceedings Broadcasting Act 1946 be amended to bring the proceedings of the Main Committee of the House of Representatives and of parliamentary committees within the Act to allow the Joint Committee to make recommendations or determinations as to how these activities are to be broadcast.
2. The Parliamentary Procedures Broadcasting Act 1946 be amended to cover the radio and television broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings generally.
3. The Parliamentary Proceedings Broadcasting Act 1946 be amended to provide absolute privilege only to compulsory radio broadcasts of proceedings which are required by the Act.

Not supported. The Government believes that absolute privilege should be extended to all live broadcasts of parliamentary proceedings where broadcasters lack of editorial control may expose them to contempt proceedings. This may encourage broadcasters to broaden their coverage of parliamentary proceedings.

4. The Parliamentary Procedures Broadcasting Act 1946 be amended to make it consistent with other related legislation and to accommodate current management and operation of transmission facilities for compulsory radio broadcasts.

5. The functions of the Joint Committee on the Broadcasting of Parliamentary Proceedings continue to be specified under the Act and that these functions include:.advising the Parliament on the arrangements for radio and television broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings;.specifically in relation to the compulsory radio broadcasts, advising both Houses on the general principles and standing determinations which should apply to these broadcasts.;.the regular review every five years of the arrangements for the broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings; and.advising the Houses on the application of new broadcasting technologies to the public dissemination of parliamentary proceedings.

6. A new act covering arrangements for the broadcasting of parliamentary proceedings be drafted and introduced into the Parliament. The new Act should implement the recommendations the Committee has made in this chapter.
The Government will consider this recommendation in the context of overall drafting priorities.
7. The PBN continue to be used by the ABC, both for parliamentary broadcasts and for the ABC's news channel.
8. The ABC supplement its compulsory parliamentary broadcasts on the PNN with coverage of other parliamentary material.
For the ABC to consider in consultation with the Committee.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY GOVERNMENT SERVICE (CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) AMENDMENT BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Tambling) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling, Sen Grant

TALKER.NAME: Senator TAMBLING
TALKER.ROLE: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Transport and Regional Development)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard .
Leave granted.

This bill proposes an amendment to the Australian Capital Territory Government Service (Consequential Provisions) Act 1994 to enable the extension of staff mobility arrangements between the ACT Government Service and the Australian Public Service.

In 1994 when officers of the Australian Public Service were compulsorily transferred to the ACT Government Service, the provisions of the Australian Capital Territory Government Service (Consequential Provisions) Act 1994 were introduced to allow ACT officers to apply for selection on merit for positions advertised in the Gazette as vacancies in the Australian Public Service. Similar provisions are provided in ACT legislation for Australian Public Service officers to apply for ACT vacancies.

In July 1995 the ACT Government corporatised the ACT Electricity and Water Authority (ACTEW). This had the effect of removing the mobility rights which ACTEW employees previously held as ACT officers.

Following a request by the ACT Government and advice that the ACT Government is considering corporatising further authorities, this bill proposes an amendment to the Australian Capital Territory Government Service (Consequential Provisions) Act 1994 to insert a regulation making power in the act which will enable the mobility rights of former ACT officers to be continued in an appropriate way consistent with overall Commonwealth policy on corporatisation and contracting out.
I commend the bill to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans, Sen Chris

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise today to speak to my motion concerning child care. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate notes, with concern, that:
(a) the changes in the administration of the Australian child care system will dramatically increase the cost of child care for most Australian families;
(b) the increase in child care fees will completely erase any benefit these families may receive from the Liberal Party's family tax initiative; and
(c) the increase in fees will reduce the choices available to Australian women and are therefore anti-family.
The reason I sought to bring on this debate today was because of the great concern that exists in the community about the government's child-care changes contained in its recent budget.

TALK.START.PARA: —You have not got a personal interest, have you?

—I was just about to declare before I started, as I have in all such debates, that my personal interest is not a pecuniary one. I am a father of two young children—at least, to the best of my knowledge only two—and both attend a child-care centre for a couple of days a week. That is to facilitate my partner also working, although unfortunately she has had to work only part-time in recent years because of my full-time employment. So that is my personal interest, if you like, in the matter. Child care is a matter that a lot of Australians have an interest in as most of us belong to families and have relationships with children in one form or another.

SPEECH.PARA: The motion seeks to highlight the cost to families of the changes made in the budget, the failure of the family tax initiative to compensate for those increased costs and the impact this will have on women. I am sure my fellow Labor Party speakers will concentrate on some of those issues, as I hope to.

It is important for us to realise the changing nature of our society—the number of families that have two parents working has increased and the demand for child care in our society has risen dramatically in recent years. Since 1983 the number of places for child care in Australia has risen by 500 per cent. There has been an enormous growth in child‐care places. Over half a million children are in care. About 34 per cent of children under four are in some form of formal care.

This is an enormous industry. It is an industry in which the Australian community must have a close interest because it is about the care and development of our very young children. As I said, it is no longer just a small sector but a large vitally important sector.

Given that position, the Liberal Party went to the last election promising to retain and improve the child‐care system that the Labor Party had built over its 13 years in government. The coalition promised that it had no plans whatever to change the operational subsidy. That promise was given by Mr Kemp—

TALK.START.PARA: —Dr Kemp.

—Sorry. It was given by Dr Kemp, who was the then shadow spokesperson. They also promised that a coalition government would maintain the non‐means tested child‐care cash rebate, and they generally argued that they would broaden child‐care options for the community. The Liberal Party went to the election promising to protect and improve the child‐care system that had been established by the Labor government.

BREAK.PARA: Quite clearly in this budget they totally reneged on those promises. Apart from the obvious breaking of their promises to maintain the operational subsidy and to not means test the child‐care rebate, they have chipped away at a number of the provisions that are at the centre of child‐care assistance and the child‐care system in this country. They have used child care from which to drag back a massive $504 million over the next four years. They have attacked the child‐care system to raise revenue for this budget.

The result of those attacks on child care is a massive dislocation to the system and an enormous increase in fees to parents. The recent EPAC report indicated that the removal of the operational subsidy from subsidised child‐care centres would represent a cost of $14 per week per child over three and a cost of $21 per week per child under three. So you can see that the removal of the subsidy is going to have an enormous impact on parents through increased fees.

In the budget the government also removed $282 million from child‐care assistance through a series of measures that nicked and cut to restrict child‐care assistance and to restrict access to child‐care assistance. They were even so mean as to provide that there would be no indexation over the next two years, so that those currently receiving child‐care assistance would receive no compensation as fees increase in line with the CPI but would rather have their assistance reduced in relative terms.

The Government have also walked away from the Labor Party's commitment to build more child‐care places, so the Labor program for 5,500 new places between now and the year 2000 has been abolished and those places will not be provided. The Liberal government is relying on the private centres to provide for the demand that is emerging for child‐care places in this country. So the budget represents a massive attack on child care and on parents' capacity to enrol their children in good quality child care.

According to our estimates, more than 330,000 families will pay more for child care as a result of the various budget initiatives. These families will get no benefit from the family tax initiative that was also contained in the budget. Whatever small amounts those families would have received by way of taxation relief will be completely eroded by the increased child‐care costs.

It also represents, in my view, a thinly disguised attempt to close community based child‐care centres. The Liberal Party for a long time had difficulty accepting the role of community based centres in our system, and I think these changes are an attempt to close those centres, to drive them out of the market and to leave child care as a purely private, profit driven market with no community input into child care and child‐care centres.

Quite frankly, that is a great shame because the role that community based child‐care centres have played in developing quality child care and in improving the child care available to Australian children and Australian families has been excellent. I commend the community based child‐care centres and their staff for the role that they have played over the years. They have provided choice, quality and leadership on a range of issues and have provided assistance to disadvantaged children. They have helped meet special needs.

An obvious area where they have been involved in which private centres have not been keen to take a role is in the area of providing places for children under the age of two. It is very hard to find places for children under two in private centres because of the higher costs required in meeting the supervision needs of those children. But the community based centres have filled that need in our community.

They have also allowed for parental input into the control of their centres and the development of their children and have been a focus for a lot of community activities. So they have played a very useful role in building community spirit, in involving parents in the care of their children and in assisting parents learn how to be good parents and how to meet the development needs of their children.

I make the point that I do not say that these needs are not met in part by private centres. My comments are not meant as an attack on private centres—I have visited a number of very good private centres. But there is a role for community based centres in our system.

I do not think that we should be moving to what is effectively a child‐care system solely dominated by the private sector and market forces, because I think that we would end up with a lesser system, a system without the same quality and without the same capacity to deliver as currently is provided. The community based centres have in many ways acted as a benchmark for the private centres and have forced standards to be applied that otherwise might not have been applied.

The ALP will be opposing the child‐care cutbacks that were contained in the budget. We will be looking very closely at each of the bills as they come into this place. We will be seeking to defend what we can of the community based child‐care centres' role and to defend the rights of parents to good quality child care at an affordable price. We will highlight the fact that the Liberal Party promised these people that their child‐care places would be safe, that the system, the assistance and the rebates they had enjoyed under the previous administration would be maintained. We will be trying to hold you to what is obviously now considered to be a non‐core election promise.

I can tell you from the experience I have had of talking to families around Perth—I attended a meeting the other night of 300 or so people at the University of Western Australia—that there are a lot of very angry people out there. Many of them believed the coalition when it said that it would maintain the current child‐care system, that it would maintain the community based system. They are becoming acutely aware of what Liberal Party promises mean.

In terms of the argument about increased costs, I think it is quite obvious there will be significant increased costs to parents of children who attend community based centres. As I said, the EPAC figures indicated that the costs per child were somewhere between $14 and $21 per week. The centres I have spoken to receive an operational subsidy of somewhere between $30,000 to $45,000 per annum. That is $30,000 to $45,000 per centre that will be removed from their budgets. For some of them, this represents 10 per cent or more of their total costs.

These centres do not have many options. They are not for profit. They do not have the ability to carry over losses and profits. Their only answers are to increase costs or to start doing things like cutting the amount of food or the quality of food they provide to the children, or reducing the number of staff employed to care for those children. There are not a lot of options. They run a very tight operation as it is and most of the centres I have spoken to—and I have spoken to at least a dozen so far—have indicated they will just have to pass most of the costs on to the parents. So those centres are looking at having to significantly increase the cost to the parents.
The budget, to be fair to the government, admits this is the case. The budget papers state:
There is potential for increased costs for some families using community based centres as the result of the removal of the operational subsidy.
Even the budget concedes that the subsidised centres will have to pass on these costs to families of children enrolled in these child‐care centres.

But it is not just the subsidised centres that will suffer—or the families who use subsidised centres. The costs for families whose children attend private centres will also rise. The cap on assistance to a maximum of 50 hours a week, the changes to child‐care assistance, and the freeze on the fee ceilings for the cash rebate and child‐care assistance will all force up the costs to every parent with a child in child care.

All will have to pay more. Well over 300,000 families will be paying more. Some of those families with two or three children in child care will be paying a great deal more for their child care. My estimates are that some will be paying anywhere between $40 and $90 a week extra as these costs are passed on. These are massive cost increases. These are costs that will force life changing decisions for a lot of people in terms of whether both partners work, whether they place their children in quality care or whether they seek informal and ad hoc arrangements.

These are very important changes that the government has brought about—changes that will have a real impact on people's lives, and not just people at the top end of town. I know the government is very keen to have this sort of Robin Hood image perpetrated since the budget—how it is attacking the rich to protect the poor—but these changes will impact on ordinary working men and women in Australia. People who are earning less than $30,000 a year where both partners are working will be severely affected by these changes. Women who are studying and put their children in child care while they study will be affected. Some of them are on very low incomes. There is going to be real pain, real hurt, to low and middle income families as well as those on higher incomes who will be affected by the means testing of the cash rebate system.

The government have at the centrepiece of this budget the family tax initiative. They have heralded the family tax initiative as being their attempt to protect the family to ensure that people raising children in our society have a better deal. On the one hand they give and on the other hand they take. Many of the benefits that come from the family tax initiative will be completely erased for families in our society. Many families will be $10, $20, $30 or $40 worse off as a result of the dual impact of the family tax initiative and their increased child‐care costs.

Those people will not believe you when you say that they will be better off from the family tax initiative when they get a $7, $8, $9 or $10 a week increase in their take home pay as a result of the changes to taxation, yet they will have to fork out $20, $30, $40 or $50 a week extra in increased fees for child care. They will not thank you. They are very angry about it and they are beginning to realise what it is going to mean for their budgets, for their choices.

The Liberal Party campaigned on improving and broadening choice in child care. This makes a complete lie of that claim. You are restricting people's choices. You are removing choices by forcing them to pay more for their child care. As I say, for many Australian families the tax initiative will not result in them being better off at all because the impact of the increase in child‐care fees will completely erase any benefits that there would have been from the family tax initiative.

I am sure Senator Crowley and others will speak more about this aspect of the motion—that is, the aspect that refers to the reduction in choices to women and the anti-family nature of these cuts. But I think it is very clear that what has occurred here reflects the Liberal Party's bias against two‐income families. It has been a cry of the Liberal Party for many years that we do not do enough to protect those who have a carer at home not in paid employment. But what we see in this budget is an attack on women who work, because it is largely women who will suffer as a result of these changes. The government has not broadened choice at all. It has reduced choices for these women. A number of women I have spoken to will have to make very hard decisions as a result of what will occur.

At a meeting I attended the other night, a young woman made a very strong speech. This young woman is studying and she said that as a result of the huge increases in HECS fees and the child‐care fee increases, she will have to give up study. She has done her maths. She will not be able to afford to continue her university course because the combined effects of HECS and increases in child‐care fees will mean it is just not economical for her to do it. She cannot manage, so she will have to give up her university course at the end of the year. She will not be able to continue studying next year under the new arrangements for HECS and the increased child‐care fees.

This woman is not atypical. A number of women at meetings I have attended have spoken about how this is really making them have to think again about whether they can continue to stay in the work force. The increase in costs of child care may make it uneconomical for many women to continue to work. They will be driven—not through choice but through the impact of these fees and other charges, like the HECS charges—back into the home to care for their own children when they would rather be doing some part-time employment, some study or some full-time employment. You are very much reducing the choices to women.

A lot of women I have spoken to are angry. They feel let down, they feel marginalised and they very much fear that their opportunities have been reduced by these changes. They are organising themselves to campaign against these changes. When a number of these measures come before the Senate in budget bills, I hope that the Democrats, the Greens and the Independents will combine with us to defeat a number of these measures because they are anti-family and they very much restrict the opportunities and choices for women in Australian society.

Finally, I wish to make a few remarks about a letter I received from a constituent. This constituent sent me a copy of a letter she forwarded to the Hon. Judi Moylan, the Minister for Family Services, in response to the budget cuts. This constituent lives in Derby in Western Australia, in the far north‐west of Western Australia. I am sure Senator Eggleston will be interested in what she has to say. She sends her only child to the one child-care centre in Derby, a subsidised centre.

This woman says that the impact of cuts in remote areas is tantamount to abolishing formal child‐care arrangements in the bush. She currently pays fees of $174.50 for a child in nappies, already far greater than those paid at comparable centres in the metropolitan area. Her centre will have to find an extra $40,000 next year to continue operating. That will result in this woman paying fees in excess of $200 per week for one child—$200 per week to have her child cared for while she attempts to earn a full-time income.

She makes the point that the private sector will not step into this particular breach because they will have no interest in opening up an alternative centre in an isolated area like Derby because of the difficulties in attracting staff, higher costs, et cetera. Senators would be aware of the difficulties of operating in some of the far‐flung regional areas of northern Australia.

This woman thinks that these child‐care cuts will have an enormous impact on her lifestyle. She cites that the minister has accepted that some centres are likely to close as a result of the removal of the subsidy. She believes her centre may well be one of those. Fifty-five families in Derby will have to deal with the consequences of that—to face job loss or income reduction. It will have an enormous impact on their lifestyles and their ability to stay and continue to work in areas such as Derby. As Senator O'Chee and others would know, it is sometimes very hard to attract people to these sorts of regions to do valuable jobs. This is going to have an enormous impact on the whole fabric of Derby and other communities.
I am sure government speakers will say, `There is some money in the budget for adjustment,' and there is, but it is of the order of $10 million.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is more than that.

—I will listen to your explanation, Senator Troeth, with some interest. I do not have the figure directly in front of me, but I had a look at what it would mean. I cannot see it satisfying the needs of even Western Australia, let alone the rest of Australia, because the needs in the bush are enormous. The costs are very high and I cannot see the adjustment package as contained in the budget papers doing anything to overcome the need for subsidised centres in remote and regional areas.

BREAK.PARA: I think there is an enormous range of issues here that are of concern. There is a growing resistance to the government's cuts to child care. I think as families begin to analyse what it means for them in terms of costs, in terms of the closure of centres and in terms of the reduction of their choices, the government will start to feel the heat from those families that feel very much let down by the government's broken promises and its attack on working families in Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Troeth, Sen Judith

TALK.START.PARA: —I congratulate Senator Chris Evans on his thoughtful speech. As he is a parent with young children, I do realise the interest he would take in this area. It is equally important to realise that the changes in administration of the Australian child-care system, which he referred to in the motion we have before us today, are simply related to, more or less, the removal of the operational subsidy for community based, long day care centres.

SPEECH.PARA: The fact that the operational subsidy is retained for family day care, occasional day care, outside school hours care, multifunctional services and multifunctional Aboriginal services highlights the compassion and concern this government has for parents and children who use the child-care system that we have. It is regrettable that some of Senator Evans's comments could only be construed as scaremongering.

There is no proof that charges to parents will increase as a result of the removal of the operational subsidies, and this government is all about providing a flexible service. Not all families, as I have indicated, who use child care will be affected by the removal of the operational subsidies. Let us get this in perspective. The figures in June 1996 indicate that community centre places comprise 20 per cent of all long day care places nationally. Certainly, there are many more children who attend child care and many parents who will simply not be affected by this change and who will, in the long run, be grateful for the attempt to provide a far more flexible service than what we have seen in the past.

The operational subsidy has never been available to services owned by private operators, and private operators are a significant part of the market in the child-care industry. For instance, in South Australia I understand that community based centres cost, on average, $7 per week more than private centres. It is a known fact that community based centres have for a long time enjoyed a commercial advantage over private centres because they were obtaining operational subsidies. The removal of that operational subsidy simply redresses the imbalance in government subsidies. It removes a significant inequity for families using the private child-care sector, and it places both those sectors on an equal footing.

As I said, while Senator Evans maintains that this will necessarily lead to an increase in child-care fees and/or a reduction in services, it would be a regrettable step if the community based centres took the decision to increase fees or reduce their services without first attempting to achieve efficiencies through a restructure of their financial operations and management. To this end, the Commonwealth government will make $8.3 million available across Australia for centres to purchase financial and/or management advice and to help them manage the loss of that subsidy prior to its removal on 1 July 1997. The centres have almost 12 months, or certainly nine or ten months, to start making these changes. That $8.3 million is additional to the $11.5 million over three years, which is available to assist centres to upgrade and amalgamate in order to improve their efficiency and viability.

Senator Crowley would be the first to admit that when she and I together, although on opposite sides of the table, looked at the way child-care centres were planned across the length and breadth of Australia, there were areas of oversupply and there were areas of undersupply. In that way, these centres will be encouraged in the public sector to look at the way in which they have planned their centre in relation to centres in the neighbouring area.

Not only that, in relation to Senator Evans's comments on his disadvantaged constituent in Derby—and I would be the first to admit that in country areas parents may be disadvantaged through not having access to a choice in child-care centres—the government will provide supplementary funding totalling $12.5 million over four years to community centres in severely disadvantaged areas, where no other child care is available, to ensure that families in these areas do not lose their access to child care.

So I suggest that, lamentable though the circumstances may be for Senator Evans's constituent, the government will be there to assist in this way and that his constituent may well be able to continue what she has been doing in the past. Information on eligibility criteria is being finalised at present, and I suggest that those parents who feel that they fall into that category should make inquiries about that. Not only that, $10.9 million in capital funds will also be made available to innovative services in rural and remote areas to ensure that families in these areas have access to flexible child care. Certainly I hope that the pilot program on farm child care, which is presently being trialled in Albury-Wodonga, will be able to continue.

Not only that, up to $31 million will be spent by the government over four years to support children with high levels of additional needs, especially those with a disability who would not normally be able to access places in federal government child-care centres. This budget shows a significant and continuing commitment to child care. When we take into account measures in this budget, outlays in this year will exceed those in 1995-96 by $150 million, which is a 15 per cent growth in outlays.

The second clause in Senator Evans's notice of motion deals with the fact, as he puts it, or the supposition, that the increase in child-care fees will completely erase any benefit these families may receive from the Liberal Party's family tax initiative. The new family tax initiative will benefit over two million Australian families. These families will receive around $200 per child in disposable income, and single-income families with at least one child under five will receive an additional $500.

The changes to child care in the budget substantially protect the benefit of low and middle income families. I think Senator Evans used the phrase `robbing the rich to pay the poor'. I would like to point out that it was Senator Evans who actually used this phrase; they are not my words. In actual fact, what we are asking is that those people and parents who can afford the payments in child care should be asked to make them so that the people who do benefit from the allocation in the budget will be low and middle income earners.

Firstly, we can look at the reduction from 30 per cent to 20 per cent in the child-care cash rebate for families on incomes over $70,000. That only reduces benefits for high income families who are better able to meet their child-care costs, and those families are in the top 20 per cent of family incomes in Australia.

Secondly, the decision to limit child-care assistance to a maximum of 50 hours per week for families who are currently charged and pay for more than 50 hours per week, but who actually use less, is a responsible move by government. Open-ended government assistance should not be used to subsidise inefficient operations or excessive charging practices. Indeed, I should point out that no family receiving the new family tax initiative will be affected by the change in the child-care cash rebate.

Thirdly, the abolition of the $30 per week for child-care assistance assessment purposes reflects the significant improvements since the mid-eighties in other forms of government assistance to families with children, and I include in there the enhanced family payments. Sixty-five per cent of families in child care are one‐child families, and other families currently receiving maximum child-care assistance will not be affected by this measure.

Fourthly, the reduction in the cut‐offs for child‐care assistance will result in about 500 high income families no longer being eligible for part child‐care assistance and about nine per cent of all families receiving child‐care assistance receiving a slightly reduced level of assistance. I hope this lays to rest once and for all the sort of myths that were being perpetuated by Senator Evans in his remark. I would have also thought that people in the Labor Party, which continually proclaims its desire to assist low income families and to protect those families against the ravages of government, would have been the last to complain about the sort of measures about which I am speaking.

Finally, the decision not to index the child‐care assistance ceiling on 1 April 1997 or 1 April 1998 will require services to review their efficiency rather than simply increase their fees by the level of indexation. So low and middle income families will not lose the benefit of the family tax initiative as a result of these child‐care measures.

Briefly, I would like to run through some of the budget measures spoken about by Senator Evans and the way in which these will help families rather than impede them. The cut to the operational subsidy, as I said, means that centres are simply put on an equal footing with the private sector. Where families do encounter increased fees, they may be eligible for increased child‐care cash rebate where they are not already receiving the maximum. This should mean that the whole fee increase is not passed on.

Where a service is faced with closure—and this may well relate to Senator Evans's constituent in the far north‐west of Western Australia—and it is the only service for families to access work related care in that region, people may be eligible to apply for supplementary funding. Funding will be targeted to areas of disadvantage and to areas where alternative private or family day‐care services are not available. I would have thought that this would have completely fulfilled Senator Evans's example.

As I said, there will be an allocation of money for the purchasing of financial management services by centres to enable them to work through the transition period. We have not walked away from our commitment to establish innovative child‐care services for families in rural and remote areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —Our policy, our initiatives. Glad you continue them.

—Senator Crowley, not only that, but also parents will now be able to choose how child‐care assistance and child‐care cash rebate is paid, rather than your system, which entailed, as you and I both know, an enormous amount of paperwork for both parents and centres. That assistance and the cash rebate can now be paid either as a direct payment into the family bank account—and what a boon that would be to busy parents—or to the service directly. That will be implemented by January 1998 and administered by the new Commonwealth government service delivery agency, which is to be under the auspices of the Department of Social Security. Changing those payment arrangements will give families more control over their benefit and it is expected to improve competition and encourage services to be far more responsive to the needs of families in relation to quality of care, flexible hours, extended hours care and charging practices—all of which help busy parents, many of whom are both in the work force.

BREAK.PARA: Lastly, as I said, Senator Evans's motion deals with the increase in fees reducing the choices available to Australian women and therefore they are anti‐family. How can the provision of extra child‐care money be anti‐family? These sorts of budget measures encourage choice. They streamline services for busy mothers and fathers. They are much better targeted to people who need the services, and people who use the services and can afford to make the payment are certainly being asked to do so. That is in line with our entire budget strategy of targeting services, and particularly government services, to families which need them.

The opposition, I know, will make great moment of the fact that, in their view, there is less money available for child care. If the policies of their government had not left this country in such parlous economic straits, there would be far more money to deal with child care and with the economically responsible budget measures that are being undertaken by my government. In the future, one would imagine that greater amounts of money will be available for areas such as child care.
