I, for one, would be the first to be pressing government for that, but it is only by responsible economic budgetary measures, such as these that I have outlined, that we will be able to do that in the future.
In short, Senator Evans's motion, while well intentioned, simply does not accede to the facts that have been expressed by Treasurer Costello. Certainly, the coalition does not agree with this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley, Sen Rosemary

TALK.START.PARA: —I am glad they sent you down, Senator Troeth. You have got a quieter voice, so you are probably less provocative. The point is that you went to the electorate promising absolutely no change to the operational subsidy. You promised absolutely no means testing on the child‐care cash rebate and you promised to retain the child‐care accreditation system. You have done none of these things: you have broken every one of those promises. Feeble complaints about the budget and those sorts of things simply will not do, particularly as Senator Troeth has just pointed out that, in the child‐care area, the government will be expending more money, not less.

SPEECH.PARA: What you have done is to rearrange it in a way that is going to be very disadvantaging for families. You did it by finally coming clean on what you really mean in this area. You have not introduced a budget that restores, in covert ways, Fightback; you have actually introduced John Howard's initial proposals when he was the previous leader in Towards the future. There were four column inches on child care in that document; that is all. You did not know about it then and your policies were `All women should be at home; we will abolish child care and that will make the world and the families of Australia much happier.'

Since Mr Howard was last leader, the world has changed. Even he has recognised that he could not go to the electorate this time around saying what he really means about child care. The world has caught him up. It ran over him, but his intentions are still there under the changes. The most important thing that Mr Howard did in the run‐up to this budget was to promise no change to operational subsidy. He promised no means test on child‐care cash rebate. He promised no change to the accreditation system. They are distinctive and deliberate untruths which have been perpetrated on the people of this country. The noises coming from the child‐care industry mean that all those people in child care know and understand that the Howard government got elected by broken promises. It told terrible untruths to the people, particularly about child care.

The very first thing they have done is to remove the operational subsidy from the long day care centres, and they have done much worse than that. Let me find the quote from a letter from Dr David Kemp on 28 February 1996. He was still trying to convince people that he was serious about child care. He said:
The coalition has no plans whatever to change the operational subsidy.
He also spoke of:
. . . our continuing support for the community based long day care sector. We regard the operational subsidy as one of the key supports of that sector.
I remind you again of his line:

BREAK.PARA: The coalition has no plans whatever to change the operational subsidy.

They had hardly crossed the threshold of government before they were removing it. They thought they could remove it from family day care and they thought they could remove it from outside school hours care until they discovered that, if you had no operational subsidy in those two areas, you would have no family day care and you would have no outside school hours care. They are slow learners.

Even they realised that you could not pull down family day care. Of course, although hours and hours were wasted by family day care families and providers in defending this absolutely outrageous proposal, in the end they did what we knew they would have to do: retain it. Their attack on the community based sector is overt, blatant and disgraceful. `We believe in the community based sector,' says Dr Kemp, but they have hacked away the operational subsidy and they have removed any further growth strategy. Five and a half thousand community based long day care places and employer sponsored community based places will not now be built. They say, `Leave it to the private sector,' which has been growing and filling the gaps very quickly.

The next thing they say is that we did not have much planning but they are going to have a national planning program. The only part of child care that was properly planned was the community based sector, on needs areas across the country delivering community based child care very fairly to low income areas, to rural areas, to regional and remote areas, to all the places that were difficult. The only part not planned was the private sector. What on earth do they think is now going to make the private sector become more thoughtful and planned than it has been to this point? Indeed, as I understood Senator Troeth, she was suggesting that community based sectors that might have some trouble need not worry because, after all, if they cannot be financially viable, then, no doubt, the private sector will take those places over and continue the provision of child care.

Families in this country have said for a long time that they like and support community based child care. It has been the standard set‐up. It certainly established levels of quality care and provision of longer hours, of more baby places, of care for children with disability, of regional and remote area provision and provision in low socioeconomic areas. All of those were provided by the community based sector—not the private sector—on a needs based delivery. This government has done away with the growth strategy; that is, 5,500 community based places will not now be built. It has taken away their operational subsidies and, while the equity of that may be arguable against the private sector places, they are not comparable deliveries of child care. They do not have the same population of children and they do not cover the same areas.

It may be one thing to say, `We will remove the operational subsidy,' but please do not say that this is not going to affect costs of child care. By any estimates, it will be something like $14 to $20 unless the child‐care centres cut services or quality. There is no doubt that that will have to happen. The government said it would not means test the child‐care cash rebate. It could not wait to get into government to do that, but it has done it in a picky, mean kind of way so that it appears it has only half done it and so that they have not really been seen to do it. Yes, they have. They have broken another promise. `We will not remove operational subsidy. We will not means test the child‐care cash rebate'—two broken promises.

They believe in the accreditation system. Having fought in this place in every possible, disgraceful and disgusting way to oppose it, they now say they are going to keep it. If you believe that, you believe anything. They have told dreadful porkies. They have said that they believe in child care and grudgingly they have had to admit it is here to stay. They have done their best, certainly, to break their promises and to attack the public sector delivery of child care in long day care centres. They could not do it in family day care; there are too many families to cut that public sector provision of services out.

I note the Senator Troeth wants to wish the farm based child‐care program in Albury‐Wodonga well. I am very pleased to say that that is one of the innovative things we were able to achieve. I am pleased that the opposition is now talking about innovation in child care. That means they are deliberately continuing the Labor policies, and well done. You should. It was a good policy and will continue to be a good policy. Senator Troeth hopes Albury‐Wodonga will continue. There is only one reason it will not: you will stop it. It is an excellent program. It follows the research done by the people in Albury‐Wodonga for farm based child care. It has the flexibility needed to meet the needs of those families in rural and remote areas. Make every effort to keep it. Don't worry whether it will survive, because, from here on in, when it does not survive it will be yet another thing that you will be responsible for.

Senator Troeth wanted to suggest there will not be too much change in the cost of child care and that the fees will not rise. Of course they will. They will rise in the community based sector because of the cuts in the operational subsidy, but they will also rise because of the reduction in the taper of family income for assessment of eligibility for child‐care assistance. Senator Troeth says it will only be a teensy‐weensy bit extra cost for families in the middle income bracket, or below $70,000. It will be much more for families at the top end of the scale and a considerable number of families will lose any child‐care assistance or part child‐care assistance at all.

But for families in the middle range, I do not believe the government is fully aware of the impact of its changes. First, they have frozen the amount for a place at $115 per week for the next two years, into 1998—no extra payment for any of the child‐care places. Secondly, they have reduced the taper for family income assessment. Thirdly, they have done away with the $30 child disability allowance for the second and subsequent children. All of these impact very significantly on the costs of fees and charges that centres will have to set for families to have to pay.

This notion that you get some of your tax assistance through the family tax package may seem good, but that dollar has completely gone because of the dramatic increase in the costs of child care. I say to Senator Patterson that, yes, they will go up, and you know they will go up. You are going to come in here shortly and tell us why. But please don't say they won't. Of course, they will.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am already in here.
—I am glad you are here.
—You implied I was not here and I am already in here.

—No, I didn't. I made a small mistake. Don't worry. You can tell us about it. You have dramatically increased the impact on families of the costs of child care. You have reduced the growth, cut away the operational subsidy and fixed the fees for two years. You have done away with the child disability allowance and reduced the taper. All of those are very significant differences. As I have heard it said, the government, and government senators, seem unaware of the impact of these factors altogether.

BREAK.PARA: One of the things we have had to deal with in this place is the impact of a number of women coming into parliament on the Liberal benches. This is supposed to be a great thing for the women of Australia. As a person who has campaigned for years for more women in parliament, I do not have any dispute about more women in parliament. But these Liberal women have joined the Liberal men to make life very hard for Australian women.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—Yes, you have. You are the women who have come in and seen these dramatic changes. You have not actually improved choices at all for families. You have restricted their choices. That is what you have done. Everything you asked them to believe on 1 March was not true. You broke your promises. Clearly, child care is not a core issue or a core promise for this Howard government. It is a pretty marginal issue. They want women out of the work force and back at home, enjoying their little tax assistance. That is what the Liberal government wants. Women and families of Australia are quite clear that they are not going to be fooled by that.

BREAK.PARA: If you offer with one hand `x' amount of dollars and then take 2, 3 and 4 times `x' with the other, families are not going to be fooled by that. Their tax payments are already eaten up by the increased costs of child care. But they are also eaten up by the increased costs of dental care for the older people in their family. They are also dramatically eaten up by the rising costs of health. They are going to be eaten up by the costs of pharmaceuticals. Every time you go to the pharmacist or the chemist, that is going to whack away your tax increase in one go. So families of Australia will know very quickly, as they live through the next year or so, exactly what you have done for them. You have restricted choice.

Your whole choice for this country depends on the economy somehow getting going. Somebody on the other side said the other day that small business is the engine room for jobs; suddenly, everybody in small business will start providing jobs; suddenly, everybody will be working and this will improve the lot of families. There is no doubt that the minister for giving out the number of unemployed is preparing to duck and twist rather than give us a number of how many unemployed people there are in this country and how your policies will not make the slightest difference to the number of unemployed people.

Those unemployed people will not be enjoying the tax benefits. They will have to pay more for any child care which they can access. They will have to pay more for their pharmaceuticals. They will have to pay more for any elderly relative in their family who needs dental care. They are some of the costs. If anybody should want to study or try to go to university, their costs will be further eroded. If they were previously enjoying some assistance through job assistance programs such as skillshare or jobstart, they will not get that anymore, either. So it is very tough on Australian families out there.

I have said it before and I will say it again: this is a classic Tory Thatcher budget which has abandoned the unemployed. If you do that, you are certainly not assisting the families of Australia. To use these changes in child care to suggest that you are assisting families with more choice is a matter of tortured and convoluted language for those opposite.

Having opposed all the initiatives of the previous government, you then adopted the whole lot in the lead‐up to the election. Once you were across the barrier, you changed your mind and did what you really believed—means tested the cash rebate, did away with the operational subsidy and you have already cut the money for the accreditation system that ensures quality care in all the child‐care centres. You were true to form once you won the election. You were very untrue to form in the lead‐up to it. It will not take the community too long to find it out. You have done away with the industry council in child care—a council that I established to try to make sure that this very significant growth area was working as one, with the old divisions between the community based and the private sectors removed.

It is interesting to find now that the majority of private child-care centres want the quality accreditation system to continue and want it to be tied to the eligibility for child-care assistance. They do not want to see the proposals that you are allowing to happen.

They also know, as I do from various polls that we have done in the past, that over 60 per cent of Australian families do not want to have access to the child-care money paid directly to them. They do not want that. They want it to go to the child-care centre so that it is one huge area that will not be of any worry to them. Senator Troeth says that you could reduce the paperwork and worry for people applying for child-care assistance. We considerably streamlined it. I will be interested to see if your proposals to amalgamate these payments will further streamline it. If it does, I will support that.

While you are streamlining on one hand, you are giving people more bills, more payment and more paperwork on the other by giving them the child‐care dollars in their own bank accounts, if that is what they choose. That is more paperwork for them. So you cannot say that this is going to be streamlining it for families. You had better get clear what you are really on about in child care here.

It is a grudging admission that child care will continue. You used to accuse the Labor government of allowing families to double dip, for example, but you have done the same. You are going to pay tax payments to families when a family member stays at home and you are going to allow those same families to have access to occasional care with the child-care costs now very significantly increased by the changes you have proposed under this government.

The interesting thing is that you have actually introduced a 50‐hour limitation on child care. Now, Senator Patterson, you are not going to say this out loud, but we all know what that is. It is called 12 hours by another name. You opposed the 12 hours. You are now actually introducing a de facto 12 hours by another name.

One of the other problems you had to deal with—and certainly one Minister Moylan had to deal with—was that by opposing the 12 hours in this place you took $140 million off the bottom line. When anybody over the other side stands up and says, `You'll wreck the country if you don't deliver our budget,' we can just say, `Well you wouldn't deliver ours. You wouldn't deliver the savings that were proposed last time with the 12 hours.' It was $140 million. You had to find it this time and you have done it by calling it 50 hours. The centres are having a lot of trouble dealing with the consequences of that to their costs, to their fee structures and to their charges.

It is a very big whammy that you have given families here. You have dramatically increased the cost of child care, particularly in the community based sector by removing the operational subsidy, but you have also reduced the taper for eligibility for child-care assistance payments on family income. You have taken away the $30 disallowance for second and subsequent children. You have frozen the amount of money that child-care assistance is calculated against.

So for those very poor families, for families in the lower socioeconomic area, for the families that you claim to have assisted or will assist, you have just whacked them round the head with dramatic increased child-care costs. I hope that when you senators over there actually have a look at what your policies mean, particularly for the battling families and the low income families that you claim now to represent, you might want to rethink and modify your own government proposals in this area. They are unconscionably harsh. They are particularly harsh for families at that lower income end. You cannot say to families, `You'll be much better off if we give you $4 or $20,' and then give them $25 or $30 increased child-care costs. That is what you have done.

You have also made a great claim in the past that families with one parent at home should also have access to child care. We utterly agree. We established that policy. We think it is a very reasonable thing indeed, but we certainly wanted to make sure that they could afford it. We also wanted to make sure that as many families as possible would have access to those child-care places.

TALK.START.PARA: —They ought to prescribe this for insomniacs.
—I am glad to note that you are awake, so it is clearly not working.
—It is close to working.

—In that case, I would like to think that at least some benefit might come from the hard facts of your policies. Again, I remind you, there is no forward growth strategy; there is a cutback in growth strategy in the community based sector. This is going to enormously distort the contribution of long day care centres. Long day care in the community based sector, as I said, in the past has been the standard setter for quality. It is very depressing that you should be restricting that growth, indeed ceasing it altogether.

BREAK.PARA: You have also called for a national planning strategy, but I remind you again that the only part of child care that has been planned has been the public sector. The private child-care centres have grown like topsy. There are gross oversupplies in areas like south-east Queensland and north‐east New South Wales. There is absolutely no indication that those child-care centres in the private sector have any better capacity to make decisions that will allow better distribution.

I am very shocked to discover that one of the private providers of child care from Queensland has recently come into the state of South Australia, had an appointment with the state education minister and has approval to now go and talk to school councils about the sale of school land—that is, state government school land. If the council decides that the land can be sold, the child-care people will buy the land, half the money of the land's value will stay with the school and, on the corner of the school, a private child-care centre will be built.

I find this is a totally extraordinary proposal. So bad is it in South Australia that, in one area where the private as well as the community based child-care centres around a school heard that this was happening, they actually attended the meeting of the parents and the school council and protested rigorously against the school going this way because there is already sufficient child-care places within cooee or very close to that school. Another child-care centre built on the school grounds would have been an oversupply and would have put all the child-care centres in that region in jeopardy of becoming financially unviable.

It is an appalling process. It is a process that takes the land from the citizens of South Australia. It is a process that restricts any comprehensive planning for the provision of child care by the private sector, contrary to what Senator Troeth and the government senators and members have been saying.

I really believe that if you are going to have some kind of national planning strategy for the private sector, you must arrive at it very soon because, clearly, the financial advisers who are urging people to get into private child care are not giving them any more advice other than saying, `It's a good investment; get into it now.' There is already an enormous supply in south-east Queensland and north-east New South Wales. They are in difficulty now. Some of those private centres have to face the fact that they have invested very poorly and they may have to sell out and move on. That is not what is best for child care.

The private sector would do very well to take up the option that we gave them when we were in government—to have a look at the high need area of planning that was used to provide the community based sector and start providing their child care along the lines of the planning model that was there for the public sector. It was delivering child care fairly and appropriately in every area of Australian society, particularly in rural and remote areas. Those are the sorts of places that the private sector has been very slow and loath to go.

If you are going to come up with some kind of planning, please do it quickly because, quite clearly, the private sector, which has not made too much use of what we provided for them in the past, does not seem to have learnt too much to this point. That is a tragedy. As you are now relying on the private sector to deliver the long day care child‐care places, I would like to know—and will certainly be asking you at estimates next week—what provision do you have for any kind of equity of access for families when they are reliant on private child-care centres only.

I actually think that it is very important that we have the opportunity today to talk about the government's proposed changes in child care. They are, to reiterate, a complete litany of broken promises. They said, `We will not change operational subsidy. We will not change the quality and accreditation program and we will not means test the child‐care cash rebate.' Once in government they did all of those. But they have done much more and much worse.

Not only have they stopped the forward growth of community based places—over 5,500 now lost to the people of Australia—but also they have also clearly made it impossible for centres not to raise their fees. Costs for families using child care will rise very significantly and that will disadvantage poorer families, middle of the range families and, in particular, families where perhaps one parent is at home and not working.

The child‐care arrangements by themselves will cut out all the benefits of the government's changes of payments to families. When you add that to their attack on education, the increased costs for education, the increased costs of pharmaceuticals and the increased costs for nursing home or home and community care assistants for elderly, frail, aged or disabled members of the family, we see that this is a government that is not delivering for families. This is a government that is very harshly increasing the costs for families much along the lines of the user‐pays principle. It is called, `We will give it to families'—some—`and let them try to meet the costs.' The amount that is being given to families through tax benefits will go nowhere near enough towards assisting families with all of these services. It is very anti-family and, in particular, in the child care area, it is particularly anti-choice.

The changes that you have proposed will not increase flexibility. The 50 hours means, for example, that a lot of the centres that have been open up to 12 hours so as to assist families who have lots of travel time on top of their eight or 10‐hour working day will not have the assistance with the child‐care costs at either end of a long travel day unless they go to the bother of making application for exception. Will the individuals do it or will centres do it? Then there is all that paperwork and no guarantee that they will get any assistance.

This is a policy that has dramatically increased costs of child care. It has done nothing to make the provision of child care fairer or wider. It has done nothing to guarantee assistance to the pockets of those people currently denied child care, particularly rural and remote areas and areas of disadvantage. It certainly has not done anything to see a much closer amalgamation between pre-school, kindergarten and child‐care services.

I urge senators opposite to read through the recently released report from the Senate References Committee on Employment, Education and Training entitled Childhood matters: report on the inquiry into early childhood education because it does address ways in which some of these problems can be met.

Finally, the last item that does bear making comment about, but only to breathe another depressed sign, is that following the routing of Treasurer Costello at the Premiers Conference, there is actually much less money now going to the states. The states, who have to pick up such a lot of pre-school education, will continue to do what Mr Kennett has already polished to an art form—slip the Victorian government out and cost shift on to the Commonwealth through child care, particularly the establishment of private child care. At a time when the fees are already expensive, these fees will only get higher. The amalgamation between pre-school and child care will be at an extra cost and a further disadvantage for people in all states and territories, particularly in Victoria, where we have already seen the harsh evidence of that.

Senator Evans is absolutely right in bringing forward this motion because it does do damage and enormously increases the costs to Australian families. What looks to be a good thing on the one hand will turn out to be a series of extra charges and very harsh for Australian families. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson, Sen Kay

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Crowley's feigned indignation did nothing for me and I am sure it would do nothing for the members of the public who have seen what they have done. She said that we have given a big whammy to Australian families. Let me tell you that the biggest whammy of all occurred two days after the last election when the Australian public discovered that the budget last year was $8 billion behind. It was Beazley's $8 billion black hole.

PARA.BREAK: That is the reason we have had to address some of the issues that maybe we would have preferred not to address. We have attempted to have a fair budget. The Australian public has agreed that it is a fair budget and everyone has had to take a bit of the pain so that we can fix up a problem which we did not make. It was not our problem; it was a prob lem generated by 13 years of Labor government.

SPEECH.PARA: If you look at what has happened over the last six years, each year we have spent significantly more than we earned. Over the last five years we have gone from overspending $17 billion to overspending $96 billion. Each year we have chalked up more and more debt. We have spent more than we earned. We cannot keep doing that. Anyone who runs a family budget and anybody who runs their own personal budget knows that, if you keep putting stuff on the bankcard, the chickens come home to roost at some stage. At some point the bank manager will ring up and say, `There is no money left in your bank account. We cannot extend your credit any further.'

In the case of a nation, the International Monetary Fund comes in. You get no choice about what social security programs you have and you get no choice about whether you subsidise this child care or that child care. You are told by the IMF exactly what will happen and exactly where the cuts will be made. That was the crisis point we were reaching when Paul Keating said that we were about to become a banana republic. A lot of Australians did not realise that that meant we would have lost our sovereignty. We would not have had a say in policy: we would have been told that, if we were to continue being given money and credit, we would have to conform with what the IMF wanted.

The Australian public woke up to what the Labor government was doing: spending, spending, spending with its largesse to unions, to interest groups—to all sorts of groups. Australians realised that we could not continue to do that—that we were living beyond our means. I think the worst thing was that we were spending the money of the next generation. Senator Crowley can come in here and talk about there being changes to child care, but we would have had the next generation caring for an ageing population; that generation having spent the new generation's money. Our generation is spending money ahead of time.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is Liberalspeak, but it is nonsense.

—The Australian public know it is not nonsense, Senator Cook. They know that what we were doing was chalking up the bankcard. Let me repeat it again, because I do not think you understand what you did: in the last five years you chalked up $17 billion to $96 billion. Then you tried to pretend to the Australian public that your last budget was balanced when, in fact, it was $8 billion in deficit, so we added another $8 billion. You just cannot keep spending like that. As for Senator Crowley coming in here and saying that we delivered a whammy to families, that was the biggest whammy of all. It was capped off with the debt and deficit that continued over the 13 years of Labor.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Keating got up on budget night and said that this was a budget that was in balance. He said that it was the best thing since sliced bread. You also frittered away months and months of growth. When we had the opportunity to reduce our debt you frittered that opportunity away. There are consequences if we want to be responsible as a government and ensure that we put our budget back into balance and have enough money to actually run the sorts of programs we want to run. Senator Crowley ought to be reminded that, just to pay the mortgage on our public debt, we put up $10 billion a year.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is just the interest.

—Just the interest. We spend $10 billion on interest on what we owe in public debt. This is not about what private enterprise has borrowed from overseas because our savings are so low here in Australia; it is about what we have had to borrow as a government to fund the largesse of the former Labor government. We pay $10 billion.

SPEECH.PARA: I just saw somebody nodding up there in the gallery: they know that paying off interest is going backwards. We are going backwards paying $10 billion in interest. We do not have that $10 billion for aged care and we do not have that $10 billion for all sorts of programs that we would like to have. The responsibility lies fairly and squarely on the shoulders of those people opposite.

TALK.START.PARA: —What percentage of the debt is the Commonwealth's? Most is private sector debt—don't be stupid!

—I will respond to that interjection. That shows how ignorant Senator Cook, on the other side, is. That just shows his ignorance when he sits there and says that it is private debt. I clearly said it was not taking into account private debt at all; it is just taking into account public debt. I said that very clearly. Just taking into account public debt, we are paying $10 billion in interest per annum.
—Take into account Commonwealth, not state and instrumentality debt.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, we sat in relative silence while Senator Crowley went on with the most absolute rubbish—I think I interjected once. I do not really need protection from Senator Cook, but to hear him say that it is private debt! Public debt now requires us to pay out $10 billion in interest. I will keep saying it because we have to get through to the Australian public that we are paying $10 billion per annum to pay off the debt that we inherited from the former government on the other side. That is what we are paying. We do not have those sorts of resources.

BREAK.PARA: It is not only the $10 billion that we are paying in interest; it is also the $8 billion that we are behind when we were supposed to have a balanced budget last year. Eighteen billion has gone down the tube already: $8 billion that they spent last year after they said they were not going to spend it—they did not tell us until after the election—and the $10 billion we are spending this year paying off the debt. If we had $18 billion we would have so much more to put into well‐targeted and appropriate programs.

Senator Crowley went on about broken promises. Broken promises! I can remember one when we are talking about families: one of their former Prime Ministers said that no child would live in poverty by 1990. What a promise! What happened during the time of the Labor government? The rich got richer and the poor got poorer.

When most of us were growing up—those of us in the chamber who are baby boom age; at the moment there are some in the chamber who are not baby boom age—there was a greater egalitarianism in Australia. In our country we had one of the lowest gaps between the rich and the poor. We had one of the most equal societies. Thirteen years of Labor has seen that whittled away. Now we really have a bimodal distribution of income. We have a high number of people on low incomes and a high number of people on very high incomes.

Instead of a platykurtic curve of distribution of wealth, we now have a bimodal curve showing a large number of people with low incomes and a large number of people with high incomes. That is another legacy of 13 years of Labor. Labor come in here and bleat about the terrible things that the coalition is doing to families. Let me say that Labor repeatedly had policies which were detrimental to families.

I had just forgotten for a moment—but I should never let the Australian public forget—that promise that we were going to have tax cuts: l‐a‐w tax cuts. They were going to be written into law. Yes, families would be better off because: `We won't just make a promise; we will write them into the law.' And then what did we see? Labor reneged and gave them in two tranches. Who is paying for the second tranche? Senator Cook is going out because he does not want to hear it. We are. We are paying for the second tranche of the Labor Party's promise that we would have l‐a‐w tax cuts.
Senator Cook interjecting—

TALK.START.PARA: —It is quite disorderly to have someone shouting out interjections while they are walking out of the chamber, but I suppose it is a good thing that he has actually left.

BREAK.PARA: We had that promise broken, and then we had it put out into two tranches, and we pay the second bill. So we are committed to that. Some more money has gone because Labor made a promise it did not keep.

Senator Crowley came in here and went on about low and middle income families. The Labor government would not bite the bullet with the Medicare levy. We found that a large number of people who can well afford to take out private health insurance do not. Former Prime Minister Keating and former health minister Lawrence have admitted that they do not have private health insurance. We found that people on high incomes have failed to take out private health insurance.

When they get sick and need care, instead of being able to go to one of the now very well equipped private hospitals that can deal with things like acute cardiac arrest and all sorts of major surgery that once upon a time these places were not able to deal with, we find people on high incomes filling up beds in public hospitals. Because many of them have acute needs for surgery, that has squashed out people who need elective surgery for total hip replacements, cataracts, bunions, or whatever else. We found that wealthy and young high income earners, who felt they were immune, did not require private health insurance and were not going to get sick, were making use of public hospital beds and increasing the length of waiting lists in public hospitals.

We found out because former Senator Richardson has become very honest about what happened on the other side now that he is writing in the Bulletin. When he was minister for health, he attempted to bring in an increased levy for high income earners if they did not have private health insurance. He admitted, `I could not get it through cabinet.' He could not get it through cabinet because these people on the other side were prepared to give benefits to high income earners.

I have forgotten his exact words in the Bulletin but it was something like, `Heaven forbid. Here is a Liberal National government saying to high income earners, "If you don't take some responsibility for your own health, we will make you pay a higher Medicare levy."' You would have thought that Labor would have done it.

He was stunned and surprised and shocked and horrified—that is the only way to describe his article—that the Liberal National Party government has chosen to do that. We believe in targeting; we believe in a safety net for those who cannot afford it themselves. We do not believe in propping up those people who can do something for themselves. Our philosophy is that you should look after yourself first and, if you are incapable of doing that, then the state should step in. That leaves more resources for those people who are less well off—the very people they purport to represent.

In the last election the public realised that Labor was not representing them. The battler that Senator Amanda Vanstone met down in Wollongong said to her, `I cannot make ends meet. I have a family. I have two children and a wife who is at home.' When he looked at some people on some benefits, they were getting more than he was as a single income earner. He said, `I cannot vote Labor anymore.' Senator Vanstone brought him up to have dinner in Parliament House on budget night because she had been so moved that he was expressing clearly to her the fact that he was working in a job on average weekly earnings or just above, with a wife and two children at home, and he was getting less than some people on benefits or other programs like Austudy. She thought that there was something wrong with the system.

Senator Vanstone did not tell me that story. A journalist chose to write it in, I think, the Australian about a week ago. Somebody said to me, `Read this story. Isn't it amazing?' And I read it. I had not read it. That was what that person was saying: a battler who had voted Labor all his life had decided that Labor had neglected him and he changed his vote. That was the message that the Labor Party ought to have got and should have got out of the last election.

I have just given the example of funding high income earners in health. But we saw it in child care with the child‐ care cash rebate. I have two friends who are doctors and they were both getting a child‐care cash rebate. They were stunned. They could not believe they were eligible. They said to me, `Has the world gone cuckoo? We are both doctors.' One is an anaesthetist and one is running a quite successful general practice. They have two young daughters. They said to me, `Can you believe, Kay, that we are eligible for a child‐care cash rebate?' They did not expect that.

The former Labor government did not choose to target the rebate. I suppose somebody else will fall out of the woodwork and write an article in the Bulletin. It might even be Senator Richardson who says: `I tried to get that changed.' I know that someone who was totally opposed to it was the former Senator Walsh. He wrote constantly about the inequities in the child-care system. Constantly we saw articles in the Australian Financial Review where he was critical of Labor's child-care policy.

I used to listen with interest to Senator Crowley when she gave answers in the Senate. I find it amazing that people on the other side are so critical of our ministers if they stumble on a word or look down at their notes. It would pay some of the former ministers on the other side to go back and read Hansard—

TALK.START.PARA: —Or watch a video.

—Or watch a video, because some of their performances left a lot to be desired. As I said on one occasion, with one of them in particular sometimes it was verbal fruit salad that came out. You could not understand what they were saying when they answered the question but when you read it, it was just as bad. I want to give the Senate an example of a question about child-care that was asked in the middle of last year by Senator Troeth:

BREAK.PARA: My question is directed to the Minister for Family Services. I refer to my question in Senate estimates in which I asked: how many of the child-care places in this year's budget were actually new child-care places and how many were part of your government's child-care strategy or election promises? The First Assistant Secretary of your department, Mr Barry Wight, replied—
Listen to this. This is classic:
. . . None of them is new. There is juggling of numbers, bringing forward of places. . . There is a different mix of places.
Then Senator Troeth went on to say:

Given this clarification by an officer of your department, how can you then claim, as you do in this year's budget and in Agenda for Families , that you have established and created new child-care places?
I will not read the answer—or maybe I will just read the beginning of the answer. This is Senator Crowley:

For a start, the ongoing commitment to see that those places foreshadowed are built is, in lots of people's minds, certainly a commitment to new places. As well as that, it shows you have not really argued this case before.

It did not answer the question. She goes on. I read the rest of the answer and it does not answer the question. Out of the mouth of one of her officers she was condemned in that they were juggling numbers. So how could she come in here today and criticise our child-care policies when a lot of the things we have had to do are because the former Labor government left this country in dire straits in terms of debt and deficit? She comes in here and says that we have broken promises. I have given a few examples of the broken promises of Labor. She also comes in here and says, virtually—I almost cannot believe it—that we should not target the child-care cash rebate.

The other thing that I thought I should point out, which I did not know, I discovered today when I was finding out more about child care. Senator Crowley is going on about the subsidies being taken off community based long day care programs. I was fascinated to read that community based long day care programs have a greater proportion of high income families in them than does the private sector. The private sector gets no subsidy. The community based long day care places do get subsidies but more of the families using them are from high income areas. In effect, there is no targeting. Senator Crowley needs to go and look at the facts and the figures because she is arguing for no targeting, not saying: `We need to make it fair'.

Our policy is creating greater flexibility. It is targeted to low and middle income families, something the former Labor government was not game enough to do. They did not do it with Medicare and they did not do it with child-care because it was too hard. So we kept on spending and running up debt. We have built into the program some safeguards in a number of areas. They will ensure, for example, that $195 million will be given over four years to retain operational subsidies for occasional care and out-of-school hours care.

Money will also be given to the community based child-care programs to assist them with financial management and dealing with the loss of the subsidy. We have not left them high and dry. We have not withdrawn the subsidy and said: `You go on your own.' There is funding to assist them in managing. The private sector can manage without the subsidy. I think it is approximately $4 a day more in fees. I am sure some of these community based programs could compete if they were given assistance because they do not have some of the costs of the private sector. Some of them, especially those that are run out of churches and other non-profit organisations, have some tax advantages that the private sector does not have.

We are also providing $31 million over four years for children with special needs. So the government is particularly committed to families from rural and remote areas, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander children, children from non-English speaking backgrounds and children with a disability. Also, there is an additional $12.5 million available over four years to ensure that families from severely disadvantaged areas will not lose access to child care. That is what we are doing.

The shadow minister for family services issued a press release titled `Howard's tax initiative rort: families with kids in care lose'. Jenny Macklin needs to get with it and get her facts straight. The figures that she released, and other information that she is sending around to centres, are extremely inaccurate, grossly exaggerated and misleading. When I was shadow minister I made as sure as anything—I know it is difficult because you do not have the resources—that I got the facts right. If I got a fact wrong it was not intentional but because I just did not have the information. I cannot believe that Ms Macklin has got so much wrong.

It would be much more helpful to the majority of families using child care if Ms Macklin and others focused their concerns on the situation of the majority of families instead of on the extreme examples which create undue concern for most families. It is the same thing for aged care; they are running around saying that everybody going into a nursing home will have to pay $26,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is just wrong.
—It is just wrong, Senator Abetz. Pensioners will not have to pay it. Those people with a certain amount of money—I have forgotten the exact figure—will not have to pay it.

BREAK.PARA: They forget to tell people that that $26,000 has a drawdown of $2,600 a year and you can pay for a maximum of five years, so it is only $13,000 plus the interest on the capital. But, no. It is as if every single person has to pay $26,000 up‐front and they will not get a bean of it back. They are doing exactly the same thing with child care. They are going out and scaring people with extreme examples.

This morning on the radio I heard Mr Free—who is going to be the candidate in the by-election—say that all people going into nursing homes will pay $26,000. So the Labor Party have started again on their scurrilous way in exactly the same way they did with the GST—you will pay 15 per cent on everything. They had ads with a cash register indicating the 15 per cent increase. In fact, there was a 20 per cent wholesale sales tax on sheets. Had that gone up sheets would have cost less.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let us not let truth get in the way.

—No, we do not want truth to get in the way of a good story. That is exactly the same thing with child care—let us not let truth get in the way of a good story. We will give them the most extreme examples.

BREAK.PARA: The calculations that Ms Macklin makes are misleading. Firstly, they are based on families using 50, 55 or 60 hours of care per week. Do you know how many low and middle income families are using 50 hours or more care a week? Two per cent of them are using more than 50 hours. The opposition are basing their figures on 50, 55 or 60 hours of care, so their figures apply to two per cent of low and middle income families. On the other hand, around 12 per cent, or 22,500, of low and middle income families are currently charged for more than 50 hours of care but use less.
Secondly, the majority—86 per cent—of all low and

middle income families pay and use significantly less than 50 hours a week. Thirdly, none of the calculations used in the misleading releases even closely relate to the fact that the average family pays for about 26 hours per week.

The family scenarios that Ms Macklin uses are the least typical. That is exactly the same thing that they are doing in the nursing home situation. So we get the very worst scenario and we publicise it everywhere, and we scare the living daylights out of older people with regard to nursing homes and we scare the living daylights out of families.

But we do not say, `Guess what the government is doing!' We are actually targeting child care so that those on middle and low incomes get a better deal—with the limited amount of money we have after the disastrous management of the previous government. That is the goal: to increase flexibility, to target child care and to make sure that we are putting programs in place to ease that transition. As I outlined before, we are enabling various groups to be assisted.

When I analyse Ms Macklin's press release, I am stunned that it is so inaccurate, that it is so full of extreme examples. I hope that the Labor Party lifts its game and is more truthful and more honest and gives the average example rather than the extreme example.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do not hold your breath.

—I am not going to hold my breath, Senator Abetz. The strategy that we are implementing provides child care that is fair, affordable, flexible and of high quality. The opposition needs to listen to what we have to say and to have a closer look at it. We are encouraging greater choice for families and a greater choice for women. That is the point—a lot of women say, `I want greater choice.' We are improving competition in service delivery, and we are reducing the compliance cost for providers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Denman, Sen Kay

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to be able to speak on the issue of child care because it is emerging as a major item in my state of Tasmania, and I can speak only on Tasmania and the contact that I have had with child-care centres. Ever since the budget announcement about the withdrawal of the operational subsidy from community based child-care centres and the fiddling with child-care assistance, I have been in constant contact with the managers and users of community based child-care centres in the north-west of Tasmania, where I live.

SPEECH.PARA: I have also spoken to and received correspondence on this matter from other centres in the state. The central theme arising from my many discussions and correspondence is incredulity. Many have questioned why there was no prior consultation with child‐care providers and parents in Tasmania about this matter. The response has been that not one director I have spoken to supports the statements contained in the audit commission report, and now Liberal policy, that child‐care centres should all be privatised.

They have said to me time and time again that taking away the subsidy may not rebound as drastically in the urban environment of Melbourne and Sydney but it will be disastrous for rural regions which contain small cities and townships that make up Tasmania. Many parents have said, `Why increase subsidies to family based day care while totally cutting subsidies to community based child‐care centres?' People tell me there are advantages in both.

Parents who have experienced both systems of child care have said that community child‐care centres provide that little bit extra in quality of care. The carers are usually well trained and innovative. They don't operate in isolation as do most family based day carers. That is what people have been telling me in the north‐west of Tasmania. I can vouch for the creativity of many of those directors and carers who work in community child‐care centres.

I have not visited one centre in the region where I have not sensed the feeling of true community. Many of the centres have links with local councils, which I think is a worthwhile partnership. Time and time again when I have visited and walked around these centres I have observed heaps of community news. People when they are bringing their children to the centres and collecting them at night collect this matter, take it home and read it. So as well as providing care for the children it provides information from the community and, I might also add, from government.

The centres not only provide the quality of care but also provide something extra that is intrinsic. It is difficult to describe and in many senses it cannot be touched upon physically. But I can honestly say that in all the community based child‐care centres that I have visited there is a sense of community, from the early morning bustle of parents dropping off their children to when the children are collected at night. There is a sense of camaraderie that I doubt would exist in a private child‐care centre of which conservatively at least 60 per cent of parents receive top fee relief in the north‐west of Tasmania.

The day after the budget I rang many community child‐care centres to see what they thought about the cuts. Many were unaware of the gravity of the Liberal Party's decision. Ever since that day, there has been an awakening to just how detrimental this withdrawal of subsidy will be for centres and for the community at large.

I now want to relate some of the comments I have received from the diligent women who run these centres. I have been told, for example, that taking away the operational subsidy will lead to the possible withdrawal of the midday meal for children and of the in-house library service. This in-house library service is really important to some of the parents who receive subsidies because it is the only way they can afford to give their children some of the services the library provides. Further, existing full‐time staff will have to contemplate working part-time.

Another director said that fees would have to increase by at least $20. Another said, `We are still the leading child‐care centre in the town, irrespective of the recent establishment of a private centre. If we have to put up our fees, I can assure you that the private centre will do the same.' I quote from one of the many letters I have received. It says:

Our child‐care centre predicts that its fees will rise at least $20 to $25 per week if government funding is lost, assuming that all places at the centre continue to be filled. Obviously, parents on lower incomes will have to make alternative arrangements or leave work to look after their children, as increases in fees will be beyond their capacity to pay.
The letter continues:

My husband and I strongly object to any increases in fees. The increases could actually be more than those predicted if all child‐care places cannot be filled. We believe the fees are high enough now. This type of budgetary measure is short-sighted, ill-conceived and discriminatory. Has the government realised how far reaching the effects will be? In our case, it soon will not be financially viable for myself to remain in the work force, as after paying substantial child‐care fees, my salary is significantly reduced.

That is an example of one letter I have had amongst many. Even after briefings from the department, the directors of child‐care centres in my area were jointly saying that the full story was not being told about the measures that were going to affect many parents, including single mums. Several directors came to my office for assistance in getting the message about the failure of the government to provide the full picture to parents.

It is clear that as well as services having to increase fees due to the loss of operational funding, family benefits will also be reduced. Entitlements to be reduced as listed by those within the industry are: $30 per dependent child, currently deducted from the family income, when calculating eligibility for child‐care assistance will go; fringe benefits will be considered in calculating eligibility; the ceiling rate of $115 per week will not increase for three years, thereby increasing the gap for parents; eligibility for child‐care assistance and cash rebate has decreased; and child‐care assistance will be available for only 50 hours per week, thereby reducing flexibility of centres for opening to meet family needs.

It cannot be challenged that the child-care profession has in the past five to 10 years come a long way in the provision of high quality child care. Systems in place, for example accreditation for long day care, are attracting international recognition. We cannot afford to take a backward step at this crucial time.

The rhetoric from the government is that there is a commitment to increase flexibility and that opportunities will abound for families reliant on child care, but the budgetary strategies in place are to the contrary and will, according to the industry, in fact decrease family opportunities and choices.

These things that I have quoted have all come to me from the north-west coast of Tasmania—some from other areas of the state, but mainly my duty electorate of the north-west. I have visited child-care centre after child-care centre—Ms Macklin came down and visited child-care centres—and all these issues were drawn to my attention. That is where I draw these facts from. We must not lose sight of the fact that our children are our most precious resource.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Abetz, Sen Eric

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to be able to take part in this debate and debunk some of the myths that have been promoted by those opposite. First of all, in this debate we have been accused of breaking promises. Let us analyse that statement. A promise that is made in good faith and is not broken but for a supervening event which then makes it impossible to keep, is in fact not a broken promise. You see, we went to the last election believing the Labor Party's figures and the supervening event was that the Labor Party did not tell us the truth during the election campaign and we were left with an $8 billion deficit.

SPEECH.PARA: The Labor Party very glibly and cynically refused to accept that fact. That was the supervening event that did not allow us as an incoming government to be able to meet all the commitments we made. But whose fault is that? The Liberal Party? Or is it because the Labor Party had the cupboard bare because of their extravagance and overspending in their desperate attempt to try to remain in office?

Each time the Labor Party denies that budget truth of the $8 billion deficit, they reinforce within the public's mind that they have learnt nothing from their shattering defeat on 2 March, which was of such humiliating proportions. The community feedback overall has been that this is a fair and reasonable budget given the circumstances which confronted us as an incoming government. Overwhelmingly, it has been accepted.

There is a realisation within the community that there is no benefit in bankrupting our children's future for cheap political point scoring and to try to keep ourselves popular with the electorate. If we spend money today that we do not have, we are mortgaging the future of our children. There is no social justice, from whatever angle you may wish to look at it, in spending money that we do not have today on the basis that a future generation will have to pay it back. So let us put this whole debate and the budget into context.

The people of Australia now realise that we do have to bring in the budget deficit. We cannot keep going as we have been. The Labor Party just refuse to acknowledge that they left us with this problem. Sure, they do not have to acknowledge it, but the people of Australia realise there is this problem. They realise that we did not create it, but they do realise that we are going to fix it up. We will and we are committed to doing so because of our commitment to the families and children of this country not to leave them with a legacy of debt but rather an inheritance. We want to leave them with something good.

We did not create the problems and until the Labor Party can come up with an alternative budget strategy which says how they would cover the $8 billion that they left by way of a deficit, they should not get up in this chamber at all and seek to make a contribution to the way the government is arranging the fiscal affairs of this country.

It has been suggested that our policies are anti-family. I have to say that that would come as a surprise for the overwhelming number of people who voted for us at the last election. It would come as a great surprise for those lower income families, with combined incomes of less than $70,000 per annum, who are now going to be saved $1 billion in tax payments. It will come as a real surprise that somehow that measure is anti-family. It will also come as a bit of a surprise to them that $7.70 a fortnight for each dependent child for low income families is also somehow anti-family. I would be interested to hear from those opposite in their next contributions how those sorts of measures are anti-family. It would be really interesting to see how their cerebral processes work in trying to justify that sort of statement.

There will be a $51.90 a fortnight tax break for families on less than $70,000 a year, with two dependent children, who take out private health insurance. Somehow that is anti-family. Because of our measures, interest rates are already coming down. That saves the average family a lot of money each month on the mortgage payments. Yet again, Labor would say to us that that as well is somehow anti-family.

The reality is that we are committed to the family unit. In fact, during the campaign we were ridiculed for wanting to go back to the 1950s and 1960s. That was the catchcry of the Labor Party—that somehow we wanted to go back and really talk about the family unit, and that assistance for the family was nothing really. Of course, the people of Australia said, `It is something, we are concerned and we are going to vote for the government that is committed to the family unit.'

I have noted in recent days that Senator Crowley seems to have got her courage back after her confidence-shattering performance as a minister. She is a minister whose record on child care is best summarised by her refusal to allow Christmas carols to be sung at a child-care centre. They are the sorts of things we remember Senator Crowley for. She is the one who comes in here and says that we as a government somehow hate women because we believe—

TALK.START.PARA: —You do.
—Senator Neal says that we hate women.
—Oh, you don't.

—Thank you, Senator Calvert. Just do not tell my wife that. The reality is that Senator Crowley said—and this is beautiful, it really is—that we believe that all women ought be at home. Let me read something to you:

BREAK.PARA: In the last couple of years the government has boasted about the increasing number of women in the workforce. Rather than something to be proud of, I feel that it is something of which we should be ashamed. . . . Husbands have been forced to send their wives to work in order to provide the necessities of life. Young mothers have been forced out of their homes by economic pressure.

TALK.START.PARA: —People on both sides make mistakes.

—Senator Neal knows who I am quoting—her former leader, the former Prime Minister, Paul Keating. He believed that a woman's place is in the home. So it is very disingenuous of you people opposite to get up and try to visit the views of your Prime Minister upon us and our new Prime Minister (Mr Howard). It is very disingenuous and very silly of you.
—He learned from his mistakes. Have you? Have you learned from your mistakes? He did.

—He has never recanted from that. It is interesting to see that Senator Neal now acknowledges that that was an error. Also—and I was not going to read this out, but in view of the renewed interest in the former Prime Minister by those opposite I will—on the subject of multicultural affairs he said that, `After all, the best migrant is the Australian born infant.' That is a really good multicultural policy—a great multicultural policy! It is great, isn't it? That is the man who led your team to the election last time around.

BREAK.PARA: Senator Crowley quotes from John Howard's previous statements as well. Let me tell you this: if you want to try to embarrass us because of our support for the family unit, go right ahead, because we unashamedly support the family unit. The problem is that those people within the Labor Party are in a real conflict. There are some who really do genuinely support the family unit, but then there are those others like Senator Crowley who are really motivated by the extreme ideological stance of the sisterhood. That is the problem.

Of course, the sisterhood has been let down by the Liberal Party. We have let them down, but we have not let down the other 99 per cent of women in Australia who so overwhelmingly voted for us. The women of Australia recognise how good our policies are, and that is why they voted for them. Of course, it is the Labor Party that have this patronising policy of saying, `Thirty-five per cent of our candidates have to be women. We are not going to choose them on merit or anything else. It just has to be 35 per cent.' Then they could not even live up to that expectation.

What we did in the Liberal Party was to say, `Anybody can run for endorsement. If you are good enough, you'll win.' We have a record number of women in this parliament, not because we had patronising quotas and said, `Oh, these poor little women darlings. We need to help them into parliament, as the Labor Party does.' We say, `The women in our party are equal. They will contest preselections with us as equals.' They have won preselections; they have done very well. Of course, we see them on our front benches now in such excellent performers as Senator Newman and Judi Moylan.

The Labor Party's record is one where the rich got richer and the poor got poorer. That was recognised by former Prime Minister Mr Hawke. So, in a desperate bid to try to regain the initiative, do you know what he promised? He promised that no child would live in poverty by 1990. What a great promise! Senator Crowley has the audacity to come in here and say, `You people break promises.' My goodness! She has the audacity to come in here and say that. It really is disingenuous of you people opposite to try to make something out of this motion and our child-care policies. What you are not telling the people is that our budget establishes a strategic direction which is sustainable in the long term while protecting the benefits of low and middle income families.

TALK.START.PARA: —It contracts the economy. Is that a strategic direction?

—Those are the families, Senator Conroy, that Labor deserted over the 13 years and which we are now looking after. Our measures, I believe, are good and will protect the long-term future of our child-care centres.

BREAK.PARA: I will turn to the matters raised by Senator Denman in her speech. I must say that, out of the speeches from the other side, at least Senator Denman's was a sincere speech—albeit misguided but, nevertheless, it was genuinely sincere. I take it on that basis—unlike the contributions of the other people from the other side.

The community based long‐day‐care sector has played an important part in delivering and improving the quality of child care to Australians over the last 24 years. Guess when the operational subsidies were, in fact, introduced? They were introduced under a Liberal McMahon government in 1972.

Since that time, the child‐care industry has changed dramatically. Private centres have never been eligible for operational subsidies even though they currently provide care for about 70 per cent of all children in long day care centres. What is fair about that? Why is it that the private sector should not be given an operational subsidy but others should, so that parents who happen to have to send their kids to a private centre have to pay more for their child care whereas those who are in the community long day care centres get a subsidy from the taxpayer? I do not think you can argue that proposition and say that that is fair and reasonable, especially when 70 per cent of the children who are the users of the child care get no benefit whatsoever.

The decision to remove operational subsidies from 1 July next year places parents and services on an equal footing. What is more, because we realise that those changes will mean some dislocation within the community and within the industry, we have provided for a lengthy changeover period and set aside substantial funding to assist centres to manage the loss of this subsidy and to ensure that families in disadvantaged areas do not lose access.

Despite withdrawing that operational subsidy, we are still directing our funding to ensure that there is no undue hiatus during the changeover period. Operational subsidies will be retained in family day care, outside school hours care, multifunctional services and multifunctional Aboriginal services—services which, I would submit to the Senate, are crucial to meeting the diverse needs of Australian families.

In relation to our child‐care policy generally, I believe that it is important to note a few very important matters. The package of measures in this budget is clear evidence of this government's ongoing commitment to child care, amounting to $5 billion over the estimates period, and provides the foundations for a coherent national framework for the long-term sustainability of the child‐care sector. Child‐care payments will be made through the new service delivery agency, with parents being given the choice to receive benefits directly or to have them paid to their approved service. It looks as though the lights have gone out on the other side, but I am still with you.

TALK.START.PARA: —Guess who was speaking when they went out, Eric.

—By the sound of your interjection, you were, Senator Woodley. The choice that we give to parents will give them greater control over how they receive their benefits and privacy in respect of who knows that they receive benefits.

BREAK.PARA: There will be no dilution of existing quality requirements for services. The link between child‐care assistance and accreditation will be maintained, and parents and industry will be consulted about implementation. That was one of the matters that Senator Denman raised, saying that there had not been consultation up to this time. I would suggest to her that, to a certain extent, there has. But, because of the transitional period, which is going to be of some duration, and the assistance of extra funding to assist during that transitional period, there will be a lot of consultation. As a result, the matter which Senator Denman quite properly raised as a matter of concern has been thought of and will be addressed, and, therefore, her concerns in that area will be appropriately relieved.

The history of this government's very short term so far, of only six months, has been one which is unashamedly focused on the lower and middle income earners of this country, one which is focused on the family and the proper care for children. Funding has been allocated to assist services, as I have said before, in making the transition to target specific gaps in supply. It is appropriate just to read out a few of those amounts. Some $8.3 million has been set aside over two years to enable community based long day care centres to purchase financial management services to assist them in restructuring their business.

Why did we not hear any of that from those opposite? Because they are embarrassed about the sensitive way in which we are dealing with the budgetary constraints imposed upon us by their mismanagement over the past 13 years. There will be an extra $12.5 million available over four years to ensure that families in severely disadvantaged areas do not lose access to child care. Undoubtedly, that is another cause of embarrassment to the Labor Party—that we have deliberately focused and sought to look after those in severely disadvantaged areas. The Australian Labor Party deliberately does not talk about that.

There is a $10.9 million payment over four years to develop services in remote and rural areas where the private sector will not locate. The area that Senator Denman talked about, the north‐west coast, could well fit into that category and there could be those sorts of concerns addressed. Let me say to her that $10.9 million has been provided for those areas and that $31 million over four years has been provided to enhance access to services for children with high levels of additional needs. Additional funding has been provided to both the community and private services.

Unlike the former minister, Senator Crowley, whose departmental officers gave the game away during estimates, we are not in the business of juggling figures. We are not in the business of saying that there are underlying budget surpluses when clearly there were not. And, of course, we have committed ourselves to be as open as the Australian people have ever had government administration. We make no apology for targeting those in the low income and middle income areas for special attention and special assistance because they were so terribly neglected under the previous government.

I have spoken about the changes in child care and, for some reason, Senator Evans would want us to note those changes with concern. The only matter that we ought to note with great concern is the $8 billion budget deficit with which we were confronted when we came into government. That is a matter of real concern and is the one thing that the Australian Labor Party will never acknowledge.

Let me say, I am quite happy if they do not acknowledge it because the longer they deny that reality the longer they will remain in opposition. The Labor Party know what the people think of them. Gary Grey said it, and Senator Sue Mackay ably assisted him in that report which said the Labor Party stank. What has happened is that we, as a government, are looking after the child‐care industry in a way that is fair to all and, in particular, looks after the 70 per cent who do not get the subsidies that the Labor Party seems to be promoting.

One thing I must commend Senator Evans on is his reference to the Liberal Party's family tax initiative which is specifically targeted at the family. It is now acknowledged, finally, by the Labor Party that the Liberal Party's family tax initiative does exist and does provide benefits. We are told that we ought be noting with concern the reduced choices available to Australians. In fact, they will be given extra choice. The Labor Party have never been in favour of choice. They want to tell everybody how to live their lives and what they should believe in through their political correctness and things like that, but that has been overwhelmingly rejected by the Australian people. They ought to get back into the real world, realise the heyday of the past 13 years is over and that we are now getting on with the job of providing real assistance to the people and families of Australia.

Let us conclude on this note. We, as a government, are committed unashamedly to the family, to the future of our country and to our children. There is no social justice in spending big money today and letting the children pay it off tomorrow. We want to provide our children with an inheritance, not a legacy of debt. Once the Australian Labor Party realise that that is the basis on which we are attacking the problems of government and budgetary responsibility, we might be able to have more constructive debates on a whole range of measures. But whilst they deny the mess that they left and try to say that it does not exist and that we ought to keep spending as though there is no tomorrow and no deficit, we will not be able to have a rational debate on issues.

The thing that fortifies me is that the Australian people do not believe what the Australian Labor Party are saying to them about this budget and about the deficit. They realise there is a problem which needs to be fixed. They realise we did not create the problem and they realise that we have set about to fix it. That is the important thing that the people of Australia are going to find out, have already found out and will continue to find out over the next 2½ years of this current term of government and I look forward to many further terms of a Howard‐Costello government which will deliver true social justice to the people of Australia without mortgaging the future of our children.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was in the chamber to listen to the speech of Senator Troeth and I caught a little of the speech of Senator Patterson on the television. I do not know how much I heard of Senator Abetz's speech—he has been going on for quite a while—but I did catch quite a bit of it, I think. I need to say to the coalition that you are really making these speeches in the wrong place. Somehow or other, you should be out there trying to sell what you are saying to us in here because either the people outside this place are not hearing you or they simply do not believe you. Hundreds of centres and peak bodies and thousands of parents are contacting us.
—Thousands.
—Yes. My fax machine was smoking.
—And your fax machine was smoking.
—Was smoking, Senator Abetz. What I am going to do in a moment is read you as many of those letters and faxes as I can. The problem is that nobody in the community believes you.
—The Liberal Party don't believe him either.

—I don't think they do. Anyway, I do not have to deal with that; that is his problem. There are people not only coming to my office but, as I said, also jamming up my fax machine sending submissions.
