All of them are saying that this government has betrayed them in terms of child care. I want to say one thing that I believe everyone in this chamber would agree with; that is, families are important. I would also add that any other statement about families beyond this is bound to open up vigorous debate. This is especially so when governments try to define what a family should look like. Mind you, they do not have to do that in words. They do not necessarily have to legislate a definition.

BREAK.PARA: Ideological views about family can be promoted by shifting government assistance through budgets. The Democrats would argue that the coalition has determined its preferred family in measures it has taken in the 1996 budget. The Democrats believe that governments ought not to do that. They ought not to try to define nor confine families in this way. Surely, the role of government in regard to Australian families ought to be to set a framework within which all of our families, whatever shape they might take, will be encouraged to reach their full potential. A very important part of that framework is what governments do with child care. For that reason, the Democrats are concerned about the negative impact which many of the government's proposed changes to child care will have on families. There is little doubt that many of these changes—the abolition of operational subsidies to community based centres, the 50‐hour cap on child‐care assistance per child per week, the abolition of the additional income allowed for additional dependent children and the two‐year freeze on child‐care assistance and the child‐care cash rebate—will impact significantly on the cost and accessibility of child care for many families.

The Democrats recognise the tremendous pressure many families face in juggling work and family commitments. We recognise that for many families the financial benefit of working now only just outweighs the cost of child care. The Democrats are now deeply concerned that any significant increase in the cost of child care will force at least some parents to take their children out of formal care altogether. This will leave many families with two choices. One is that one parent will have to give up work to care for the children full‐time; or they will have to look for alternative, less formal, and therefore also less regulated, forms of child care—backyard child care, if you like. We do not believe that forcing parents out of the work force or forcing parents to place their children in forms of child care which are not subject to quality control is an acceptable or desirable choice.

So much for the government's pledge to make things better for families through the new family tax initiative. Many families will now need this new payment just to meet the increased cost of child care, the increased cost of medicines, the probable increase in the cost of going to the doctor, the increased cost of going to the dentist, increased higher education repayments, the increased cost of nursing home expenses, and the increased cost of home and community care services.

The Democrats are still considering what their response to many of these changes will be. But I can give you this guarantee: in determining our position, we believe it is very important to take time to listen to those who are going to be most affected by these changes. The Democrats have been consulting widely with parents, child‐care providers and peak bodies. I can assure you that our final position on the child‐ care budget will be very much in line with our long‐held commitment to quality, affordable and accessible child care.

We believe that all parents should have a real choice when it comes to combining work and family responsibilities. We believe all families should have a real choice about the type of care they want for their children. We support a mixture of family day care and community based, work based and private child‐care centres as the most practical and equitable way of providing the range of services required. Because of that, we do not believe that ideologically driven definitions of what an acceptable family should be, dressed up as changes in a budget, are acceptable either to us or to the majority of Australian families.

Let me turn to the faxes which seem to amuse the government so much. It seems as though they are prepared to laugh at the agony of people as they struggle to understand their future. Let me read a few excerpts from some of the correspondence I have received on these issues. I believe this will give senators an insight into what Australian families understand they are facing. This person says:

I searched a long time for child care that would ensure that my son & daughter would thrive and be loved and cared for and would allow me to return to the workforce and my chosen career with some peace of mind. I found that at a community based centre, which created a happy, safe & secure environment, had highly trained staff, an excellent developmental program and most of all, one where the staff became part of an "extended" family for us, because of the care they provided for my children. . . Our children are a precious resource in our community and I resent the fact that their care is being treated like a saleable commodity and financial bargaining point—all in the interests of PRO‐FAMILY CUTS.
I presume they mean tax cuts. The person continues:
If family is so important then surely its time to stand up for the rights of families and support them in providing affordable and quality child care.
Another person—again, someone whom the coalition seems to want to dismiss by laughing at the fact that they have contacted my office—says this:

My four year old daughter attends a community day care centre in the Northern suburbs of Perth. . . The impact this Budget cut will have on me personally is that I may have to reconsider whether or not to remain in the workforce . . . My husband is not on a high salary. We have a mortgage, a car loan and very little disposable income once our bills have been paid. However, we want to continue to pay our way and work towards financial security for the future.
Another person—again, someone whom the coalition apparently would dismiss by their laughter—wrote to me as follows:

We wish to express our dissatisfaction with the new guidelines laid down in the 1996 Budget. With the new fees in force, we will have no option other than to reconsider the viability of a second income and therefore will have to reconsider day care altogether as trying to squeeze a further $50 or so a week in addition to our fees will be near to impossible.
Another parent wrote:

I am a single parent and if the fees are increased I will have to take my child out of the centre. I will have to stop studying which will be really disappointing as I want to create a better future for my child.
Finally, another parent wrote:

The cuts to community long day care centres will result in the closure of community based centres as parents will be hard hit by the ensuing fee increases. At the centre that my 3 year old son attends, I have been told to expect increases in the vicinity of $26.00 per week. As a full time student, I will not be able to absorb these costs and, as a result, will have to withdraw my son from the centre.

While there are some positives for families in the budget, let me acknowledge that, for many other families the pain will outweigh the gain. This is despite the claim that the budget is fair because all are supposed to share the pain. Let me point out that it is quite obvious that the equal treatment of unequals leads to gross injustice. In this budget, the rich have been slapped with a feather while the poor have been bashed with a mallet.

I believe that this government is engaged in the most radical experiment in social engineering this country has seen in a generation. It seems to be almost a kind of religious crusade. I abhor what is being done to families. I, as do the Democrats, support very strongly this motion.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the motion (Senator Chris Evans's ) be agreed to.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 11 September, on motion by Senator Panizza:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert, Sen Paul

TALK.START.PARA: —Unfortunately, I was not in the chamber to say a few words about this Public Works Committee report when it was tabled on my behalf by Senator Panizza earlier in the week. I will take this opportunity to make a few comments now. It is the 59th general report of the Public Works Committee, the oldest committee of the parliament. It deals with the activities of the Public Works Committee during 1995. It was certainly a very busy year. I am sure my colleagues in the chamber would be interested to hear about it when they sit down.
—When they hear about it.

—Senator Murphy, you were a member of that committee and you know that we met on 98 occasions, we conducted 32 public hearings and we conducted 40 inspections. It is no wonder that the travelling allowance of some of us was very high. We met at locations throughout Australia, not just in capital cities and major regional centres, where one would expect the bulk of Commonwealth public works proposals to be constructed. We ranged far and wide, going to remote locations such as Christmas Island, Maralinga, Ceduna, Puckapunyal and Canungra, to name just a few of the places we had to work.

SPEECH.PARA: We presented 29 reports on projects estimated to cost in excess of $1.5 billion. It was certainly a very busy year compared to others. In 1994 we presented 14 reports on $320 million worth of projects. In 1993 we presented only nine reports on works costing something like $252 million. In 1992 we presented 21 reports on works costing $1.4 billion. By any criteria, this was one of the busiest and most productive years in the committee's long history.

The parliament and the people of Australia were very well served by the committee, whose role is essentially that of a watchdog of Commonwealth public works. The committee examined projects wide-ranging in purpose and cost. In terms of their stated purposes, they ranged from defence projects to office accommodation, law courts, CSIRO laboratories, overseas works, soil decontamination and defence housing. In terms of costs, these ranged from $6.8 million for a Defence Housing Authority project at HMAS Cerberus to a massive $264 million project in the Northern Territory on stage 2 of the Army presence in the north project.

Defence housing projects costing more than $232 million were examined during the year. They involved housing developments at Canungra, Westernport, Darwin and Townsville. I think my colleagues from the Public Works Committee would agree that the standard of housing that is being erected for our defence personnel at present is of excellent quality and certainly is long overdue for our defence personnel.
The committee also reported an overseas public works estimated to cost something like $74 million, although we do not have the opportunity to visit those projects and peruse them at first hand.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why not?

—When Senator Foreman was the chairman of this committee, I believe he had the same problem. Every time we present a report we make the same comment. It is also interesting to note that of all the projects we have during the year, no matter how big the budget is, the ones we have the most problems with and the ones that tend to cause us the most concern are the overseas projects. A good example of that was the Australia House refurbishment this year. After having approved the project for some $7 million, there was a blow-out in the cost for no explained reason. When we carried out some investigations we found that they had omitted certain things, including the cabling for the computers, costing half a million dollars.

SPEECH.PARA: At present the Overseas Property Group provides us with videos of the new sites or of existing conditions and a model of what is supposed to be constructed. I think our committee has been highly critical of some of the standards of the buildings that have been built overseas, particularly given the fact that they are supposed to reflect Australian culture and heritage. Unfortunately, the ones I have seen over the years are not the sort of buildings that I would think stand up under any standards. Tokyo is a good example. We attempted to get around these unsatisfactory arrangements by the chairman and the deputy chair, in particular, using the opportunity when they were overseas on other business to look at some of these projects.

The committee's concerns over the year have resulted in a review of energy standards, which is quite significant. The committee also continued to insist that solar hot water heaters be provided in houses being constructed by the Defence Housing Authority.

In a number of instances environmental clearances were not obtained before projects were referred to the committee. In one instance this resulted in a proposed site here in Canberra being declared unsuitable for development due to the presence of an endangered species of earless dragon lizard. The result was that a new site had to be found and additional expenditure of $650,000 was incurred.

One area of concern involves soil or site contamination: the rehabilitation of the former British nuclear test site at Maralinga in South Australia is a case in point. We were very privileged to see the new technology being used there. Using high voltage they are going to fuse the soil so that any plutonium that is still there will be held in suspension to reduce the risk of any contamination of the local Aboriginal people. The cost of this particular project was $104 million, but I am happy to say that about half of the cost was borne by the British taxpayers. As is our practice we spent a day at Maralinga, during which the Commonwealth experts in nuclear test site remediation showed us the extent of the problem and the ways in which contaminated soil and test detritus will be made safe. The technique is called in situ vitrification, I believe. As I said, it is where the two electrodes in the soil melt the soil into a glass‐like substance and it holds all the nasties in suspension.

Other projects involving remediation or uncertainty were the sites selected for a housing development in Darwin and the need for the site of the Australian Embassy complex in Hanoi and the new high commission in Port Moresby to be declared free of unexploded ordnance. The cost of projects continued to be a matter of concern, especially professional fees for consultants and the considerable sums of money set aside for contingencies, particularly in the UK.

The report gives well‐deserved credit to the untiring efforts of two former members of the committee: Ray Braithwaite and Ben Humphreys. Throughout the past year and previous years they continued to question sponsors and designers about mechanisms designed to deter collusive tendering, and guaranteed the payment of subcontractors. In fact, as a result of Mr Braithwaite's concerns, I think the Braithwaite amendment, as we call it, will be coming through to ensure that in the future subcontractors are always catered for and will not lose out if the contractor goes broke. The latter is now covered by Australian Standard 2124, which should serve as the basis of any tender documents the Commonwealth is involved in. On the question of collusive tendering—otherwise known as anti‐competitive conduct—we know that the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission found evidence of it in the Brisbane concrete market and has imposed heavy fines. I hope this serves as a lesson to the construction industry.

The report acknowledges the leadership of the former chairman of the committee, the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) during 1995, which marks the tenth year of his appointment to the committee and his eighth year as chairman. I am sure that the chamber recognises that under his leadership the Public Works Committee has earned a very enviable reputation as a watchdog.

Last evening we had a dinner to farewell the secretary, Peter Roberts, and Denise Denahy, who are both very good servants of the Public Works Committee. It was interesting to see that Ray Braithwaite, Ewen Cameron, and Bert James—a former Labor Party chairman of the Public Works Committee—were in attendance. I would like to take the opportunity to wish Peter Roberts—the long serving secretary of the committee—and Denise Denahy all the very best in their retirement. I commend the report to the Senate. (Time expired)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy, Sen Shayne

TALK.START.PARA: —I would just like to say few words with regard to the committee's 59th report and the fact that I was appointed to this committee on 10 February 1995. Initially I was not too interested in the committee. I was not quite sure what it was supposed to do—as sometimes seems the case with some committees. Certainly in the time that I have been involved with it, with regard to the staff of the committee, I have to say—not unlike Senator Calvert—that it is one of the best staffed committees that I have seen. Peter Roberts and Denise Denahy certainly deserve congratulations. Michael Fetter and, of course, the other staff of the committee made it run it as efficiently as it did.

SPEECH.PARA: The committee had 23 references in one year and reported on 20 of them. I think it is a fairly reasonable effort, particularly when you consider the amounts of money and the projects that the Public Works Committee deals with. One thing I have found somewhat concerning is how often departments come forward with projects that seem to have a fixed price. It is never a fixed price and it blows out quite substantially. In fact, so much so in some cases that it is almost unbelievable.

There are three in particular that I would like to make reference to: the proposed decontamination of the former explosives factory at Albion in Victoria, the refurbishment of Australia House in London, and one—yet to be reported on and a decision taken—which relates to the rock fall defence on Christmas Island. That was rather interesting. The department had spent some $12 million or thereabouts refurbishing some buildings below a cliff. Within 12 months they had decided that somehow some rocks might fall down, so they had to shift the population out of those buildings which had been refurbished. They wanted to spend another $22 million building new buildings somewhere else.

I was rather curious about it in terms of the rock fall: when the last rock fell and what the percentages of opportunity might be for people actually being killed or creating some liability for Commonwealth. Of course, most of the people who lived in that area in those buildings actually thought it was some big con job to get them out so as to make it into tourist accommodation. It was rather interesting.

More recently, we had the Federal Police, the Department of the Environment, Sport and Territories, and the Department of Industrial Relations put up proposals to us here in Canberra for building new accommodation buildings within the Barton centre. This is another very important aspect of this committee's work as it relates to the ACT and the development and management of it, and also the Commonwealth's responsibilities that continue within the ACT.

There seems to be very little cooperation or discussion that takes place between the various bodies that have some responsibility for the planning of the ACT at an ACT government level. Recently, when the public works committees met in the ACT Assembly, I actually put a question to the chairman of that meeting about why it is that there seems to be very little communication between the three bodies that actually have some responsibility for planning within—

TALK.START.PARA: —Two planning bodies doing something.

—Yes, two planning bodies that do not seem to talk one another. When we were actually dealing with the applications of the various departments for new buildings within the Barton centre—or the Golden Triangle as it is known here—the ACT Assembly opposed them, as did a number of other local interests and local government groups. Because Canberra is basically a bunch of satellite type cities, the planning was given no consideration as to where these things ought to be located in terms of the best interests, the other resources and also the services that need to be provided.

SPEECH.PARA: In the 59th report we dealt with some very important issues: the decontamination at Maralinga, Defence housing and the planning for Defence housing. Clearly, some departments have their act together but, in so far as many of them go, the issue of cost overruns is an unacceptable practice. Hopefully, as time goes by, we will see a greater ability on their part to bring proposals before the committee ultimately responsible for making recommendations to the government, or to the minister responsible for the expenditure of funds, in a more efficient and exacting way because it will be the only way that we will allow for a more exact expenditure process—in terms of the budget process—overall.

In the very short period that I have been on the committee, I was quite amazed at just how often departments would come back for very sizeable increases in expenditure. Quite often, it was for things that you would have thought ought to have been staring them in the face in the first place. Even though the departments were quite often questioned about these matters by the committee in the first instance, we were quite regularly given assurances that it would not be the case that they would be back for another bucketful of money. The reality was quite different.

Like Senator Calvert, I commend the report. I would also like to commend the former chairman, Mr Colin Hollis, who, I have to say, ran the committee in a very efficient way. We always had to be on time. If we were not on time, we always got a kick up the backside. The now chairman, Neil Andrew, who was the deputy chairman, is also doing an admirable job of chairing the committee. The committee provided me with the opportunity to see a great number of places, many of them very interesting. I commend this report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report of Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts References Committee

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 9 September, on motion by Senator Lees:
That the Senate take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Carr, Sen Kim
SPEECH.PARA: First of all, in speaking to this report, I would like to thank the secretariat and the support staff who had a particularly difficult job in the preparation of this report. That was made more difficult as a result of the shoddiness of so many of the government departments and agencies which were so late in their responses to questions. It was made so much more difficult as a result of the evasion of so many of the Telstra officials who appeared before the committee; they were making answers to questions as remote as possible from the questions that they were actually asked.

The fact that so many other particulars of the questions were not responded to adequately—this is particularly the case with regard to the revelations that this committee uncovered about project Mercury, and the details of the scoping study—demonstrated beyond any possible doubt that this government has embarked upon a program of destroying Telstra as part of its drive for privatisation.

It is quite clear, as Mercury documents have revealed, that this government is set upon a course of action to destroy Telstra by the removal of one‐third of the employees of Telstra as part of its program to minimise its costs effectiveness and therefore produce a better result as part of the scoping study and as part of the prospectus. That means that the real question about the cost of privatisation of Telstra is very much being borne by the 24,000 Australian workers and their families who have been identified under project Mercury to go as a result of this government's privatisation drive.

As far as I am concerned, this report and inquiry demonstrated my long held view that the selling of Telstra to private shareholders is not in the public's interest. If we put ideology and rhetoric aside, we will find that there is no substantive argument for the privatisation of Telstra.

Of the 650 submissions received, and the 135 witnesses who appeared before the committee, the only real supporters for the privatisation of Telstra were the government departments—under the direction of the Minister for Communications and the Arts—and the officials of Telstra. I might add that the Telstra officials would enjoy quite considerable benefits as they moved to privatisation as a result of the movement to private salaries and all the bonus shares that come with that, as we have seen with all other privatisations that have occurred in so many other government departments.

BREAK.PARA: In Victoria we saw the most obscene of this, where the chief executive managed to pick up a salary package of some $8 million. In that case Jeff Kennett had sold off TABcorps and introduced a whole new regime which saw public benefits being stripped away and private benefits being accorded to the shareholders. Nothing could be further from the public interest, particularly in the case of Telstra.

We have seen a purely illusionary economic justification for this sale. Telstra has set a record profit in its return to this parliament through the public purse and has produced a magnificent result in so many areas of world's best practice. In so many areas of its financial performance it is way above world's best practice. You will not hear that from this government, which is determined to talk down the performance of Telstra in an effort to find some reasons as to why it should try to get its hands on $8 billion. This is part of its program of bribes to the Australian people and political blackmail involved with this program of privatisation to fund its so-called environment programs—programs which ought to be funded properly out of its budget.

The use of international studies by government agents has been cited to try to demonstrate some sort of international respectability. The World Bank study, in particular, looked at some 6,800 cases of privatisation. Some 6,100 of them were in Eastern Europe, Latin America and the Caribbean and 4,500 of them were in the former German Democratic Republic.

The officials were brought before the committee and asked: `Can you demonstrate an occasion where privatisation has worked well and for the benefit of the public in circumstances similar to those of Australia's economy, its social structure, its demography and its geography?' `No,' was the answer right across the board. In fact, there is no example relating to the privatisation of a company with the same profit levels and the same regulatory authority as Telstra—none whatsoever. It is quite clear. This government has sought—for rhetorical, not empirical reasons—a politically engineered, ideologically driven program aimed at ensuring the destruction of one of Australia's great companies, possibly one of the world's great companies.

TALK.START.PARA: —You hypocrite! You incredible hypocrite!
—I hear the pipsqueaks on the other side of the chamber.
—Order! Would you withdraw the use of the word `hypocrite', please, Senator Campbell?
—It is a descriptive word, Madam Acting Deputy President, to describe a previous government which sold Qantas, CSL, Australian Airlines, the Commonwealth Bank—
—Order! Senator Campbell, would you withdraw? You know that that word is out of order.
—Senator Carr might describe to the Senate—
—Will you withdraw that word?
—I withdraw.
—Thank you.
—What this is about is trying to transfer control one of Australia's most important economic assets from the public arena to the private arena.
—Tell us about Qantas, Kim Carr, and the Commonwealth Bank. You are a mob of hypocrites!
—Senator Campbell, would you withdraw that word and would you not use it again in this place?

—Madam Acting Deputy President, I understand, and I do not want to canvass your ruling, that to refer to a group of people as `hypocrites' is parliamentary. If it is unparliamentary, I withdraw it, but I understand that referring to a group of people as `hypocrites' was common practice by previous government members as they described us in opposition.
—I am advised that if it is senators opposite it is unparliamentary, but if it is more general it is not unparliamentary. In those circumstances I would still ask you to withdraw.
—The words I used were `a mob of hypocrites', which I think is about as general as you can get.

—On a point of order: obviously, a check of the record would indicate exactly what was said, but I took it that it was a direct reference to me and others. This particular senator once objected to a Labor senator using the word `bloody'. I think somebody who applies that standard ought to withdraw under the circumstances in which I took it—and I think other senators on this side took it—as a direct reference to us as senators.

—On the point of order: if you require me to withdraw, I will do so. However, to refer to `a mob of hypocrites' is about as general as possible. Out of deference to Senator Carr's strongly held political beliefs—and I am sure he did not support the sale of Telstra or of the Commonwealth Bank—I decided not to call him a hypocrite. But to call a group of people `a mob of hypocrites', I think, is parliamentary. However, I will, if you require me to withdraw it, do so immediately.

—Senator Campbell, we seem to be having a fairly inappropriate debate about language which, whether or not it is technically unparliamentary, is still inappropriate. In those circumstances I would prefer that you withdrew it, even though it may not technically be unparliamentary.
—I withdraw.

—This committee was able to demonstrate that there is no substantive argument in favour of the privatisation of Telstra. We were able to discover through the project Mercury document that there will be a massive loss of jobs. I am particularly concerned at the attitude of Telstra officials. In the report that attitude is referred to in some detail on page 115. I draw that to the attention of senators. I am particularly con cerned about the attitude of officers from the Finance Department as well as Treasury, about the way answers were given and at how, it seems to me, answers were not being clearly put to direct questions and the manner in which the use of in-confidence material was presented to the committee, which clearly was not of that category. It was a terrible abuse of this process of the Senate and, frankly, it does no credit to the officers of the department to appear before the committee—(Time expired) I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

BREAK.PARA: Leave not granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles, Sen Susan

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise as a member of the Environment, Recreation, Communications and the Arts Committee to speak to the report relating to the Telstra bill. I have to say that Senator Carr's contribution today has been as breathtaking as the contribution of the opposition parties throughout the whole inquiry. I found the inquiry to be absolutely the most unrealistic waste of money that I have ever seen in my almost 12 years in this place. For the opposition parties—the Democrats and the Labor Party—to wilfully spend taxpayers' money to the degree that they did on an inquiry about which they had already made up their minds prior to the first hearing date is scandalous.

SPEECH.PARA: Madam Acting Deputy President, they went to your fine town of Townsville, which is a beautiful town. But they spent $3.34 per second to go up there and listen to two witnesses whose evidence at best could be called questionable and at worst could be called, in one particular case, outrageous. There was absolutely no point at all to be made in this exercise other than to turn the whole question of the partial privatisation of Telstra into a farce, with the Labor Party engineering witness after witness after witness to talk about a whole lot of unrelated issues.

PARA.BREAK: We saw submission after submission being completely and utterly repetitive of the issues that had been raised by the Labor Party in the hearings and just coincidentally appearing in the submissions of many of those who gave evidence. The allegations that were made time and time and time again about the implica tions and ramifications of the bill were also pretty breathtaking.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to look at the statements of the Labor Party about the unemployment impact in the context of their record. We have a party on the opposition benches now which was in government for 13 years and which privatised completely Australian Airlines, a la Qantas, and which privatised completely the Commonwealth Bank and the Commonwealth Serum Laboratories without a blink of an eye in spite of the fact that it gave an assurance prior to a number of elections that it would do the reverse.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where was Kim Carr then?

—Exactly, Senator Campbell, where were they all then? Where did they line up to vote when it came to selling off those public assets? Why is there a change of heart now? There is a change of heart only because there is a change of government. That is the only reason that you have taken a different position on this from that which you have taken before.

SPEECH.PARA: If one had listened completely to the credible evidence given by individuals who were not primed up like those unions and so forth who came before the committee, one would find that there were guarantees of service obligations and that there would not have been what was alleged there would be—timed local calls. That was a Labor Party suggestion many years ago. Because of the electoral damage that that caused them in the federal seat of Adelaide—they lost the federal seat of Adelaide—they are trying to turn that into a ramification of this bill. It is absolutely and utterly untrue.

They have tried to imply that there will be ramifications in rural and regional parts of Australia. Why is it then that those people who actually live in and represent those areas came before the committee and gave contrary evidence? Why is it that the National Farmers Federation, who would have a far better idea about what is going on in the bush than any of the people sitting opposite, came before us and said that over 60 per cent of their membership agreed with the partial privatisation of Telstra?

BREAK.PARA: Why is it that Western Australian rural women came before the committee and vociferously defended the position that they believed that the partial privatisation of Telstra would give them a better deal, would stop Telstra charging outrageously for repairs and installations at various times? It is absolutely and utterly absurd. This is a situation where the key and fundamental issues that were brought out in evidence at this committee have been totally and utterly overlooked.

I have a list here of all the Commonwealth asset sales conducted by the former Labor government since 1987. So this list is not even a comprehensive list; it is only a partial list. Let me give you some classic examples. We do not have any excuse as to why the Labor Party has opposed the partial privatisation of Telstra when they have sold things like the lease of Chifley Square in Sydney, the Commonwealth phosphate rock stockpile, the Commonwealth Government Centre in Melbourne, the Paris head of mission residence, the Commonwealth Accommodation and Catering Service, the Commonwealth equity in the Primary Industries Bank of Australia, the National Materials Handling Bureau and Williamstown dockyard—a further $1.2 million in 1988-89.

The list goes on and on. There was also the Tokyo embassy sale redevelopment project, the defence service homes scheme, Australia House in Sydney, the sale of property to Film Australia, the ACT housing loans assistance scheme and the Australian Industry Development Corporation. The list is endless. That is only the first two pages, and there are many more pages to go.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has it got the Labor Party's soul on that list?

—No, unfortunately it has not, Senator Campbell. This is not even a comprehensive list in terms of 13 years of Labor administration of the Commonwealth assets that were just simply flogged off for no good reason. Here we are talking about a partial privatisation—a partial privatisation—and it has been so badly misrepresented.

BREAK.PARA: If this Labor Party were really desperate to get it right, it would not be misrepresenting things the way it is. Once again, we were told that 700 people would lose their jobs in Townsville. Witnesses were repeatedly asked: on what basis would 700 people in Townsville lose their jobs in Telstra? At the end of the day we found out by a circuitous route that in fact the number was arrived at because that was the total number of Telstra employees in Townsville so they must all lose their jobs because Telstra was going to be partially privatised—the most illogical nonsense that one could possibly dream up.

Yet one of the their own witnesses—in fact, a couple of their own witnesses, but one in particular—whom they thought they had primed up so well spilt the beans. I will quote from the report as follows:
. . . Mr McLean, Queensland branch secretary, communications division, CEPU, had this exchange with Senator Tierney:
Tierney: Those job losses (in Telstra) are primarily driven by technology?
McLean: Yes. The major driver is technology.
Tierney: You would agree that these technological changes will continue?
McLean: Yes, and the union recognises that.

Tierney: Given that you have said that job losses are basically technologically driven, that will go on regardless of whether Telstra stays in full private ownership or is partly privatised, will it not?
McLean: For jobs that are technically driven it does not matter about ownership.

One of their own mates admitted that the scare campaign that had been run on the unemployment issue was not as a consequence of this. Mind you, the other thing Labor did not mention was that its policies had seen 19,000 people lose their jobs in Telstra under Labor administration. Did Labor mention that? No way. We cannot muddy the waters with the truth.

The problem with this whole inquiry was that it was so skewed right from the word go. The report could have been written before the first hearing and there was absolutely no consideration of the evidence that was given in a substantial fashion. That is how we have ended up with a majority report—a majority report that has not been based on the evidence that was provided to the committee about the benefits of partial privatisation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: —I am speaking tonight in relation to the tabled document Telstra: To sell or not to sell? In the last few years there has been what I believe to be a dangerous trend in legislation. This trend is to pass hastily drafted legislation which provides a basis for action but which contains insufficient safeguards or guidelines about how things are to be done or even what is to be done.

SPEECH.PARA: We had another example today in debating the Airports Bill. In putting it together the community consequences were not looked at and many of those are still coming out now. We have seen the World Trade Organisation bills and the competition policy bill which fit that model. These cases were brought together by the previous government. Both major parties agreed, but I can tell you many of the consequences will not come out for years.

Inadequate public provisions, inadequate attention or even comprehension of the implications is what we are seeing. Bills are rushed through with instruction from cabinet and shadow cabinet that no amendments or delays be allowed. Issues raised by the community, the Greens and Democrats receive virtually no response from government or opposition. We have seen those bills, like the World Trade Organisation bills and the competition policy bill, where a great deal of information was provided to committees and the recommendation was that the bills be passed unamended.

This report examines the bill to sell Telstra and concludes that selling Telstra is a bad idea. It recognises that the current dual carrier situation is not good. It points out that the current exemption from state or local laws and regulations by telecommunication companies is not good. It points out that the situation that will pertain after 1997, when any company is supposed to be allowed to compete with Telstra and Optus, is unclear.

I would like to point out that many of the problems which I see related to this—and I will explain a little more in relation to Austel—are in fact related to the fact that the bill on competition policy, which both parties put through last year, was also rushed through. It basically provides the basis for the future operation of any telecommunication carriers in Australia. This report points out that the situation for service providers is also unclear. The whole issue of the implication for non‐telephone communications is unclear. We have just seen suggestions that there would be a separate rate for local calls involved in electronic transfers. Will these calls remain untimed?

In fact, we have an inquiry currently going on to examine the definition of standard telephone service, which will not report for some time. We are being asked to pass this bill and then to view the report on whether passing this bill in its present form is a good idea and what it actually means in terms of universal service obligations. If the standard telephone service changes, then our universal service obligations change in a large way—lots of money and there is obvious in‐built conflicts of interest in terms of sale price.

This is the calibre of the legislation. It is obviously not being informed by real thought or investigation. The decisions on which this legislation is based are obviously not being informed by ordinary economics which, in the evidence given by Professor Quiggin, shows that it is economically more beneficial to retain Telstra and receive the profit flow than to sell it. There is a guarantee that there should be phone services to rural users. They are already disadvantaged by a huge range of cuts and transfers, the institution of user pays, and the elimination of cross-subsidies that results in higher costs for everyone not living in a major metropolitan area.

As the report notes, there is little recognition of the quality of the service or the non‐telephonic telecommunications costs and availability of the services. This bill might as well have been written in the 1960s. There is little or no recognition that computer networking can provide a low‐cost option that allows, for example, children in rural schools access to cultural and informational resources they cannot duplicate or access in their towns. I particularly support the consumer protection recommendations in this report, such as Nos 15 through 17 and Nos 19 through 23. I also support recommendations Nos 23 to 36 on cabling.

BREAK.PARA: I would like to point out that there is a problem with reality here. Even if you have a recommendation which looks at strengthening Austel, there is no mention in this report that Austel will not be there after next year. The functions of Austel will be absorbed into the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission. What does that mean? It means that already, as I mentioned before, the decisions that were taken in parliament in relation to rushing through the competition bill will in fact override many of these concerns. Public interest in its real sense will be in fact equated with profitability and corporate interest via the Competition and Consumer Commission. It is ironic that evidence from the consumers association seemed to show concern that the consumers themselves will benefit from this outcome.

We also support the major recommendations that Telstra remain in public hands and that the bill be split into two bills, one for the sale and one concerning the consumer service guarantee. That would obviously depend on how the bills would look, if that were the case. I do wish to make a suggestion, however. I think there is an assumption that the Senate might defeat the sale bill but the customer service guarantee bill might pass. It is what many of us might prefer to see. The reality is that a deal may be done that would allow the sale bill through while a customer service bill, especially if amended by the Senate, may languish in the House where government has control. My suggestion is that the Senate assure that the sale bill, if passed in some form, include in its commencement a requirement for the customer service guarantee bill to be passed before the sale bill comes into effect.

I would like to make one particular comment in relation to words from Senator Knowles that evidence in Townsville was questionable and outrageous. I listened in where I could, sometimes by teleconference, to the evidence of this inquiry. The most outrageous thing I heard through all the inquiry was the way the witnesses were treated, the way the witnesses were denigrated and the way witnesses were often harassed. I listened with shame.

I had people contacting me who were concerned—I have mentioned this in the chamber before—about appearing before the committee because they had heard how other witnesses were treated. This is disgraceful. Ironically, some of the Hansard that has been repeated in the government senators' minority report highlights some of their responses, such as to Stephanie Mayman in Western Australia as to whether or not she knew every word of the bill. The words of the inquiry were carefully chosen. It was quite acceptable, in my view, that people talk to a term of reference and not be harassed by the senators at that inquiry.

TALK.START.PARA: —They wouldn't know every word of the bill.

—I am certain they would not know every word of the bill. I really liked the particular line of questioning that was responded to by Professor John Quiggin in Townsville when he was asked why he was the only economist who used that particular discount rate in calculating the value of a national asset. He said that there were a number of economists who have a similar view and he outlined quite a substantial list of them. Senator O'Chee's response was that he did not think he had heard of any of those and did any of them have any standing. Professor Quiggin said, `One of them is a Nobel prize winner.' That was the standard of denigration of witnesses at this inquiry—a person giving a view, which in this case was supported by a Nobel prize winning economist, was denigrated for the value of his contribution.

BREAK.PARA: I think it is a very sorry way to conduct an inquiry, which basically was the only means by which the community would really have a chance to have some view and some say. That is the point of an inquiry—not for us, but for the community to have some means of input into the whole process before it gets to a vote. That is the reason for an inquiry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Murphy, Sen Shayne

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to make a few comments with regard to this report in respect of its consideration of the dilution of public ownership of Telstra. Of course, as has been said many times, the situation regarding Telstra really is the issue of what is fundamental to nation building in this country and the provision of services, services that can be provided to all Australians equally. I think that is one of the very important factors that Telstra has been able to achieve. The fact that we have one of the world's highest percentages of access to telephones—some 97 per cent of Australians have that—clearly demonstrates the real community value of having Telstra kept in public ownership.

SPEECH.PARA: There is simply no way, in terms of any future situation with partial or indeed, as Senator Alston said, complete privatisation of Telstra, you would ever be able to deliver that in future, particularly as it relates to new technology. I think more and more it would be the case that people who may well purchase part or all of Telstra simply would not—no government could expect them to—provide the sort of funding that would be required to meet the community service obligations.

Another very important aspect of this is the way the government has sought to link the sale of Telstra to the $1 billion `best ever' environment package. Of course, the government would like us and the Australian public to believe that their environment package was the best ever and that they are the real environmentalists of the Australian political scene. I find that really interesting.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have never said that.

—Senator Campbell says, `We have never said that.' I would suggest, Senator Campbell, that you read a few speeches of your leader, the now Prime Minister, Mr Howard. I think your environmental package is already being shown for the con that it really is. I think the record shows that we took a number of steps. I would just like to outline—for your benefit, Senator Campbell—a few of the things that we did when we were in government that you opposed. Under a coalition government, the things that would have gone ahead—because it is clearly on the record as such—would be things such as the mining of Coronation Hill—

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. The debate is in relation to a report on the privatisation of Telstra. There will be an occasion for senators to contribute to the report on the Natural Heritage Trust bill when it is tabled, and I think that will be in about a fortnight's time or possibly even next week. The terms of reference and this report do not deal with the environmental record of the previous disgraced Labor government. I suggest that Senator Murphy, if he is to be relevant to the debate and the topic before the Senate, would need to restrict his remarks to the privatisation of Telstra, which is the subject of that report.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I want to speak on the point of order. It was the government which linked the sale of Telstra to the environment, not us. It was the government that has continually said that, for the $1 billion land fund to be set up, the sale of Telstra had to proceed. So I would suggest to you that I am quite relevant to this report with regard to the sale of Telstra by mentioning the land fund and the relevance of it. It is the government that put it on the agenda. The government is the one that said that to the Australian public. It is the government that keeps threatening the Democrats and everybody else by saying, `Well, if you don't pass the Telstra bill, there will not be any land fund.' So I think it is quite relevant, Mr Acting Deputy President.

—As long as you maintain relevance and highlight the relevance, Senator Murphy, I will listen carefully to what you say. Obviously, the prime purpose of this debate is to debate the Telstra report but, where other matters are relevant to that, I will listen carefully.

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. As I said to Senator Campbell, in terms of records on the environment—and this is directly linked to this particular report because this particular report does deal with the sale of Telstra, which is going to provide the money, according to the government and the Prime Minister, for a land fund that will do certain other things—this has been claimed by the now government as being the best environment policy that has ever been. That is fully relevant to the sale and to this report.

BREAK.PARA: I just want to point out for Senator Campbell's benefit the government's real record in terms of environmental matters which, I think, demonstrates the big con that the government has effectively pulled over the Australian public's eyes in terms of what its previous record was. I think it is important to remind Senator Campbell at least that, had the coalition been in government for the last 13 years, the mining of Coronation Hill would have gone ahead. Uluru and Kakadu would have been handed back to the Northern Territory government—because that was the position that you took—instead of the indigenous people. Wet tropics would have been logged. More recently we have seen the Port Hinchinbrook situation and, of course, there was also the woodchip issue. Senator Campbell, you really ought to take a look at your record. Do not try to pull some con with regard to promising $1 billion for some ridiculous land fund which will come out of the sale of Telstra.

As I said, in terms of Telstra's value to the Australian public per se, you just cannot go past the amount of money that it expends in this country purchasing both services and goods. There are huge amounts of money. In 1992 it had a five-year expenditure program which was in excess of $40 billion. It expended in 1994-95 some $3 billion. I think some 50 companies were awarded contracts over $10 million. Over $200 million has been invested in research. All of those things will be affected with the privatisation of Telstra, if it should proceed, either in part or in whole.

We do not know. At the moment, we have Senator Alston at odds with the Prime Minister. He is saying that you lot are going to sell it all. We know you are. We know you want to. But, hopefully—with the opposition, the Democrats and the Greens and the two Independent senators—you will not be allowed to proceed with the sale. That is the important fact, and that is what should not be allowed to happen.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The time for discussion of reports has expired. It being 7.20 p.m., I propose the question:
