SPEECH.SPEAKER: Conroy, Sen Stephen

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on an issue raised yesterday in the other place by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Reith) relating to the Communications Workers Union 1994 ballot. The minister raised the findings of Justice Moore on the issue of electoral fraud during this ballot. I also note from the Hansard that the Prime Minister (Mr Howard) participated in the discussion. I will return to that later.

SPEECH.PARA: The minister has been poorly advised on this matter. If he had read the complete judgment, he would have been less inclined to grandstand on this matter. I would like to read from page 18 of Justice Moore's findings, dated 14 August 1996. I quote:

. . . As this is likely to be the last judgement given in the inquiry it is appropriate that I refer to one other matter. It is not relevant to the issues I have dealt with but it is, in my opinion, a matter that should not go unrecorded. Following the orders of the 21 June 1996 further examination of ballot material was undertaken by Mr Westwood. He has given evidence about that further examination. What was revealed was a matter that I had not appreciated to that point, namely that in his original examination there were a limited number of fraudulently completed ballot papers favouring candidates who were not part of the Natour/Jarman team. Those numbers were increased by his later examination. Thus, it would appear, electoral fraud was not the province only of those supporting the Natour/Jarman team but it was perpetrated by others involved in the 1994 election as well.
Justice Moore has exposed that supporters of the Cook‐Battese team were involved in electoral fraud. Was there any indication of who might have been involved in this?

I would now like to read to senators from a submission to Justice Moore from Edward Mason, dated 15 July 1996. Mr Mason was a candidate in the 1994 elections and a member of the Cook‐Battese team. It states:

. . . I do not believe that Noel Battese is fit and proper to hold office as a caretaker before the new elections. I have formed this opinion because of my knowledge of his actions during the 1994 elections.

Prior to the 1994 elections I attended a series of meetings that were held at Noel Battese's house. At these meetings I tried unsuccessfully to raise issues of campaign organisation but all Noel Battese was interested in discussing was vote collecting and how many ballot papers various people could collect for him. Joe Kanan was at all of these meetings and this was the only subject he wished to discuss. Noel Battese was constantly asking me throughout the campaign how many votes I could get "in the hand". I told Noel that I believed that vote collecting was illegal and that I would not be doing it. I believe that Noel Battese was heavily involved in the frauding of the ballot in the overturned 1994 elections and that this should disqualify him from holding office before the new elections. There are several witnesses who I believe could verify my claims.

So there you have it. A member of the Cook‐Battese team has pointed directly at who is responsible. Yet Battese is the instigator of the challenge to the election on the grounds of electoral fraud. One of his own team has given him up.

In fact, Mr Paul Westwood, the court appointed handwriting expert, in his report of 10 July 1996, points out that a number of individuals have completed ballot papers and voted for both tickets. So what the court has found is that supporters of the Cook‐Battese ticket have also filled out ballot papers voting for their opponents. Then they have demanded an electoral inquiry into fraud.

I would like now to return to the role of the Prime Minister in this affair. Why, senators may ask. Well, I will tell you. In 1994, Prime Minister Howard took a direct role in this union election. He wrote a letter, using Commonwealth parliamentary funds, to members of the CWU. The question that Mr Howard's office has never answered is: how did his office gain access to the union voting roll? But the critical issue is that John Howard endorsed the Cook‐Battese team in a union how‐to‐vote card mailed to all members of the union. An extract from the how‐to‐vote card titled `For a strong honest leadership', which was included with John Howard's letter of endorsement for Cook and Battese, read as follows:
This time, a Liberal team is presenting itself with the full backing of the Liberal Party of Australia—

The how‐to‐vote card then lists Cook and Battese as the preferred candidates to support. Clearly, the Prime Minister is a supporter of this team. I ask: how did Mr Howard's office gain access to the CWU voting roll? Can the Prime Minister assure the Senate that his office was not involved, as a supporter, in collecting and filling out ballot papers during this ballot? Is the Prime Minister willing to cooperate with the federal police in their inquiries? I look forward to the inquiry into electoral matters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney, Sen John

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak on a great event that has been announced for the central coast of New South Wales, and that is the approval for the International Garden Festival and Planet Earth 2000 Expo. It is interesting to note the origins of this particular garden festival. The festivals started in Europe after World War II and often they were used to develop or redevelop degraded and bombed out land in Europe. But now they are run right across the world, particularly in Europe, because they represent good business. The Dutch flower industry, for example, is worth $10 billion annually. So it was a great thing for Australia to be one of the few countries outside Europe to be accepted to hold this expo and it was a great thing in particular for the state of New South Wales and also for the city of Gosford on the central coast.

SPEECH.PARA: On Australia Day 1994, the city of Gosford won the right to host this A1 Expo International Garden Festival. To give the Senate some idea of the scale of it, it is not just, as some people often say, a flower show. It is actually on the scale of Expo 88 in Brisbane in terms of the size of the event and the amount of economic activity that it will generate. The total investment for the project has been estimated to be about $230 million. Because it is being staged in the year 2000 through to 2001, it will ideally complement the Olympic Games. People will be able to come out to Australia in the last part of the year 2000, go to the Olympic Games and then move on and see this brilliant expo of horticultural products on the central coast of New South Wales.

BREAK.PARA: The event is to be run under the auspices of the Bureau of International Expositions in Paris and the AIPH in Brussels. It is being run in Australia by the Nursery Industry Association of Australia. It has the rights to the event and the site is the magnificent Mount Penang site above Gosford in New South Wales, which overlooks, from a high elevation, the beautiful Brisbane Waters. The people who have come out to Australia from Europe have concluded that this is truly a magnificent site.
The Prime Minister, John Howard, announced federal support last week in a letter released to Jim Lloyd, the new Liberal member for Robertson. The letter says:

The Commonwealth Government supports the concept of a commercially viable international garden festival and is willing to consider an appropriate Commonwealth contribution consistent with national responsibilities for such an event.

And $300,000 has now been provided by the Commonwealth government as seed funding for the next stage of the development of this exciting exposition. The Prime Minister has agreed to the seed funding to assist in the further development of the concept and scope of this project and to assist in getting it through to its main stage, which will involve private investment. When the private investors get involved—and this is projected to start next year—the massive task of horticultural planting on the site will begin. There will be a private sector underwriter‐developer consortium which will be taking this project through to its completion. In the end, it is believed that the value, the profit, to the consortium could be in the order of $40 million to $50 million.

Once private sector funding is in place, other government assistance will follow, including the construction of an Australian pavilion which will be a cultural asset to the Central Coast long after the floral exhibition has finished. Despite the value of this project—its value in so many ways—it was almost lost by the bungling of the ALP. Local member, Michael Lee, the man who was formally Minister for Communications, hesitated, did not give it support and did not take it to cabinet last year, and the event was almost lost.

Fortunately the new Liberal member for Robertson, Jim Lloyd, picked up the bundle and has run with it, with the assistance of the Hon. Barry Cohen who is a former minister in this place. They have worked hard together to get this project on track, including visiting 16 cabinet ministers to explain its benefits. I have never seen any one project get so much push and support in this place. For this reason, it finally paid off. In very tight budgetary conditions, they got the seed funding they required. The importance of this can be seen when you consider the economic and social benefits of the project.

It is estimated by Traceys, a consultant group, that it will actually create $1½ billion in economic activity. It will bring to the event 5.7 million visitors. It will create 18,000, one‐year full‐time equivalent jobs and the after‐value use of the improvements is estimated at $40 million. It will create a wonderful environmental and entertainment infrastructure right on the edge of Sydney which will be left permanently for the citizens of the Central Coast and for the whole of the New South Wales community.

It is much more than a flower show. It is a project of vision and great excitement and the government is now facilitating the private sector investment to generate real jobs and create real employment in the area. It is an opportunity for Australia to establish another very large international event right on the millennium which will focus the attention of the world on Australia.

The Planet earth 2000 exhibition, as it is called, has other dimensions, apart from what I have mentioned. It creates trade, research and development opportunities. It will showcase Australia as an innovative leader in horticulture, primary industries, care and management of the environment and new technologies in water management and communications, and it will boost our exports, especially to Asia. The Senate should welcome this very bold initiative and, in particular, the support of the Howard government to help make it happen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Forshaw, Sen Michael

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam President, this is the first occasion on which I have had an opportunity to congratulate you on your recent election to this position. Tonight I rise to speak about this government's disgraceful decision to inflict upon the residents living near the Holsworthy base fear, panic and despair as a result of their decision to include Holsworthy as a potential site for Sydney's second airport. As I have said on previous occasions—and I will go on saying because this is an issue that is going to become bigger and bigger as the residents to be affected come to understand what is in store for them—it was this government that, prior to the election, failed to outline to the people their plan to make Holsworthy Sydney's second airport. After the election, with the announcement, hundreds of thousands of residents who thought they were living safe in the knowledge that the site had been rejected as long as 12 years ago were suddenly faced with the prospect of a 24‐hour, full domestic and international airport being built in their backyard.

SPEECH.PARA: This is a government that has made a lot of noise about its promises and how they would keep them. We have seen their track record so far. When the government announced that it would include Holsworthy as a potential site, the Minister for Transport and Regional Development, Mr Sharp, waxed lyrical about how the process of the EIS would be inclusive and would enable full community consultation and input to the decision. On 28 May, in the other place, the member for Hughes, Mrs Danna Vale, asked the minister:
Can the government guarantee the people of Hughes that the environmental impact assessment conducted into the Badgerys Creek and Holsworthy sites will be fully comprehensive on both sites?
In his answer the minister said:

The study will follow the guidelines established by the Senate Select Committee on Aircraft Noise, which involves full public consultation, full industry consultation and its being a transparent process. The honourable member for Hughes is concerned to ensure that residents of her electorate will have their views considered in this process. I assure the honourable member for Hughes that that will be the case: their views will be considered and given great weight in the process of determining the environmental impact study.

One of the recommendations of the Senate Select Committee on Aircraft Noise was that an independent auditor would be appointed to oversee the EIS process, but no such independent auditor has yet been appointed, notwithstanding that the draft EIS guidelines have been prepared and released and the period for public comment has now closed. So a fundamental promise of this government regarding the EIS process has simply been discarded. The people have been treated with contempt because that committee found that, to protect the community's interests, it was vitally important that an independent auditor be appointed to run parallel with the EIS process being conducted by the proponent and the consultants involved. Again, on 27 June, the member for Hughes, Mrs Danna Vale, asked the minister this question:

Can the minister assure the House that the constituents of Hughes will be given the opportunity of making submissions on the draft guidelines so as to ensure that all relevant matters are canvassed by the environmental impact statement itself?
I remind the Senate that Mrs Vale is the Liberal member for Hughes. The response from the minister was—and I quote in part from his answer:
Submissions will be invited from interested persons in the public.

In relation to the last aspect of the question of the honourable member for Hughes—that is, whether members of her electorate will be able to make comments and submissions in regard to the EIS process—the answer is yes. They will be welcomed, we will expect them and we will treat them with due regard and great importance.

This was from the minister, after having broken a fundamental commitment to follow the guidelines laid down by the Senate select committee by not appointing, as that committee recommended, an independent auditor.

PARA.BREAK: What has been the reaction since the minister's comments on 27 June welcoming the involvement of the community? Over 52,000 submissions were made to the Environment Protection Agency by residents in and around the Holsworthy site—an incredible response, indicating the outrage and the concern of those people. What was the re sponse by the Minister for the Environment and Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Hill? His response to the agency under his administration having received 52,000 submissions was contained in an article in the Daily Telegraph of 3 September, which reads:

SPEECH.PARA: Environment Minister Robert Hill questioned the intentions of the alliance—
that is, the community alliance representing the residents in the area—
in sending a deluge of submissions on the environmental impact statement guidelines.
"It appeared to be an attempt to clog up the system," Senator Hill's spokesman said.

What a disgraceful, despicable remark from a spokesman for the minister. At no stage has the minister disowned that statement. The attitude of this government, after welcoming and calling for comments and submissions and promising the community that they would have the opportunity to be fully involved, to have their submissions treated with great respect, has been to say, `All you're trying to do is clog up the system because you happen to put in excess of 50,000 submissions to the Environment Protection Agency.'

That sort of contemptible attitude has been further demonstrated this week when, despite numerous attempts by representatives of the South‐West Sydney Community Alliance, the group formed to fight this airport proposal in south‐west Sydney, to meet with the minister, Mr Sharp, he has declined to do so. They have been to his office in Goulburn, they have been down here this week, but he will not meet with them.

This is a government and a minister who say, `We welcome the community being involved.' This is a government that attacked the former Labor government over the EIS process for the third runway at Mascot. This government said they would be judged by how they opened themselves up to community involvement and community input. They have been found sadly wanting. In fact, more than that, their attitude is clearly one where they have no regard at all for the interests of the residents of south‐west Sydney. They have no regard at all for the interests of the residents, the electors, of the seat of Hughes. Not only did they inflict this decision upon them after the election—a clear breach of a commitment given at the election—but when the people put in their submissions in accordance with the procedures laid down, they were abused and criticised, and there were allegations that their submissions were nothing more than an attempt to clog up the system.

This issue is not going to go away. A lot of questions still need to be answered by the government. I am going to continue to stand up in this place on behalf of the residents of south‐west Sydney because, unfortunately, the member for Hughes elected at the recent election is really doing nothing at all for the residents of her electorate. Those of us on this side are going to stand up for those residents and their legitimate concerns.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McKiernan, Sen James

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be fairly brief tonight. I want to finish a contribution I was making in this place yesterday on the matter of telephone towers, which is of enormous concern in the community in which I live, which is the City of Wanneroo. Before people think I am going to talk about Wanneroo and start to panic, I say to them that I am actually confining my remarks tonight to telephone towers within the boundaries of the municipality of the City of Wanneroo. As I said, it is not only of concern within Wanneroo; it is of concern right throughout Australia, certainly in the built‐up areas of Australia at this stage. But it is of particular concern where I live and where some local action has been taken on it.

SPEECH.PARA: By way of a national perspective, I note that the National President of the Local Government Association, who is also the Mayor of Concord in Sydney, is also concerned about the matter. He tipped somewhat of a bucket on Austel, the regulatory authority. In an article in the West Australian he is reported as saying:
"Austel is just a pathetic organisation which is not performing its function. They are useless,". . .

That shows you why the people are so concerned about this matter. At a state local government level, there is huge concern within the WA municipal authority and its membership. They have expressed the community's fears about health, aesthetics and property values as the national program of installing telecommunications towers and infrastructure facilities proceeds.

At a more local level, one of my local councillors in Wanneroo, Graeme Major, said in an article in the West Australian on 5 August that the Wanneroo City Council was considering the approval for the erection of 14 telecommunications towers within the boundaries of the municipality. Councillor Major said:
. . . people were worried by the proximity of towers to residential areas and the lack of research into their long-term effects.
"There is a lack of evidence on the effects of microwave radiation and the carriers have not communicated to communities very well . . .
He went on to say:
By 2006 there is expected to be one tower for every street.

That is not something that we should be looking forward to. We are taking action about this on a local level directly into this parliament. The local Labor Party candidate for the seat of Joondalup, Dianne Guise, who is also President of the WA Council of State Schools Organisations, has produced a petition which calls on the Senate to:
(a) immediately commence a moratorium on the erection of mobile phone towers;
(b) institute, as a matter of urgency, a Senate inquiry into health and environmental risks that may be associated with mobile phone towers;

(c) enact, in liaison with State and Territory Governments, appropriate legislation that shall prevent the erection of any future mobile phone towers in the immediate vicinity of any school, kindergarten, child care centre, recreation centre or playground.

Some of those petitions have already been lodged in the Senate by me, and I personally agree with the sentiments as contained in the petitions. I note also for the record that the local members of parliament, the member for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans) and the member for Moore (Mr Filing), have also taken action in the other place in regard to this.

PARA.BREAK: I commend the work of Ms Guise in enacting, on behalf of the local community, these petitions. Hopefully, the matter will be lis tened to by the regulatory authorities and by the relevant minister, who can in fact do something about it. Hopefully, Austel, who is subject to some degree of criticism, which I have repeated here tonight in this place, will listen again to the criticism. If it does not, there will be further pressure from within this chamber and, I have no doubt, from within the other chamber to get action in regard to the safety of the residents in municipalities right around Australia to prevent the damage that is being done to people by the erection of these facilities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Neal, Sen Belinda

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not initially planning to speak on the adjournment debate this evening, but I was drawn to it because of some inaccuracies put forward by Senator Tierney in relation to what has become known as Planet Earth 2000—originally, the international garden festival—which is proposed for Mount Penang just outside Gosford. I did not catch all of what Senator Tierney said, but certainly he was attempting to suggest, firstly, that the previous federal Labor government had not been fully supportive of that garden festival and, secondly, that in fact this coalition federal government has made some sort of commitment to it, which in fact it has not at all.

SPEECH.PARA: Just to give you a brief history of the situation, in 1994 Barry Cohen, the ex-member for Robertson and former Labor member, in conjunction with the Nursery Association of New South Wales and the Nursery Association of Australia, began to promote a garden festival for the central coast area. Some examination was done of various sites available and it was decided that it should be a site located at Mount Penang, which is presently owned by the state government.

Barry Cohen, in conjunction with the nursery association, put forward an application that theirs should be the preferable site. They narrowly succeeded despite a very clever bid put in by Wollongong. The idea was promoted in the next year or so and a large amount of community support was gathered and a proposition was put to Michael Lee, the then minister for tourism.

It has been said that in some way Michael Lee's support was lacking or that he was not as supportive as he could have been. I say that in fact the position was quite contrary to that. He expressed very strong in principle support. He supported the application of the nursery association to the Bureau of International Expositions to hold the garden festival in Australia at Mount Penang. He, along with cabinet, approved a payment by the federal government—a deposit for that application. He then went on to ask proponents of the garden festival to inquire into and advise him how that proposition could be furthered and how they proposed to bring it about.

Unfortunately, there was some lack of direction in what took place. Maybe things did not progress on the part of that community group as quickly as it could have. At that stage, in 1995, I became involved and decided that a little bit more direction would be helpful. So we formed a committee for the garden festival. The committee was comprised of Tony Sansom, the Labor mayor of Gosford; Grant McBride, the state member for the Entrance; Les Eastcott, the Vice‐Chancellor of the university at Ourimbah; representatives from the nursery association; and Barry Cohen, who, as I said, has had a very long and abiding interest in and enthusiasm for this project.

The committee was a great success. The local government body, Gosford council, donated sufficient moneys for consultants to be employed to prepare quite a substantial report of some several hundred pages. This was presented in turn to the Premier of New South Wales, head of the Labor government, who greeted it with some enthusiasm. In August last year, he suggested that he would support the project. There has been further discussion and investigation since then.

In August of this year the Premier made a formal announcement that they would financially support the project. He has indicated that they will hand over the land at Mount Penang, valued at approximately $20 million, for the purposes of conducting the garden festival and also, if necessary, will seed it completely in order that it can be used as security to raise the necessary funds. At the same time, he has also provided a grant of $300,000 towards setting up the office, and appointed a CEO, Keith Dedden—a person of some repute in the area; he is presently employed by Landcom and was formerly the general manager of the Gosford City Council—to ensure that this project comes about.

In spite of all that has happened and the letter that the Premier has sent to John Howard, nothing has occurred by way of real support by this federal coalition government. A letter was sent by Bob Carr to John Howard indicating what contribution he was making to the festival and asking the federal government to make a formal commitment. The letter was sent with sufficient time to allow provision to be made in the budget but, disappointingly for those supporters of the festival and for the community on the central coast, he failed to make any provision. In fact, it is only just recently—last week—that he has responded at all.

What we have received from John Howard and his coalition government, despite two years of coalition members saying that they are supporting the project, is a very carefully worded and negative letter which spends three or four paragraphs pointing out all the negatives of conducting an international garden festival. It eventually says:

Taking all these factors into account, the Commonwealth would be prepared to consider limited financial assistance to facilitate further development of the IDF concept, including examination of the scope for private sector investment to underpin the viability of the proposal.

In other words, `We'll think about it.' After two years of saying, `If we were in government, we would be right behind it', all we get is them saying that they will consider it. This is after the state government has spent in excess of $1 million investigating reports and has now committed $20 million in land plus a further $300,000 in funds for the organising committee.

The real situation is that unless the federal government and the Prime Minister, John Howard, make a real commitment—not just consider making a commitment—this garden festival will not go ahead. The consequences of this garden festival not going ahead are dire for those people on the central coast. This project is a major employment creating project for the central coast for the next three years. The garden festival and exposition, as it will now be, will be held at the same time as the Olympics. We would hope that those international visitors who are attending the Olympics will also attend the garden festival, as well as the large number of people who are solely interested in the garden festival itself.

I put it to the Senate that the possible failure of this garden festival is entirely on the head of this federal coalition government. I ask the Prime Minister to consider well his actions and to change his mind and actually make a real financial commitment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles, Sen Susan

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator McKiernan and Senator Neal for giving me a couple of minutes to put some comments on the record. I only partially heard the comments that were made earlier by Senator Margetts in relation to alleged badgering of witnesses. I know that the Australian Pensioners and Superannuants League made a precise comment about me and one of my Senate colleagues at the Telstra hearings in Brisbane.

SPEECH.PARA: I wanted to put on the record the actual questions that I asked the witness, Mrs Bowden, in particular because it has very much become folklore that we actually badgered Mrs Bowden. I have actually sought the approval of Senator Neal to seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the letter of response to the Australian Pensioners and Superannuants League in response to their letter seeking an apology from me.
Leave granted.

PARA.EMPHASIS: I am in receipt of your letter to me dated 25th July and that addressed to the President of the Senate relating to the Senate Committee enquiry into the partial privatisation of Telstra held in Brisbane on 11 July.
Firstly, I most definitely decline your offer to apologise to either the League in general, or Mrs Bowden in particular for a number of reasons.

SPEECH.PARA: Please find enclosed a copy of all pages of Hansard where Mrs Bowden and I had any exchange
Can you please tell me which of the four questions I asked her or the three conclusions I drew from her evidence were so dreadful?

Could it be the question which followed from Mrs Bowden's claim that "we decide policies at conference—at our state conference and at our federal conference" to which I then asked "which conference has decided your position on this Bill?"

With Mrs Bowden having said that state and federal conferences make policy decisions, I simply thought she would tell me which one and when it was held. Instead her answer came as quite a shock when she then responded "Listen my friend. As far as this Bill is concerned, our State Management Committee as the elected management committee for the Queensland branch has every right to decide its policy. . . "

One could only have drawn a conclusion from Mrs Bowden's reply that in fact NO conference, state or federal, had been consulted (as she originally claimed was the case on this Bill). It was a decision of the management committee to oppose it. Therefore, my following question of clarification was quite in order and appropriate—"The answer to my question is no, you have not consulted your membership; is that right?"
Any Senator can only go on what a witness says. In this case, Mrs Bowden inferred on thing but when asked specifics, said another. I can hardly be blamed for that.

I considered it was important to establish the method of consultation, given that so many pensioners have taken, and continue to take, a very different position on this legislation to that which was presented by the League and deeply resent their views being ignored.
Having clarified the answer, I actually requested that we move on as I had many other questions I wished to ask about other claims made in Mrs Bowden's evidence such as:
. allegations that price capping will go;
. the effect of privatisation in New Zealand and Britain;
. that employee share options would be overshadowed by big business;
. that country people did not want partial privatisation—despite the fact that the National Farmers Federation have actually surveyed their members and received a 66% positive response;
. that cross‐subsidisation would be removed;
. that the Universal Service Obligations will be compromised by the Bill;
. that directory and emergency services and maintenance "would be gravely affected"; and
. that all hearing impaired people "strongly object to the Bill"
The list of false claims was extensive and they deserved to be scrutinised as to their foundation. I was denied that opportunity due to a lack of time.

You also referred to my comments about Mrs Bowden's 30 year work history with Telecom as irrelevant. I did not raise it as a credential. She did. All I did was acknowledge what she herself had stated and commented that her background showed. What is offensive about that? Most people would be complimented on such a comment.
I repeat, my only questions to Mrs Bowden were on the basis of the League's submission and about the actual conference to which she referred on page 387 of Hansard .
I, along with any of my colleagues, would be failing in our duty to establish fact from fiction in public hearings, if we did not thoroughly question all witnesses.
In time, we may see a situation when the League takes an unbiased and totally objective view on a legislative issue. I await the day.

As a consequence much of the evidence that has been provided to the enquiry in question, I will be moving to reinstate the process of placing all witnesses under oath—a process which was abandoned by the Labor Party when they won office in 1983.
Yours sincerely,
Sue Knowles
Senator for Western Australia

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I wanted to put on the record the fact that my questions to Mrs Bowden were very simple questions based on her assertion that their league had surveyed their membership. One of my questions was:

SPEECH.PARA: Could I just clarify whether you have run any survey of your membership on this bill as opposed to general policy. You say that you have had a policy position on privatisation for a considerable length of time. I am respectfully asking you now: have you surveyed your membership on this bill and its ramifications?
That is hardly what I would consider badgering a witness. My next question was:
Which conference has decided your position on this bill? From where was that representation drawn?
They are hardly questions that are badgering a witness. Mrs Bowden refused to answer my question. Therefore, I said:
The answer to my question is no, you have not consulted your membership; is that right?
That is hardly a question that could be considered badgering a witness. Therefore, I decided not to ask her any more questions because Mrs Bowden refused to answer the question. I said:
You have not done it, therefore we will move on.

That is hardly a position that is badgering the witness. Most people would be complimented on the appearance that they had served things competently. Mrs Bowden claimed that she had been a Telecom worker for 30 years. I simply noted that she had been a Telecom worker for 30 years, saying:
You have worked for Telecom for 30 years and it shows.
You have come with a preconceived position.

Most people under normal circumstances would be complimented on appearing before a committee in that capacity. For some reason, Mrs Bowden and Labor Party members have seen fit to manipulate that entire exchange. That is a summary of the entire exchange. The response of my correspondence will detail it in full. (Time expired)

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Telstra: Complaint by Mr John Doohan

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Margetts, Sen Dee

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney‐General, upon notice, on 22 May 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did the Attorney‐General's office, on 30 November 1995, receive a facsimile from Mr John Doohan of Willagee, Western Australia: if so did this communication inform the Attorney‐General that the Australian Federal Police (AFP) recently provided a briefing to the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) based on false information provided by the AFP by Telecom Australia (Telstra) subsequent to complaints from Mr Doohan to the AFP and the Attorney‐General that Telstra had committed criminal acts against Mr Doohan.
(2) Were Mr Doohan's complaints against Telstra investigated by the AFP in association with AFP `Operation Oregon' which encompassed investigation of the so‐called `Casualties of Telecom'.
(3) Did the DPP refuse to act on Mr Doohan's complaints on the basis that the DPP is not an investigative agency and prosecutes only after matters are investigated by the AFP or other agency.
(4) Was the AFP brief and/or advice to the DPP in these matters influenced by the allegedly false information provided to the AFP by either Telstra or the Ombudsman's Office.

(5) Was the AFP brief and/or advice to the DPP influenced by previously secret‐classified assessments in files about Mr Doohan's alleged mental and other alleged personality defects held by the department, the AFP, and the Australian Security Intelligence Organization (ASIO).
(6) Was the allegedly false information provided to the AFP, and therefore to the DPP, given by Telstra under oath or other requirement of truth and accuracy.
(7) Will the Attorney‐General direct that these matters be properly investigated.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Vanstone, Sen Amanda
ANSWER.MINISTERIAL: Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney‐General has provided the following answers to the honourable senator's questions:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes.
I am advised that the question accurately summarises the contents of the facsimile message.
(2) I am advised that the AFP carried out a thorough investigation of Mr Doohan's complaint, taking account of all information received, including that received from Mr Doohan.
All relevant material was submitted to the DPP.

(3) I am advised that the DPP informed Mr Doohan that it was unable to act on his complaints that the information provided to it was false and that Telstra had committed criminal acts against him, because it is not an investigatory body.
(4) I am advised that the AFP has no knowledge of allegedly false information provided by either Telstra or the Office of the Commonwealth Ombudsman.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Exercise Tandem Thrust: Rest and Recreation Leave

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds, Sen Margaret

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 9 August 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What planning has taken place to appropriately manage the rest and recreation (R and R leave of the 17 000 service personnel participating in Tandem Thrust, in Shoalwater Bay in March 1997.
(2) How many service personnel will be on leave at any one time.
(3) What will be the maximum period of that leave.
(4) Which Queensland cities have been recommended for service personnel taking leave.
(5) Which cities in other States will be included as shore leave destinations.
(6) Has a social impact assessment of shore leave for March 1997 been prepared.
(7) Will the Department of Defence utilise records of the Vietnam war period when United States (US) service personnel spent R and R leave in Australia to assist in planning for the 1997 period.
(8) Have State and local governments been informed of the need to start planning for the US personnel.
(9) Will the Federal Government be providing advisory support and financial assistance for additional services required in those centres selected as R and R destinations.

(10) Will Federal and State police ministers be introducing new programs to ensure police liaison in each centre to maintain effective communication and practices between civilian and military police.
(11) What role will the Federal Police play in relation to maintaining service/civilian relations and good order for the duration of joint training.

(12) Will the Federal and State health ministers be introducing new programs to guarantee access to casualty services and health services relating to sexually transmitted diseases, drug counselling and pregnancy termination.

(13) Will Federal and State ministers for the status of women be introducing new programs of assistance for localised women's services which provide education and counselling for sexually transmitted diseases, unplanned pregnancy, sexual harassment and sexual assault.
(14) Has the department calculated the additional financial cost of the provision of social services to ensure the health, safety and security of both civilians and visitors.
(15) Does the Federal Government have a current policy about prostitution which was legalised during World War II.
(16) Will the Federal Government require State governments that have not yet decriminalised prostitution to update their laws before March 1997.

(17) What requirements does the Australian Government have for an updating of the Status of Forces Agreement to bring it to an appropriate standard to reflect the social attitudes, law and practices of modern Australia.
(18) Will the Australian Government require the US to sign a code of conduct relating to off‐base behaviour of its service personnel.
(19) Where an Australian law is breached, who will initiate prosecution and how are the divisions of responsibility to be allocated between military and civilian police.
(20) In the event of a criminal offence being committed, what processes will be adopted to ensure that the case is tried in Australia and that the victim will be entitled to compensation.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Newman, Sen Jocelyn

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) United States (US) Navy ships will be conducting port visits to Australian cities both before and after Exercise Tandem Thrust. US forces coordinate their visiting activities with appropriate Australian authorities. Working with representatives from the US Embassy or Consulate, US forces and Australian officials (Commonwealth and State) will address such issues as shore patrol, police liaison, professional exchanges, social and athletic activities. Of the approximately 17 000 US personnel participating in the exercise, only 4‐5 000 personnel will come ashore. The majority will be in Shoalwater Bay Training Area, but some US personnel will be involved in supporting the exercise at other locations such as airfields. Once ashore, because of safety and environmental considerations, their activities will be carefully managed. No rest and recreation (R and R) leave will be granted in the Shoalwater Bay Training Area.

Australian and US military personnel have conducted discussions to plan the R and R of service personnel involved in Tandem Thrust. The Australian Defence Force (ADF), cognisant of the number of personnel attending, has provided the US with advice on the preferred way to minimise social impact. Ship visits to a number of ports for R and R, staggered over the course of the pre and post exercise periods, have been recommended and adopted by the US in their planning.

(2) Eleven ships are currently planned to participate in the exercise. US ships deployed away from their homeport are typically divided into three duty sections. At any given time in port, up to two‐thirds of a ship's crew could be permitted liberty. The largest concentration of libertymen will be associated with the aircraft carrier USS Independence, which may have a daily liberty party of up to 2 000 members. Less than 500 US Air Force personnel will participate in Tandem Thrust. Since US Air Force personnel will be scheduled on official airlift in and out of the exercise locations, few will take leave in conjunction with their temporary duty assignments in Australia. US Army personnel will also be ashore in various locations, but in much smaller numbers.

Only two major Australian ships will be conducting post exercise visits, with one ship visiting Townsville, the other Mackay. The remainder of the ships will return to their home port, Sydney, on completion of the exercise. The majority of Aust‐
ralian Army and Air Force personnel will redeploy direct to their home locations at the conclusion of the exercise.

(3) Leave duration will depend upon the number of days a ship is visiting a specific port. Usually, leave expires on board a ship on the morning of the day after it is granted. The longest period that Australian ships will be in port will be four days. As the Royal Australian Navy (RAN) ships carry 430 personnel in total, and the visits are not concurrent with visiting US ships, RAN leave is not expected to have a noticeable social impact in either Townsville or Mackay.

(4) The schedule for US ship visits is still being developed, but Cairns and Brisbane are two Queensland cities being considered. The Australian ship visit program is also still being developed, however, the Australian ships will visit either Townsville or Mackay, after the exercise.
(5) Sydney and Melbourne are likely destinations for US visits.

(6) No social impact assessment has been undertaken, as the degree of potential impact has been significantly reduced by early planning with US authorities. Measures taken to reduce impact have been to utilise a number of alternative locations for port visits and to limit the number of ships visiting at any one time. The largest port visit will be conducted by up to four US ships to Sydney, a city well used to, and capable of, hosting such visits.

(7) US military personnel have enjoyed a long and successful history of visiting Australia for both work and pleasure. There are no records from the Vietnam war period the US would refer to in planning ship visits. ADF planning staff do not have ready access to leave plans from the period of the Vietnam war. The majority of these files/records have either been archived or destroyed. Furthermore, noting the significant social changes which have occurred in the intervening years, it is considered that these records would not provide useful planning data for 1997.

(8) State and local governments have not been officially informed by the ADF of plans for US personnel to visit during the exercise, as the planning is still formative. Staff discussions have commenced with a number of government organisations, including The Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority, Townsville and Gladstone Port

Authorities, and the Shoalwater Bay Environmental Advisory Committee. Defence Centre Brisbane is planning to conduct a briefing for the Queensland Premier and Cabinet during September 1996. A press release on the exercise was issued on 26 July 1996, concurrent with the Australia‐US Ministerial Talks held in Sydney.

(17) The Government considers that the Status of Forces Agreement (SOFA) covering US forces in Australia to be satisfactory and appropriate to current circumstances.

(19) All members of visiting forces, including US forces, are subject to Australian law while they are in Australia. Specifically, the SOFA contains detailed provision for the exercise of jurisdiction by both Australian and US authorities over criminal offences committed in Australia by US military personnel.

(20) The SOFA has proved to be effective in ensuring that visiting US personnel are subject to a clear legal framework and are appropriately dealt with for any offences which they may commit. The SOFA also addresses claims procedures for individuals who sustain damage as a result of activities by US forces in the performance of official duty or arising from circumstances for which US forces are otherwise responsible.
